PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will:

(1) prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as real estate agents, mortgage underwriters, insurance companies, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment.
(2) add to the cost of business and increase interest rates and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray:
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 103 citizens) and Calvert (from 79 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cooney (from 307 citizens) and Jones (from 1,553 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Romania, whose Human Rights Record had been worse than that of South Africa's even before she embarked on a diabolic village destruction program, deservedly attracts worldwide condemnation. The systematic cultural genocide of the peoples affected must be prevented.
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) the Australian Parliament establish whether or not Romania has satisfied fully her obligations under the Treaty of Trianon (1920) and the Peace Treaty of Paris (1947),
(2) if found that Romania violates these agreements, the signatures representing Australia jointly or singularly be withdrawn from the thus invalidated documents.
(3) Australia table her findings at the appropriate forums of the United Nations.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.

Your humble petitioners pray that, the Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End Of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador: Military Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia humbly pray that:
1. The Parliament heeds our profound concern regarding the Penal Code Reforms of the ARENA Government in El Salvador.

2. We request that as these reforms breach the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and in consideration of the escalation of human rights violations by El Salvadoran Armed forces, the Australian Government convey to the United States that all forms of military aid to the Salvadoran Government should be suspended.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION REGULATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, Notices of Motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in my name for three sitting days hence, for the disallowance of the Australian Federal Police Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 139 and made under the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, and of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 150 and made under the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Act 1989. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances at its meeting this morning considered correspondence from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in regard to the Committee's concerns about the Australian Federal Police (Amendment) Regulations. These concerns were the apparent lack of safeguards and criteria for a legislative scheme under which the Australian Federal Police (AFP) supplied what appeared to be sensitive personal information upon payment of a fee. In addition, the fee could be waived by the AFP Commissioner with no objective criteria for the exercise of this power and with no internal or external review of the merits of an adverse decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee also considered a letter from the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) in relation to the Australian Telecommunication Corporation Regulations, which in certain circumstances permitted Telecom to release personal information about subscribers. In both cases the Committee accepted the Minister's explanation subject to further documents being provided. The Committee thanks the Ministers for their co-operation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief description of the Committee's scrutiny and its correspondence, for the information of honourable senators and others.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION REGULATIONS AS CONTAINED IN STATUTORY RULES 1989 NO. 150 AND MADE UNDER THE AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION ACT 1989

These Regulations prescribed the circumstances where the duty imposed by the parent Act on Telecom employees not to disclose certain information gained in the course of their employment, does not apply. Most of these circumstances appear reason- able to the Committee, including for example disclosure to a member of the police force, ambulance or fire service as a result of an emergency call, or where there is a serious and imminent threat to life or health. One provision, however, concerned the Committee. This provided for disclosure of ``the affairs or personal particulars'' of a person, including any unlisted phone number or any address, where the person is reasonably likely to be aware that information of that kind is usually disclosed in the circumstances.

The Committee was concerned at the implications for the privacy of individuals affected by this provision. Telecom has a vast data base of information relating to its millions of personal and business subscribers and the Committee was particularly anxious to assure itself that the rights of those subscribers were safeguarded.

The Minister advised the Committee that she agreed that the privacy implications here were extremely important. The Regulations had been drafted to conform to the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act. The Minister then gave examples of the type of situation where the provisions of concern to the Committee might apply, and advised that Telecom had given firm assurances that personal details would not be provided as part of a circulation list. Finally the Minister advised that Telecom's policies and procedures for release of personal information were under review, which included consultation with all interested parties, including the Privacy Commissioner.

The Committee replied that it was grateful for the advice that the Regulations were in accordance with the Privacy Act, although the Committee's Principles are broader than that Act and a mere statement that instruments complied with the Information Privacy Principles is not sufficient, by itself, to meet the concerns of the Committee. The Committee accepted the Minister's advice, however, in the light of the Telecom review, pointing out that it may raise this issue again when the review is completed.
29 August 1989
The Hon. Ros Kelly, M.P.

(c) where the fact or document relates to the affairs or personal particulars (including any unlisted telephone number or any address) of a person and:

Dear Senator Collins
Than you for your letter of 29 August 1989 conveying the concerns which the Committee has with regard to the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Regulations (Statutory Rules 1989 No. 150).

I agree that the privacy considerations involved in regulations such as these are extremely important, particularly when a large organisation such as Telecom, with its significant holdings of personal information, is involved. Accordingly, the Government was concerned that the drafting of the regulations be consistent with the Information Privacy Principles contained in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988. The wording of regulation 3 (c)(i) derives from Principle 11 (1)(a).

Telecom have advised that regulations 3 (c)(i) and (ii) are considered necessary to facilitate publication of routine information such as telephone directories; and to provide personal information to the Minister or bodies such as the Ombudsman or the Australian Telecommunications Authority (AUSTEL) where this is required as part of investigating a complaint. This is clearly consistent with the intention of the Information Privacy Principles in enabling individuals to permit, explicitly or implicitly, the release of information about themselves to third parties.

You expressed concern at the possibility of personal details being sold as part of a circulation list. Telecom have provided firm assurances that it has no intention of selling personal details for circulation list purposes.

Telecom's policies and procedures for release of personal information are currently under review in light of the new legislative regime. This will involve full consultation with all interested parties, including the Privacy Commissioner.
I trust that this clarifies the situation for the Committee.
Yours sincerely

Dear Minister,
I refer to your letter of 20 October 1989 concerning aspects raised by the Committee of the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Regulations, Statutory Rules 1989 No 150.

The Committee noted that you share its concerns about the extremely important privacy considerations in the Regulations, involving as they do the large holdings of personal information by Telecom, and is grateful for this advice. In this context the Committee appreciates your assurance that the Regulations are consistent with the Information Privacy Principles contained in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988.

The Committee points out, however, that the mere fact that an instrument of delegated legislation may conform to the Information Privacy Principles is not, by itself, sufficient to meet the concerns of the Committee. The Principles under which the Committee operates are broader than those associated with the Privacy Act and the Committee may require information additional to an assurance that the requirements of that Act have been met.

In this case you have provided extra advice about the situations where Telecom regards the provisions of r.3 (c) (i) and (ii) as necessary. In particular, the Committee welcomed your advice that Telecom is firm that it does not intend personal details to be provided for circulation list purposes. The Committee's concerns have not been completely satisfied, especially in relation to the circumstances set out in your letter where personal information is supplied to the Minister. Nevertheless, the Committee decided to accept your advice in view of the current review of Telecom's policies and procedures for release of personal information, a review which you advise will involve full consultation with all interested parties, including the Privacy Commissioner.

The Committee would welcome a copy of the review when it is completed, at which time the Committee may raise these matters with you again. The Committee is, of course, concerned with any possible breach of its Principles even in regard to relatively small numbers of people. Telecom, however, has many millions of personal and business subscribers and you would appreciate that the Committee wishes to be as widely informed as possible on this important question.
In the meantime, perhaps you could advise the Committee when it is expected that the review will be completed.
The Committee is grateful for your co-operation.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT), AS CONTAINED IN STATUTORY RULES 1989 NO. 139 AND MADE UNDER THE AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE ACT 1979

These Regulations provide for the Australian Federal Police to introduce statutory fee charging procedures for services to be provided to individual members of the public, to corporations and to prescribed Commonwealth authorities. Some of these services were, at first glance, quite startling. They included express provision for reports on convictions, on a check of fingerprints, on violence or threats of violence, on road accidents involving death and of death reports. There was no indication in the instrument itself or in the Explanatory Statement of any criteria or safeguards to guide the provision of these services.

The Committee, as one of its terms of reference, scrutinises instruments of delegated legislation to ensure they do not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. The right to privacy is one of the most important of these rights. The Committee was extremely concerned at the implications for personal rights of the AFP providing this kind of sensitive information in a fee for service basis.

In addition, the fees prescribed for these service could be waived at the discretion of the AFP Commissioner. The provision of police services for charities were expressly exempt from the payment of fees, but the Commissioner was granted a discretion in all other cases to waive payment where it would cause financial hardship ``or for any other reason'' that the Commissioner considers appropriate.
The Committee was concerned that this discretion did not appear to be subject to an independent external review of the merits, or even to criteria to guide its exercise.

The Committee wrote to the Minister in these terms. The Minister then advised that the Regulations did not confer a statutory right to these services, or to any documents or information in the possession of the AFP. The Commissioner was, in any event, bound by the provisions of the Privacy Act 1988 when exercising a discretion to provide a particular service. The Minister then explained that a right of review of a decision not to waive a fee was not considered appropriate as a successful appeal could affect the allocation of other police resources or reduce the availability of police for core duties.

The Committee considered the Minister's reply and sought further advice and assurances. These related to additional information on the effect of the Privacy Principles under the Privacy Act 1988 and the power of the Minister to require reports from, or give directions to, the Commissioner in respect of the scheme.

The Minister then advised that the AFP had approached the Privacy Commissioner for advice and that a draft AFP Administrative Circular was under consideration by the Privacy Commissioner. The Minister also confirmed that directions could be given to the Commissioner, and report required, in relation to the scheme.
The Committee accepted this advice, but asked that it receive a copy of the AFP Administrative Circular when it was completed.
29 August 1989
The Hon. Lionel Bowen, M.P.
Attorney-General
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Australian Federal Police Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No. 139, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 17 August 1989.

The Committee noted that the Regulations provide for services that may be rendered by the Australian Federal Police at the request of, or under an agreement with, a member of the public, a body corporate or other organisation; or rendered in relation to a prescribed authority of the Commonwealth.

The Committee is concerned at the implications raised for personal rights and freedoms, particularly privacy, by the provisions of these Regulations. The services prescribed in the Schedules, for example, include reporting on convictions; reporting on `check of fingerprints'; reporting on harassment, violence or threats of violence; providing copies of colour and black and white photographs; providing copies of a road accident report involving injury or death; `providing a copy of a medical report'; providing a copy of a death report and providing a copy of an industrial accident report.

The Committee recognises there may be circumstances where members of the public, corporations and Commonwealth authorities have legitimate requirements for such information. As they stand, however, there is no indication in the Regulations themselves or in the Explanatory Statement of any criteria, safeguards or review in the rendering of these services. The Committee assumes that these must exist elsewhere in the legislation. The Committee emphasises that it is not sufficient merely for these safeguards to exist elsewhere; they must be fully explained in the Explanatory Statement. At present, the individual Parliamentarian or member of the public is confronted with the instrument and Explanatory Statement which, on their face, are quite open-ended with respect to the furnishing by the AFP of very sensitive information.

The Committee also noted that regulation 48 gives the Commissioner of Police discretion to waive payment of fees payable under regulations 46 and 47. There appears to be no provision for independent review of the merits of an unfavourable decision by the Commissioner.
Your urgent advice would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely
Bob Collins
Chairman
4 October 1989
Dear Bob

I refer to your letter of 29 August 1989 to the Attorney-General raising the concerns of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in relation to the Australian Federal Police Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No. 139 which amends the Australian Federal Police Regulations.
In essence the Committee's concerns are:
the implications of the amending regulations and the provision by the Australian Federal Police of the prescribed services listed in the Schedule 6 to the Australian Federal Police Regulations; and
the absence of independent review of an unfavourable decision by the Commissioner not to waive payment of fees for services rendered by the Australian Federal Police.

Paragraph 70 (c) of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 (`the Act') provides that the Governor-General may make regulations making provision for and in relation to the police services that may be rendered by the Australian Federal Police at the request of, or under an agreement with, a member of the public or a body corporate or other organisation (other than an authority of the Commonwealth), and the payment and recovery of such fees as are prescribed in relation to rendering those services.

Paragraph 70 (d) provides that the Governor-General may make regulations making provision for and in relation to the payment of such fees as are prescribed in relation to policy services rendered by the Australian Federal Police in relation to a prescribed authority of the Commonwealth, where rendering those services is a function of the Australian Federal Police.

The most significant feature of paragraph 70 (c) of the Act is that it does not allow regulations to be made which confer a right to a police service. The provision of the police service, like all police services, is purely a discretionary matter for the Commissioner (see s.13 of the Act), subject to any written directions by the Minister to the Commissioner with respect to the general policy to be pursued in relation to the performance of the functions of the Australian Federal Police under subsection 13 (2) of the Act.

Thus, Statutory Rules 1989 No. 139 do not, and cannot, provide persons, organisations or corporations with a statutory right of access to documents or information. In addition, the police services listed in Schedule 6 that may be rendered by the Australian Federal Police, are police services which are additional to the core police functions of the Australian Federal Police. As such it is both necessary and appropriate that the provision of these police services rest solely within the discretion of the Commissioner who must take into account the priorities of the Australian Federal Police and its limited police and financial resources.

In relation to the Committee's concerns for personal rights and freedoms, particularly privacy, the Commissioner is, when determining whether to provide a particular police service, bound by the Privacy Act 1988. For example, many of the police services listed in Schedule 6 relate to the provision of information to insurance companies with the consent of the person to whom the information relates or to employers with the consent of the person to whom the search of the police records relates or to solicitors for use in civil proceedings.

The reason why the Explanatory Statement did not make reference to the limitations on the provision of personal information is that Statutory Rules 1989 No. 139 does not create a right to information where such a right does not already exist. The amending regulations merely provide for the payment where a person can be provided with the information within the existing legislative framework.

I can assure you that where the Commissioner is required to consider whether to exercise his discretion to render a particular service listed in Schedule 6, where the request concerns access to documents or information, he is bound by the Information Privacy Principles (and in particular Principle 11) contained in the Privacy Act 1988.

With regard to the Committee's concerns about the absence of provision for independent review of the merits of an unfavourable decision by the Commissioner in relation to the waiver of fees payable under regulations 46 and 47, it will have been noted that subregulation 48 (2) provides that a fee is not payable under regulation 46 or 47 where it relates to an activity conducted for a charitable purpose.

Therefore, where a pop concert with all proceeds to charity is held at Bruce Stadium and the Commissioner agrees to supply members of the Australian Federal Police for security within the Stadium, no fee is payable.
Subregulation 48 (1) gives the Commissioner the power to waive payment of a fee payable under regulation 46 or 47 where:
(a) payment of the fee would cause financial hardship; or
(b) for any other reason, the Commissioner considers it appropriate to waive the fee.

There is no provision for independent review of the merits of the unfavourable decision by the Commissioner because it is not considered appropriate to place limitations on the Commissioner's sole responsibility to administer and control the Australian Federal Police set out in section 13 of the Act. On the merits review is therefore not appropriate because the Commissioner has a discretion as to whether or not the Australian Federal Police will provide the police service, as is the case with all police services. For example, the Commissioner may only be able to provide police resources to a major sporting event or concert if the fee is to be paid. A subsequent successful appeal could mean that the service would not be provided or alternatively that police resources would not be available for core police duties such as patrolling the suburbs of Canberra at night.

I do not believe it is either proper or appropriate that the Commissioner's ability to determine how police resources are allocated (taking into account all the circumstances of the Australian Federal Police and the person, body corporate, other organisation or Commonwealth authority) should be circumscribed by an independent review process in relation to what are, in any case, additional police functions for the Australian Federal Police which are performed as a community service.

It should also be mentioned that where the request relates to information or documents the requested information may be available under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 where independent review of the merits to decisions in relation to release and fees is available. It will be noted that the FOI Act creates rights. This is not the case in relation to the police services to which regulations 46, 47 and 48 apply.
Yours sincerely
(Michael Tate)
Senator B. Collins
Chairman
Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600

Dear Bob
I refer to your letter of 5 October 1989 seeking my further advice and assurances on aspects of the Australian Federal Police Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No. 139.

The Committee has sought further details of instances where information may be sought from the Australian Federal Police (`AFP') and released by the AFP without the consent of the individual concerned being previously obtained. In these circumstances you were also concerned to know the effect of the Privacy Act 1988 and Privacy Principles, including Principle 11.

I am advised that the AFP has released information in some instances without having first obtained the consent of the information provider. Following the introduction of the Privacy Act, the AFP approached the Privacy Commissioner for advice as to how such matters should be handled henceforth. It is intended that future releases should be the subject of an AFP Administrative Circular-which is binding on all members and staff members of the AFP. I am advised that the terms of a draft circular are at present under consideration by the Privacy Commissioner.

The Committee has also sought my confirmation that the Minister has power to issue written directions to the AFP Commissioner under subsection 13 (2) of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 (`the Act') and that the Minister is able to require the Commissioner of the AFP to furnish a report under subsection 13 (6) of the Act in respect of a decision not to waive fees applicable under the Regulations.

To take the latter issue first, I confirm that subsection 13 (6) of the Act gives the Minister a clear power to require the AFP Commissioner to furnish to the Minister reports relating to the administration of the fee for police services regime contemplated by these regulations. Furthermore, I can confirm for the benefit of the Committee that the Minister has power under section 13 (2) of the Act to give the AFP Commissioner written directions in relation to the fee for police services regime, in so far as such written directions would relate to the general policy to be pursued by the AFP in relation to the performance of its functions. The Minister's power in these circumstances would not extend to giving written directions in relation to individual cases.
Yours sincerely
(Michael Tate)

Dear Minister,

I refer to your letter of 23 October 1989 concerning aspects raised by the Committee of the Australian Federal Police Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1989 No. 139. The Committee considered your reply at its Meeting of 26 October 1989.

The Committee noted that future releases of information would be the subject of an AFP Administrative Circular which will be binding on all members and staff members of the AFP and, in particular, that the terms of a draft circular are at present under consideration by the Privacy Commissioner. The Committee is grateful for your advice on this aspect and believes that the involvement of the Privacy Commissioner is a helpful development in meeting the concerns of the Committee about the treatment by the AFP of this very sensitive matter. It would be appreciated if you could send a copy of the circular to the Committee when its terms are finalised.

The Committee also considered your advice concerning the power of the Minister to require information from, and to give directions to, the AFP Commissioner, in respect of this matter. The Committee particularly noted your advice that the Minister had a clear power to require reports from the Commissioner on the administration of the fees provided for in the Regulations and to give to the Commissioner written directions on the general policy to be pursued by the AFP in relation to the fees for police services. The Committee believes that the existence of such powers, to be exercised by a Minister who is subject to personal scrutiny in the Parliament, also helps to meet the concerns of the Committee.

The Committee is grateful for your advice, which meets its concerns. By way of observation, however, the Committee points out that the Regulations were made on 28 June 1989 and were gazetted on 30 June 1989. The AFP Administrative Circular, on the other hand, is apparently not yet complete at the end of October 1989, some four months later. In the meantime the general scheme of operation as provided for in the Regulations has been commented on in the popular press. The Committee believes that when schemes of this nature are introduced, involving as they do the discretionary provision of sensitive information or services to the general public, for fees which may be waived at the discretionary decision, not limited by objective criteria or subject to internal or external review, of a public official, that administrative documents such as AFP Circulars should be prepared before the introduction of the scheme.
The Committee appreciates your co-operation in this matter.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1989
This Bill introduces measures to give effect to some of the Treasurer's 1989-90 Budget announcements.

The income tax law will be amended to require major employers to remit pay-as-you-earn tax deductions, withheld from the salary or wages of their employees, to the Commissioner of Taxation on a twice-monthly basis.
Other Budget announcements to be given effect will vary the operation of the quarterly provisional tax system and provide for the method of calculating 1989-90 provisional tax.
Mr Chairman, I will now outline in more detail these measures.
Twice-monthly Remittance of Tax Instalment Deductions

The Bill will require some employers registered under the group employer scheme to pay to the Commissioner of Taxation on a twice-monthly basis, the PAYE tax instalment deductions they make from the salary or wages of their employees on or after 1 December 1989.
Employers affected by this change will be those who deducted more than $5 million in tax instalments in the financial year ended 30 June 1989, or who do so in a later financial year.
Employers who are members of a wholly-owned company group may also be required to remit their tax instalment deductions to the Commissioner on a twice-monthly basis.
This rule will apply where the total amount of the deductions made by all the employers in the company group during the financial year ended 30 June 1989, or in a later year, exceed $5 million.
Employers who are subject to the new rules will be required to pay all deductions made in the first 14 days of a month by the twenty-first day of that month.
Deductions made in the balance of the month are to be paid over by no later than the seventh day of the next month.

Once employers start to remit tax instalment deductions on a twice-monthly basis they must continue to do so unless the Commissioner determines otherwise because of a significant change in their circumstances.

This measure is the first step towards revised PAYE remittance arrangements that would require larger employers to remit twice-monthly but with less frequent remittances than at present by smaller employers, which could obviate the need for the tax stamps system.
The amendment will produce a one-off revenue gain of $550 million in 1989-90.
Additionally, outlays on public debt interest will reduce by $20 million in 1989-90 and $70 million in subsequent years.
Quarterly Provisional Tax
The Bill will give effect to two Budget proposals adjusting the operation of the quarterly instalment system of paying provisional tax.
The threshold for general exemption from the instalment system will be increased from $5,000 to $8,000.
As a consequence, a taxpayer whose provisional tax payable in a year of income is $8,000 or less will not be required to pay instalments of provisional tax in the following year.
This change will apply to provisional tax payable in the current and subsequent income years.

Some 130,000 of the existing 320,000 instalment payers will now be required to pay provisional tax only on an annual basis. Of this large number who will benefit from the change, some 45,000 are over 60 years of age.
This proposal is estimated to increase outlays on public debt interest by $20 million in 1989-90 and $70 million in subsequent years.
The Bill will also give effect to another proposal to preclude a too early offset of provisional tax credit in a year of income against provisional tax charged for the succeeding year.
Credit arises where income tax assessed as payable for an income year is less than the credit for provisional tax previously paid for that year.

Under the change, any excess provisional tax credit will no longer be offset against a quarterly instalment of provisional tax for the succeeding year which has been notified but is not yet due for payment.
This change will apply from the date of Royal Assent to the Bill.
Provisional Tax for 1989-90
Provisional tax is that part of the pay-as-you-earn system designed to collect tax on non salary or wage income within the year in which the income is derived.
It follows that the amount of provisional tax charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year.

This Bill provides for 1989-90 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1988-89 taxable income increased by 10 per cent, and by applying the 1989-90 rates of tax, Medicare levy and the increased low income thresholds for Medicare levy that are to apply in that year.
Subject to the exceptions I will announce, rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in 1988-89 assessments.
Any rebate of tax allowed on franked dividends will be adjusted, before being increased by 10 per cent, to account for the reduction in the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent.
In addition, credits for foreign tax paid will be uplifted by 10 per cent.

Concessional rebates claimed in 1988-89 for a dependent spouse, daughter-housekeeper, invalid relative, parent or parent-in-law or for a housekeeper and the sole parent rebate will be adjusted to reflect the new higher 1989-90 levels.

Changes will also be made to some claims for zone rebates and the rebates for Defence Force members serving overseas or civilians serving with the United Nations. The 1989-90 provisional tax will be calculated after increasing any such rebate by 20 per cent of the adjustment made to the taxpayer's 1988-89 concessional rebate claim.

Taxpayers who estimate that their taxable income for 1988-89 will increase by less than 10 per cent, or who consider that their rebates or credits will be at a higher level in 1989-90, will continue to have the right to `self assess' and have the provisional tax for 1989-90 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates.

The reduction in the uplift factor from the 12 per cent that was applied in calculating 1988-90 provisional tax to 10 per cent for 1989-90 provisional tax is estimated to cost $160 million in 1989-90.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

This Bill will amend the Income Tax Act 1986 to formally impose the rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for the 1989-90 financial year and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, for the 1990-91 financial year.
It will also impose for the same period the rates of tax payable by companies, registered organisations and unit trusts that are treated as companies.
In addition, it will impose the rates of tax on superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts.
The rates to be imposed by the measures in this Bill are those declared in the Income Tax Rates Act 1986.
New personal rates of tax apply for 1989-90 following the changes announced in the April 1989 Economic Statement.
A five step tax scale applies.

At the lower end of the scale for resident taxpayers, no tax is payable on taxable incomes up to $5,100. On taxable incomes in the range $5,101 to $17,650 the rate is 21 per cent. In the range $17,651 to $20,600 the rate is 29 per cent.

For income in the range $20,601 to $35,000 the rate is 39 per cent and a rate of 47 per cent applies for income in the range $35,000 to $50,000. Income over $50,000 is taxed at a composite rate of 48 per cent, reflecting the reduction in the top rate of personal tax from 49 per cent to 47 per cent from 1 January 1990.

These general rates also apply to non-residents who receive Australian social security and repatriation pensions that are taxable in Australia, or who were residents at any time during the income year.
For other non-resident taxpayers, the rate of 29 per cent applies to incomes up to $20,600 and the higher general rates apply to incomes above that level.
For 1989-90 the rate for all unearned income of resident minors, subject to shading-in arrangements for such income just over $416, is 48 per cent.
That rate also applies to trustees assessed under section 99a of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and on other categories of income that are subject to anti-avoidance provisions of that Act.
The general company tax rate payable in respect of 1988-89 income, which applies also for unit trusts that are treated as companies, is 39 per cent.
Specified tax rates apply in respect of the various components of taxable income of life assurance companies and registered organisations.

For any component of 1988-89 income referable to policies held by complying funds or in respect of rollover annuities the rate is 15 per cent. A rate of 49 per cent applies for any component referable to policies held by non-complying funds.

The rate for the component of income for 1988-89 referable to other life assurance and accident and disability insurance is 39 per cent where the insurer is a life assurance office, and 30 per cent where the insurer is a registered organization.
Finally, the rate of tax generally applying for complying superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts is 15 per cent.
The provisions of the Bill are explained in detail in the Explanatory Memorandum that accompanied the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989 I have just introduced.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989
The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989 will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to impose the basic rate of Medicare levy for 1989-90 and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, for 1990-91.
The basic rate of the levy will remain at 1.25 per cent of taxable income, the level that has applied since 1 December 1986.
The Bill also contains increases in the income threshold levels below which people with low incomes will not be called on to pay any levy.
For 1989-90, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $10,330 and married couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $17,400 will not be required to pay the levy.
The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will continue to be increased by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student.
For example, a married couple with three dependent children will pay no levy until their combined taxable incomes exceed $23,700.
The estimated cost of the increased low income thresholds is $10 million in 1989-90 and $35 million in 1990-91.
The new low income thresholds will be reflected in provisional tax raised for 1989-90, and in tax instalment schedules from 1 January 1990.
Mr Chairman, the Explanatory Memorandum on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989 about which I have just spoken contains an explanation of the provisions of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.

The speeches read as follows-
GOAT FIBRE LEVY BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce new legislation to enable a levy to be collected on the sale of goat fibre. Funds from this levy are to be directed specifically into research for the betterment of the goat fibre industry.

Associated with this Bill is the Goat Fibre Levy Collection Bill 1989 which allows the levy moneys to be collected and provides for their forwarding to the Australian Special Rural Research Fund. The funds will form a sub-account within the Australian Special Rural Research Fund which is dedicated to goat fibre research. The participation within the Australian Special Rural Research Fund ensures a Commonwealth contribution to goat fibre research while avoiding the expense of a separate statutory authority which would not be justified for an industry of this size.

The goat fibre industry comprises mohair, cashmere and, more recently, cashgora sectors. These industries have made an increasing contribution to Australian export earnings, and export earnings are expected to approach $10 million this year. In addition, there are the associated products of meat and hides from goat slaughter and the export of live goats.

These goat industries have been expanding and frequently complement the traditional pastoral industries of sheep and cattle production as they use resources which would not otherwise be fully utilised. This is particularly the case with some weeds such as thistles and blackberries which could require chemical control if goats were not used. A small expanding industry such as goat fibre production offers many promising opportunities for research in the area of animal production, fibre harvesting, marketing, economics and processing. However, the industry has limited capacity to organise and fund the required research. Despite this, the goat industry has made considerable effort to support research projects. This has been undertaken by a number of independent voluntary funds and some Commonwealth funds from the Australian Special Rural Research Fund. While the industry has identified research priorities, programs have rested on a precarious funding base with limited capacity to expand to meet the needs of an emerging industry.

A more substantive, ongoing and co-ordinated research program is required if the needs of this industry are to be met. This is particularly the case as this industry is export oriented and so must meet the vagaries of international markets and compete with producers in a range of countries, some with a long history of fibre production and others with newly emerging industries.

In December 1988 the National Goat Fibre Workshop was convened. This workshop comprised representatives of the various goat fibre industry groups who were supported by brokers, buyers, the fibre testing sector and research groups. At this workshop, the grower organisations recognised the benefits of a co-ordinated research program encompassing all goat fibre organisations.

The degree of support for such a unified research effort was reflected in the subsequent request received from the four goat industry grower organisations. They requested that the Commonwealth enact legislation to collect a statutory levy of 1.5% on the gross value of sales of goat fibre. This rate of expenditure on research will be amongst the highest of any Australian agricultural industry. In addition, the industry contribution will be substantially greater than the Commonwealth's maximum contribution of 0.5% of the gross value of production in the industry.

The willingness of the various sectors of this industry to work together and make a significant contribution to sponsoring change and improvement is reflected in the fact that they have suggested that an appropriate maximum rate for this research levy should be 5% of the value of fibre sales.

The legislation provides for the initial levy rate of 1.5% and the maximum rate of 5% as requested by the industry. Provision is also made for any recommendations from the goat industry organisations to be taken into account prior to altering the operative rate of the levy.

Initiating the levy on 1 January 1990 will allow the accumulation of some funds before the beginning of the 1990-91 financial year. This should allow research objectives to be assessed and individual research projects to be funded from the commencement of the 1990-91 financial year.

The goat fibre industry will benefit from an industry wide research program which is administered by a professional research administration organisation, namely the Australian Special Rural Research Council which was established by the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. In addition the industry will have the benefit of a guaranteed Commonwealth contribution to the research effort. Initially the industry levy is expected to raise around $150,000 with an additional Commonwealth contribution of around $50,000. The Special Research Council will, therefore, be able to implement a goat fibre research program of around $200,000 annually.

I believe this industry desires to make a substantial commitment to research and that the potential benefits for both the industry and Australia would justify the research effort. Because of this I believe the Commonwealth should provide the supportive mechanism as well as a financial commitment to this research.
Honourable Senators, I commend the Bill to the House and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.
GOAT FIBRE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1989
The purpose of this Bill is to provide the machinery necessary for collecting the levy imposed by the Goat Fibre Levy Bill 1989.
This Bill should be read as one with the Goat Fibre Levy Bill 1989 and is to also come into operation on 1 January 1990 the same day that the Levy Bill becomes operative.
The Bill specifies the liability of purchasers and receivers under the scheme, outlines penalties for non-compliance and provides appropriate powers of enforcement.
There are no financial implications other than those covered in the Second Reading Speech for the Goat Fibre Levy Bill 1989.
Honourable Senators, I commend the Bill to the House and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.

We believe that that determination should be struck down and, therefore, we will be insisting on the Senate amendment.

I want to take two minutes to refer to a constitutional question-namely, whether this Bill in any sense falls within the ambit of potential double dissolution legislation. I want to make it clear that it is our view that at this stage this Bill does not. Because of the change of date which has been made by the House of Representatives, we are now dealing with the Bill, as it were, on the first occasion for the purposes of section 57 of the Constitution, rather than dealing with the Bill on the second occasion. Before this Bill starts to come within the ambit of being considered double dissolution legislation, the statutory three-month waiting period would have to apply and it would have to be reintroduced into the Senate for debate and dealt with in a particular fashion. In fact, it would have to be reintroduced in precisely the same form as it is currently being dealt with today-namely, with a 1 January 1990 commencement date even if the matter were dealt with after 1 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was raised by Senator Cook yesterday.
