The precedent for this is that the sales tax Bills, which were passed by the House of Representatives for a second time in February 1982 and which were the basis for the double dissolution of 1983, still contained the commencement date of 1 January 1982. In the debate in the House of Representatives the responsible Minister stated that constitutional considerations required that the date not be altered. We accept that.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Macklin said by way of interjection, the double dissolution question was raised yesterday by the distinguished and electorally learned Senator Cook. I simply want to place on record our understanding that because the House of Representatives has made an amendment to this Bill, it is a different Bill from the one which we last dealt with on, I think, 27 September. As a result, this constitutes the first approach to a Bill for the purposes of the operation of section 57 of the Constitution. It will be in the hands of the Government to determine within the three-month and six-month parameters which are set out in the Constitution how it wishes to proceed.

I have simply taken the opportunity to place on record what we will do in relation to the two questions which will be put to the Committee. I have put our view in relation to the question of constitutional requirements for the purposes of section 57 of the Constitution. I believe that in all other respects the views of the Opposition have been well canvassed in this matter and I have nothing further to add to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to explain the absence of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is in charge of this piece of legislation. Again, we were not given any advance notice. The advance notice that I was given was by the Australian Democrats Whip who said, `Look, we are moving this, but we will get done'. It must have been a very eloquent speech by Senator Coulter that swung the numbers. Senator Cook is out doing a ministerial launch of some sort at the moment.
—Land care, I think.

—Yes, land care. The question of a double dissolution may or may not have been canvassed yesterday. I do not think anyone is serious about having a double dissolution and giving the Democrats that big a free kick. I think they are travelling all right, but I would like them at least to be tested in the big race rather than just being given it on a platter. As well as that, I do not know that this would necessarily be the sort of issue to go to a double dissolution on.
—The issue is actually important, is it?

—In terms of the timing. When a government has been in office for two years and four months it does not start talking about a double dissolution that far in. The cut-off point-I think Senator Puplick knows it better than I-is either March or May.
—It is 17 May.
—Yes, 17 May. I do not really think that is a realistic proposition. I am sure that we have some other defeated legislation we could roll in as a better trigger mechanism, if we so desired.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin asked a couple of specific questions. I thought that most of those matters were still under negotiation. One has to get to base one before one can determine the sorts of questions that Senator Macklin is raising. I do not think that the negotiations have got to base one. Many views have been put forward on the negotiation. Unfortunately, the grounds have changed several times, not the least of which when members of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia came to see the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others. Certain preconditions were laid down for negotiations and the Guild broke them within a few minutes. That makes it very hard to negotiate. I understand that negotiations are still continuing. The matters that Senator Macklin has raised are always difficult; good will is always difficult. But we have the same problem with taxi plates in the Australian Capital Territory. Do we say that we will not issue any more and therefore increase the value of those plates? At the moment they are up to $250,000. What is the monopoly on goodwill? I do not know. All these questions are difficult, as Senator Macklin has indicated, when we want to rationalise an industry. But hard things have to be done when we want to rationalise an industry. We just cannot continue to have inefficient industries in this country. Some sacrifices have to be made. Hopefully, though, those sacrifices should always be made evenly and should not fall on just one specific section. That is the guts of Senator Macklin's question. I cannot answer it because I still think it is a negotiable matter in the context of discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Senate does not insist on amendment No. 1, and agrees to the amendments made in place thereof.
—The question now is that the Senate does not insist on amendment No. 2.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988. I find this quite amazing because the Hawke Labor Government has shown a rather strange reluctance to submit this Bill to any systematic debate. It was introduced last year, shelved and then debated in a rather piecemeal and disjointed fashion in the previous session of the Senate. Now we suddenly see it re-emerge today. Of course, we would have seen it re-emerge yesterday if the Government had had its way in trying to put off debate on the National Health Amendment Bill because of its reluctance to debate the pharmacy issue. We can only speculate as to whether the delay in debating this Bill is some indication of the Government's lack of concern for the electoral system or whether, in rather characteristic fashion, this Government has something to hide or wants to add something to its last minute advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill covers many issues related to changing the way in which people can vote and the entitlement of those who can vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —They got all the crooks to vote for them.

—I will come to that point soon because it is of great concern to the Opposition that prisoners will be given the vote. What we have really seen from this Government over a period is a range of measures to ensure its electoral success at the polls. It has the hide to rabbit on about gerrymanders and the like, yet in this Bill we find some rather amazing changes. Examples of what we have seen from Government members in just very recent times include a Minister, Ros Kelly, using a statutory authority, Telecom Australia, to push herself and the Government. There have been attempted increases in the postal allowance for members of the House of Representatives, quite clearly overturning a decision of the Remuneration Tribunal despite its being an independent remuneration tribunal. But the Government will not overturn an independent remuneration tribunal's decision on pharmacists' income. Nonetheless, that was another ploy to try to increase its electoral advantage. We have seen the ever-increasing use of taxpayers' money to fund an unashamedly biased National Media Liaison Service. We have had the proposal to abolish paid party advertising in the electronic media. The Government wants all donations to be declared because it feels that that is one way to intimidate many of the conservative donors. Of course, it will not intimidate the unions. The list goes on.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill also seeks to provide for the printing and distribution of electoral rolls to senators, members and political parties no later than the end of the second year of each parliament. One could probably say, `About time'. I threw my last lot of electoral rolls out the other day. They were dated 1984 and are now about as useful as an ashtray on a motorbike. So it is about time that the printing of such rolls was brought up to date. It has been a thing of the past since this Government came to office and as a result we have witnessed multiple voting and rorting generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?
—The Minister knows where. He knows where there has been multiple voting.
—Name one spot.

—The Minister knows full well. He does not need to play innocent with me. Another restriction the Government is attempting to place on candidates for election is in the entering of hospitals, special hospitals, nursing homes and similar institutions after the writs for an election have been issued. Why should people in institutions be prevented from meeting candidates and learning what they have to offer just because they are in those institutions? Maybe the Government does not want individuals to make value judgments prior to an election but prefers them to accept everything it says as gospel and put out through the biased National Media Liaison Service. How dare any government deny people access to information simply because they are in hospital or similar institutions? We will therefore be seeking in the committee stage to omit this clause.

SPEECH.PARA: A further amendment was moved by my colleague Senator Puplick in the debate that took place on this matter some months ago which dealt with the process of redistribution, and specifically where a party obtains a majority of votes on a two party preferred basis but actually loses seats. If one needs further examples of how hypocritical this Labor Government is when it bleats on about the gerrymanders and the States one has only to look to Government members. They are masters of it. At the last Federal election the coalition parties actually obtained more votes than the Labor Party. However, the coalition lost seats while the Labor Party gained seats.

An even more recent example can be found in my own State of Western Australia. In February this year the Liberal and National parties actually obtained 4.4 per cent more votes that the Labor Party on a two party preferred vote. When the Liberal and National parties actually achieved that 4.4 per cent higher number of votes than the Labor Party one would have naturally expected them to have won, but, no, the Labor Party won more seats yet again. The question should also be asked as to who introduced the gerrymander in Queensland. For those who may not know, it was the Australian Labor Party. For these very reasons we are moving an amendment to attempt to ensure that the Commonwealth has legislation to ensure that any party that wins more than 50 per cent of the votes achieves more than 50 per cent of the seats.

I also wish to address the issue raised in clause 35 of the Bill, which provides for a new section 96a to be placed in the Electoral Act, allowing all prisoners other than those convicted of treason to retain their enrolment or to enrol to vote in Federal elections. The coalition opposes this out of hand. It is the second time that the Government is changing the procedures for prisoners to vote. It broadened the criteria once before. Now it is saying that anyone other than those who have been charged with and convicted of treason will be entitled to vote. I could be wrong, but I do not recall anyone in this country actually being imprisoned for treason. It is really only a bit of tokenism. The Labor Party has already broadened the entitlement since coming to office. It is now just treating prisoners as though they have committed no crime against society at all and should be entitled to all the privileges of law abiding citizens. The Opposition simply does not subscribe to that belief. It could well be argued that it is anomalous for people to retain their right to vote when members of parliament are disqualified if they are convicted of an offence with a penalty of more than 12 months imprisonment.

One may well ask why people can vote for a parliamentary representative and yet cannot be a member of parliament. I submit that to propose such a legislative change displays a real contempt for the Parliament and, perhaps more so, a contempt for the victims of the crimes. While I am in favour of rehabilitation of criminals I do not believe that a psychopathic killer should have equal rights with responsible and law abiding citizens. I cannot understand why this Government believes he should. When people choose to commit a crime they choose not to participate in the end in valuable parts of society. Why should they then have extended to them by this Government all the rights that everybody else has?

Is the Government telling the victims of criminals that these evildoers have as much right to participate in the democratic process as the victims have? Yes, it is. I do not believe that the victims of criminals want that sort of right extended to criminals. It is wrong in principle to allow people to choose the government of our society when they have shown, by their own actions, that they are, for a time at least, unfit to participate in society. There is much concern in the community today that the penalties imposed in the courts are too light, that people get out of prison too soon and that the parole system is a joke, yet this Government is saying, `Well, it does not really matter about any of those things because we are going to give them all the rights and entitlements of an ordinary member of society anyway'.

The authorities in Western Australia are all too aware that their prisons contain a couple who murdered four women in very depraved and sadistic circumstances. They contain several other men who committed murder for sexual gratification, and they contain a man who callously shot two young people because the colour of their skin was different from his. Should those prisoners be entitled to choose a government? I hardly think so, but obviously the Government thinks otherwise.

The public outrage when this measure was first introduced-it goes back to last year-was quite evident, and maybe that is part of the reason why the Government has sought to dilly-dally about bringing it back into the Parliament. There is an awareness out there that the Government has broadened the entitlement already.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you move an amendment on it if you feel so strongly about it?

—We intend to. This is an attitude that denies that our system of justice exists to punish and deter. I do not think that this Parliament should be condoning such an action. As I say, there will be a very detailed debate in the committee stage on a whole range of issues, of changes that are sought to be made in this Bill. I hope that the Senate will give the matter due consideration, particularly in the context of what is right and proper in the best interests of all Australians, and be somewhat more concerned about the welfare of the law abiding citizens in Australia rather than just a selected few.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make only a few remarks in this debate. In particular, I want to express concern about the manner in which the present electoral arrangements allow organisations which are in fact financially funded by this Government to advertise at election time without revealing at any stage, as I understand it, the extent to which those organisations are themselves receiving funds from the Federal Labor Government. This is not something new and I acknowledge that, but it is of major concern, particularly when those organisations are being used as a vehicle for the washing, through community groups, of electoral contributions which are in fact a clear benefit to a particular party, such a contribution in one instance having gone directly to the Australian Labor Party's electoral campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for my concern emerge from what happened before the 1987 election. I refer the Senate to the Australian newspaper, which in 1987 reported that on the last day of Federal Parliament before the 1987 election the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, made an announcement which Australian conservationists were waiting to hear. He announced that he would seek World Heritage listing for most of north Queensland's rainforests. The Australian reported that Mr Hawke did not make this important announcement in Parliament but from the Lodge and in the presence of most of Australia's influential environmental lobbyists. The report said:

Two most influential groups, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society . . . have apparently convinced government they can influence a sizable percentage of the electorate, particularly in targeted marginal seats . . . The Labor Party can now rely on the support of Australia's leading conservation groups in its election campaign.

During that election campaign there was no requirement and, as I understand it, there has been no requirement subsequently for those bodies to reveal the extent to which they have been funded by the Federal Government. I wonder to what extent taxpayers' money went through those organisations and was spent on advertisements, public relations or press releases attacking the coalition parties. It seems to me that there is a clear moral requirement that, where bodies funded by this Government support the Government and attack the Opposition, their vested interest in that matter should be revealed. I note that subsequently in the article to which I was referring the Australian reported:
Australia's main conservation organizations are planning their largest political campaigns-including radio, television and press advertisements to tell voters in marginal seats not to vote Liberal.

By the way, as I mentioned, no press report at that time nor any subsequent report mentioned that both the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society are patronised by the Government through taxpayers' funding and in other important ways. It did not mention-and I mention it in passing-that many genuine conservationists, many people genuinely concerned with the environment, do not support either of these organisations. Again I say in passing that I find it moderately offensive that so many people list statements by these organisations as representing all the environmentalists or all conservationists when in fact that is patently not so. But that is just by the way.

It strikes me as remarkable that those bodies which had received substantial Government funding were looked on and continue to be looked on favourably by this Government after their political involvement in the 1987 election whereas, as we all remember, the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre was brought down to earth with something of a bang by the Federal Government's Department of Aboriginal Affairs when it announced that it intended to campaign against the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Australian Labor Party in the 1987 election. The head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs immediately told the Secretary of the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre that if he:
. . . wanted to pursue the campaign against Mr Holding, he could do so without the benefit of federal funding, as from the next day.

There is an interesting double standard involved here. One can keep getting Federal funding provided one uses some of it in election campaigning against the Liberal Party within the framework of the electoral laws but if one wants to use any of one's Federal funding to campaign against the Labor Party one will lose that funding immediately. So there is a clear democratic, open-handed, responsible approach-the approach being that taxpayers' money can be used by these bodies--

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it used?

—I will come to that. The approach is that that money can be used in both direct advertising and substantial publicity campaigning, at some cost. Printing brochures, at some cost, is okay-it is totally acceptable and morally defensible-but if a similar organisation uses similar funds to oppose the Labor Party that is a disgrace and will be stopped forthwith. This Government surely has a high moral position-high in the sense that it stinks to high heaven. At the time I was intrigued by the fact that the Government's threat to the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre, which threatened to oppose Mr Holding, seemed much more vigorous and enthusiastic than its response to the same organisation when Mr Mansell indicated he had some links with Libya, but that is a matter for the Government's own moral position.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Federal Government has been using millions of dollars of taxpayers' money to support community groups, many of which have a direct and clear political involvement yet are not required by the electoral laws to reveal the extent to which they are heavily influenced-that is the polite expression-by this Labor Government, although some are its puppets. The Government creates mechanisms like the Consumers Health Forum-which it heavily supports-which, as we have discussed at some length in this chamber, are certainly not representative of the people at large and appear to be taking very strong political positions. These Government-funded bodies which get involved in political activity cover a very wide range. They have a clearly disproportionate impact, because of their capacity to influence the Government and, by using taxpayers' money, to participate at election time.
A book was written last year-I cannot remember the author-which dealt at some length with this general issue. It stated:

Officially-patronised community groups tend to become agencies of government, or, at times, tools of factions within the government party. Patronage helps harness these groups to the government's electoral wagon, at taxpayers' expense. Their campaigns to ``raise public consciousness'', are often attempts to pre-market unpopular party or factional policies, or to make radical changes to be introduced by government appear merely as responses to popular demand. Community group campaigns can be used by party factions to pressure resisting government ministers into supporting certain policies.

Once organisations become addicted to the government-taxpayer dollar, they can generally be quickly brought into line. Tightening, or even threatening to tighten, the strings on the public purse is generally sufficient. Whether co-incidentally or not, recent changes in the senior officials of several Leading ``community'' peak councils (The Australian Conservation Foundation, the Australian Council of Social Service, and the Australian Federation of Consumer Unions) have followed deterioration in their relationships with Government or particular Ministers.

Five of the organisations taking a leading part in Government-sponsored community participation which appear to bob their heads up at election times are the Australian Consumers Association-and Senator Short has dealt at great length with its involvement, along with that of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, which is approximately 90 per cent funded by the Federal Government-the Australian Council of Social Service Health Issues Centre and the Australian Conservation Foundation. The latter manages to be something of a post-box for tax deductable contributions to various other bodies, many of which appear to take positions at political times.

One of the problems that concern me is that many of these groups are, or have been, totally genuine and made up of decent people who have a commitment to important issues like conservation. One of the real things that bother me is that in taking these bodies over for political and, one often thinks, electoral purposes this Government patronage has the effect of bureaucratising and politicising these genuine groups in a way that damages their capacity to be effective. The point has been made that organisations which begin well, like Community Aid Abroad, the Australian Consumers Association and the Australian Conservation Foundation, have at times-I do not say at all times-been taken over or severely influenced by groups which appear to be heavily political and have a special access to and relationship with this Government which enables them to play strong, political roles at election times without disclosure of their links. That is the key point-the public disclosure of their links with government funding. I have a general objection to any such body which depends on government funding taking a hidden role-hidden, in the sense that its funding is hidden-in electoral matters. It is totally improper that citizens of Australia should be taxed to fund a political organisation posing as a community group. Some people feel it is bad enough that they have to fund political parties' election campaigns anyway, but to fund such groups in a hidden way is even more dreadful.

Let us not pretend there are no political links. For example, a few years ago the director of the Wilderness Society was paid $10,000 a year by the Federal Government as a consultant. Until recently, for 18 months he was the assistant private secretary to Mr Cohen, on a salary of more than $50,000 a year. I do not say that that necessarily means there is a disgraceful link between that body and the Government, but it underlines the fact that the Government seems to have the capacity to influence or control bodies by granting them money. At election times, these bodies put out press releases or advertise in a way that is clearly, deliberately and determinedly damaging to the Liberal and National parties. They can do this without being obliged by any element of the electoral law to reveal the extent of that funding.

This brings me to the apparent washing at the last election of a donation-I think Senator Puplick has raised this in this chamber-of $70,000 by Richard Farmer and Associates to the Labor Party through the Wilderness Society. The Wilderness Society is one of those bodies which appear to the coalition to be fairly politically oriented in approach at election times. I did not see at the last election any suggestion that the Wilderness Society had been involved in such a matter. I think it was raised in 1988 in The Eye magazine which reprinted a copy of a receipt dated 5 November 1987 from Richard Farmer and Associates Pty Ltd for a `donation with thanks'. I do not know where Richard Farmer and Associates got the $70,000. I was under the impression that the company had not been trading very successfully at that time. An extract from The Eye magazine states:

According to copies of the correspondence available to The Eye the secretary of The Wilderness Society, Grant Dixon, wrote to Richard Farmer on November 26 last year expressing `our sincere thanks for your recent generous donation. It has been most useful in terms of expenses incurred earlier in the year.' He attached a receipt for $70,000.

Dixon did not spell out what expenses had been incurred earlier in the year but The Wilderness Society gained a lot of publicity for its support for Labor candidates in the July 1987 Federal election and later in the 1988 New South Wales State election.

Senator Robert Ray regrettably has left the chamber. He asked me whether I could outline what support had been given. I think Senator Robert Ray must have been either blind or overseas or doing something else at the time had he not been able to recognise the volume of very public and expensive support for Labor candidates in both the Federal election and the subsequent State election. The article continues:

The donation is all the more generous in the light of the losses of well over $1 million that Richard Farmer and Associates chalked up over the last three years for which reports have been lodged with corporate authorities in Canberra.
I ask: Where did the $70,000 come from? The article continues:
The magnitude of the losses may well prompt the Liberal party to ask whether Richard Farmer was really passing on the $70,000 from another source rather than drawing on his own company's funds.

I wonder who that other source was, particularly when we recognise that Richard Farmer was one of the key advisers to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on electoral matters and on how to run his 1987 election campaign. Here we have, magically, Richard Farmer, a key element in the 1987 election campaign, paying $70,000 out of his company, which had just lost $1m, to the Wilderness Society, which coincidentally happened to run an anti-Liberal-anti-National Party campaign and a pro-Labor campaign in the 1987 election. This requires explanation. The current electoral Act, as I understand it, does not force that kind of revelation at the time or even subsequently. I understand that because the actual donation was given in November-whether it had been undertaken to be given or not-it will be required to be reported after the next election to be held, presumably in May or March in 1990.

In the first place it seems to me to be essential for a proper election environment for this sort of stunt to be revealed concurrently with the activity so that voters at the next election can judge the extent to which they should put weight-or not put weight-on the political statements at election time by organisations like the Wilderness Society that have participated in an election campaign and have been funded by someone for whom Mr Farmer was acting. Clearly this money could not have come from Mr Farmer's own company's funds. It had just lost $1m. Who was that someone? Mr Farmer has not told this place. Mr Farmer has not told anyone. But we know that Mr Farmer was a key adviser to the Government on its election strategy, on its election campaign, and that Mr Farmer's donation went to repay the expenses of the Wilderness Society. Those expenses were heaviest and clearly made at the time of both the Federal and State elections.

One wonders whether this is just a one-off donation or whether any other groups were recipients of similar largess. As well as using public money to influence and support those bodies that are favourably disposed towards it at election time and that continually attack us, one wonders whether there are not other opportunities and instances of the Labor Party, out of its campaign funding or some other source of money, directing money for this specific purpose to supportive bodies to encourage them to participate in election campaigning.

All I understand of the Richard Farmer situation is that other shareholders in his company apparently knew nothing about this donation. One of them told me that he was astonished at the thought of giving any donation of this kind and was unaware as a director that it had taken place. He assured me that the money was definitely not shareholders' money from Richard Farmer and Associates Pty Ltd. So, Richard Farmer was using his company, of which he was not the sole shareholder, not the sole director, as a front for shovelling some money into another body which appears to have acted as if it were at the time a front for the Labor Party in election campaigning.

It seems to me that the electoral laws have to be able to cope with this sort of thing speedily and effectively. As I have said, unless this matter was published by The Eye magazine, unless it was raised in this place, unless the Opposition asked continual questions-as it did-the matter would not have had a public airing before the next election. I hope the voters will be aware of the position when they see the Wilderness Society taking an aggressive anti-coalition position at the next election-which I hope it will not. I hope that the positive and sound environmental policies that Senator Puplick has presented to the Australian people will discourage any body from taking that sort of aggressive position. If those bodies do take such an aggressive position I hope that the Australian voters will recognise their standing, their status, their reputation in terms of the apparent source of their funds. It has been said in a response by Senator Robert Ray:

If the Australian Electoral Commission was minded to believe that that donation was not a direct donation but one in which money was being channelled via intermediaries it has the necessary powers to investigate that.

As I understand it, until the return has been made indicating this, which would not be until the next election, I do not think there is a matter on which the Electoral Commission can investigate because it has not been informed properly of the facts. If that is not so, I hope that if the Australian Electoral Commission has those powers it will investigate before the next election, before the return-in which this matter will be revealed to it officially-is required to be made, that is, after the next election. It is important that any such investigation and any such conclusions the Australian Electoral Commission makes be available to the Australian voters before the next election. As Senator Ray said, if there is any impropriety in this matter it is up to the Electoral Commission to pursue it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not said it has come from Butler; so there is nothing the Electoral Commission can do.

—We do not know where it came from. It seems to me that there should be a capacity in the law, where there is a clear situation like this, for the source of such donations to eventually emerge. But there is no doubt that public exposure of the source three years later is not a satisfactory way of resolving it. Obviously one could underwrite an election donation to a body like the Australian Wilderness Society, for example, as appears to have been done. A donation could be underwritten rather than given before an election. On the basis of that letter of commitment, money could be borrowed in normal, proper commercial terms from a bank of something like that. Because the funding to pay out that loan was not received until after the election the report would not be made to the Electoral Commission until three years later, and the opportunity of doing anything about it would be missed.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988 before the Senate will continue the implementation of recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. This is the third piece of legislation to be introduced as a result of the two reports of the Joint Committee. The first report was in 1985 and the second report was in 1986. There is a long list of proposed changes to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in this piece of legislation. I will deal with what I consider to be the main changes proposed. Firstly, the Bill provides for the printing and distribution of extra electoral rolls to senators and members within two years of each parliament, and the provision is made to supply microfiche and disks of the rolls. This is a very welcome provision in that it enables members of parliament to maintain a standard of reputation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second provision which I believe is of importance is the one that enables mobile voting facilities in hospitals and confirms the rights of patients to a postal vote. The coalition will be moving an amendment to delete the provision that now prevents a candidate from visiting and canvassing votes once the writs of an election have been issued. We believe that some reasonable restrictions should be placed on candidates canvassing votes in hospitals. But an open and democratic election should allow the people in the hospital access to the candidate and access to the material of the candidate. They should not be utterly denied that.

We will be moving amendments to proposed changes to the requirement for polling officers to ask set questions before issuing the voter with ballot papers. The coalition believes that provision should be maintained, that set questions should be asked by the polling officers before issuing the ballot papers, such questions as, `Have you voted in this election before?'. Given the historic Richmond Council election events and the accusations that have been made after so many State and Federal elections about double and multiple voting, I think that is a fair and just requirement.

The next point I wish to make probably concerns the most serious provision of this legislation, that is, the voting rights of prisoners. At present, a person who has been convicted and sentenced to imprisonment for five years or longer is not entitled to vote. The coalition will move that the existing standard remains, the reason being that those who are committed to prison for a crime that carries a sentence of over five years-this duration places the crime in the category of a major crime-have forgone their democratic rights. They should forgo the right to vote. While they are paying their debt to society they should not participate in the normal activities that are carried out in society. That is why they are in prison. They have forgone some of those rights.

There are many other changes within this legislation that I will not go into because they will be adequately handled in the committee stage. But I would like to deal with the activities of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters, from which the Government takes a great deal of advice. In particular, I would like to deal with its last report which looked into the activities of the 1987 election. It is very important that a committee of this nature should be able to report to this Parliament and uphold a certain standard. After all, it is looking into the cornerstone of our democracy, that is, the electoral system. However, this Committee has failed to uphold any decent standard.

The majority report of this Committee, supposedly dealing with electoral matters arising from the 1987 election, is the most party-political and biased report yet presented to this Parliament on such matters. It is now a committee totally without credibility. The recommendations in its last report were nothing short of the taking up of every Labor Party submission to it. For example, the banning of all paid political advertisements on radio and television during election campaigns and the recommendation that all radio and television stations be forced to carry election advertisements--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I was trying to give a signal to Senator McGauran that I do not think canvassing a later report not relevant to this legislation is in order. I did not want to cut him off from making a brief point, but that matter is for debate elsewhere. It is not relevant to this Bill. This Bill is not a communications Bill; it is an electoral Bill. The report the honourable senator refers to would mean amendments to communications Bills, not to electoral Bills.

—Normally, wide discretion is given with respect to second readings of Bills, but I ask Senator McGauran to ensure that his observations are in some way tangible and relevant to the legislation before us.

—The single point I was trying to make was that this Government will go to any extent, it seems, to stretch the electoral laws in its favour. The report of this Committee was a prime example, in recommending that television stations take up the payment for advertisements at election time. At this stage, they are in no financial position to take up such a recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, in light of your warning to stay within the bounds of this Bill, I will raise only one other point. I wish to refer to a serious matter relating to the Government's abuse of section 282 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. As Senator Ray, who is now in the chamber, knows only too well, there was a great deal of debate in the old Parliament House on the method of determining long term and short term senators. Section 13 of the Constitution provides that the Senate shall decide who will serve the long term and who will serve the short term Senate positions. It sets out that this chamber makes that decision.

Until the election of 1987, the method used to select long term and short term senators in the case of a double dissolution was in order of being elected. Those who finished in the first six were the long term senators and those who finished in the second six were the short term senators. However, for reasons that I will not go into, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform found that a number of unfair anomalies were thrown up by this method. Suffice to say, the Committee highlighted that this method was open to political manoeuvring and, in fact, encouraged double dissolutions. It also found that this method did not fairly reflect the proportion of primary votes received by a candidate.

The Select Committee recommended that following a double dissolution the Electoral Commission conduct a second count of Senate votes using the half-Senate quota to determine the long term and short term senators. This recommendation was taken up by the Parliament and written into section 282 of the Electoral Act. The recommendation received unanimous support in debates in the Parliament. Yet, when put to the test for the first time after the 1987 election, both the Australian Democrats and the Government moved as one blatantly to break section 282 of the Electoral Act to favour their own parties' position. They chose to ignore section 282 and return to the unfair and rejected system of choosing long term and short term senators. Senator Ray, who is seeking to interject, was the architect of that deal with the Democrats. He was the architect of breaking an arrangement and an agreement with this side of the House on that section of the Act. Yet he so pompously stood up here yesterday and spoke about the conviction that he had in the propriety and traditions of this Senate. That was just a load of rubbish.

The Australian public should be aware of the extent to which the Australian Labor Party and this Government will go to maintain their power. Obviously they have no bounds. It is a case of `hang democracy'. This Government threw out the rule book, the traditions and the understandings that keep this Parliament operative the day it threw out section 282 of the Electoral Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name your interest.
—I do have an interest because it was blatantly targeted against the National Party.
—Against you, was it?

—Against me and Senator Brownhill. We were the major losers. But that is not just the point. The point is that an arrangement was made in this Parliament and outside this Parliament with Senator Lewis-and Senator Ray knows that, not that I would hold him to any private agreements outside this Parliament-that section 282 be agreed to.
—What is the agreement?

—Senator Lewis had long and in depth discussions on section 282 with the Minister outside this Parliament. Nevertheless, what happened inside this Parliament had the unanimous support of the Parliament. The blatant breaking of section 282 of the Electoral Act cost the National Party dearly. This was nothing but a shoddy deal between the Democrats and the Government. They have thrown out the rule book and broken every understanding that has been reached in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable senators who have spoken for their contribution to the debate. I would like to respond to them in reverse order-and also reverse order of intellect, I suspect. Senator McGauran came in here and said that there has been a great breach of section 282 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Let me educate Senator McGauran for a moment. The political party of which he is a member did not give this matter even one iota of thought before the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform looked at it. All that section 282 does is insist that the Australian Electoral Commission provide this chamber with alternatives. It does nothing more. The Constitution is paramount. The Electoral Act cannot override the power of this chamber to determine long and short term senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McGauran has some idea that a deal was made before the last elections. I will tell him what the deal was. I said consistently prior to 1987 that the Senate itself should determine in advance of a double dissolution who would be the long and short term senators-not put the fix in afterwards, but determine it beforehand. I could never get agreement from honourable senators on Senator McGauran's side to go along with new section 282 because they said that they wanted to see what the result would be before they made a decision. So Senator McGauran should not come into this chamber and say that I broke my word, because I did not. I acted with propriety. We put a different method of approach in the Electoral Act. This Senate should have adopted that prior to 1987. It should adopt it now, well before the next double dissolution, so that everyone knows in advance what the counting system will be for long and short term senators.

The old system goes back to the 1900s when we did not have proportional representation, when we did not have an expanded Senate and when we did not have a quota under which Senator Dunn and Co. can get 1 1/2 per cent of the primary vote and be elected. But if they had walked in with, I think, 6.8 per cent of the primary vote, they would have had a long term. Meanwhile, the third senator on a ticket led by a senator who gets 50 per cent has to take a short term. That is why section 282 was put in the Act. That system should have been approved by this chamber-it would have had only strong moral sanction-in advance of a double dissolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —How strong do you think?

—I think fairly strong-not overwhelmingly strong because someone with an absolute majority can do a deal. But it makes it a lot harder. If we could find some time in our program, we could probably dispose of the section 282 problem in a couple of hours this year or next year.
—Do it now.

—If honourable senators opposite would not keep taking Government Business out of my hands, I might be able to. If we have some time after the committee stage, we should do that. But it has to be done in advance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McGauran gave a quick summary of what his objections were to the Bill. He then went on to attack the credibility of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I will let Senator McGauran into a secret: the party of which he is a member and the coalition never supported the setting up of this Committee. They opposed it. They never wanted any electoral reform. They wanted the old rotten borough Electoral Act because it suited their purposes. They never wanted any change. Senator McGauran has made an attack on the members of that Committee and plenty of those members in this chamber will at some stage respond. But some of those members put in an enormous amount of work. The first Select Committee, of which Senator Macklin was a member, met right through the winter of 1983. I think it met solidly for something like six to eight weeks. I do not want Senator McGauran to come in here and tell me that this Committee has no credibility.

While we are on the subject of credibility and self-interest, because that is obviously what has motivated Senator McGauran on section 282, the honourable senator spent 180 grand to get in at the last election and now he is out because apparently I have dudded him on section 282. Well, I am sorry about that. But Senator McGauran is going to come back, I hope. Senator McGauran should apply this test in respect of the Liberal Party: he trusts his colleagues in this place so much that he would not even take their word that they would re-endorse him the next time around. There had to be a meeting in Melbourne at which eight Liberal officials and six National Party officials all signed a leather bound agreement so that Senator McGauran can return here, not after the next election but after the one after that. That is how much he trusts the word of the Liberal Party. That is how much the National Party trusts the Liberal Party. It was like one of those peace treaty negotiations held in Iceland when everybody lines up and the pens are sold afterwards. What a joke! But that is enough on Senator McGauran.

Let me move to one whom I find a far more obnoxious individual-Senator Michael Baume. I found his speech today terribly obnoxious. Earlier on he said, `I wonder whether any taxpayers' money was used, basically by the Australian Conservation Foundation, in the election campaign'. From that one premise a whole series of allegations flows. Let me make my position clear. Organisations such as the Australian Conservation Foundation are entitled to campaign in elections; they are not entitled to use any taxpayers' money to do so. Quite often they have other fund raising, but they must be able to do that in such an accounting way as to prove that no taxpayers' money is ever used. That was the missing link with Senator Baume today: he never went on to prove once, in a 15-minute diatribe--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was more like half an hour.

—No, because then he went on to the Farmer matter; I am coming to that in a moment. He went on for 15 minutes attacking the Australian Conservation Foundation, et cetera, but he never made the great causal linkage that was necessary. I would oppose the Australian Conservation Foundation using any taxpayers' money to campaign. That would be a disgrace. The Foundation should not do that, and I do not think that it has done it. I have a lot to do with a similar organisation, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, which receives a core grant from the Federal Government. A couple of times it has been reported that it will campaign on this or that in the next election-I think once for us and once against us. Both times I drew that to its attention and it said, `No, that is a misinterpretation. All we are saying to our affiliates who receive no money is that these are crucial issues on which you can campaign'. That is the way it should be. Senator Baume today, based on this one half-premise that he never proved, then goes and builds this enormous straw house, as he often does. This is muckraking in its purest form. It lacks the energy of an Upton Sinclair or a good muckraker; it is just poor muckraking.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me move to the Farmer matter, as this has been raised before. Senator Michael Baume again raised only the initial allegations. None of the stuff that appeared in the press later to qualify any of that was mentioned-that the company that donated the money had not had a $1m loss the year before because it was mixed up with another company. None of these matters were brought to bear by Senator Baume. Senator Macklin will recognise this: the thing that almost moved me to tears was when he described the modus operandi of a company borrowing money and then spending it on the election campaign so that we cannot track it back any further. Has he never heard of Carpentaria Exploration Co. Pty Ltd, a $2 company in the Northern Territory that funded Senator Tambling's return to this place? It borrowed $390,000 and not one cent was ever traced. Senator Baume's own coalition went to court to prevent the Australian Electoral Commission tracking down the source of funds, and he has the hypocrisy to come in here today and say that he wants to know where the Farmer donation originally came from and whether it was Farmer or someone else washing the money through. What hypocrisy to argue that when his own Party does exactly the opposite-absolute hypocrisy! So much for Senator Baume's half-hour contribution.

Prior to that we heard Senator Knowles. The first point she made was that this legislation had been around forever and we had been frightened to bring it on. Everyone knows what the pressure on the program has been like. Everyone knows that Budget Bills must take priority and that we had this legislation listed on many occasions and never got to it because of long drawn out debates on other matters, and that it could not have priority over urgent business. That is the reason why it has been delayed from time to time.

Senator Knowles then went on to make the classic statement that it shows a lack of concern by this Government about electoral laws. Well, by golly, gosh, the Liberals were in office from 1949 to 1972 and from 1975 to 1983 and hardly touched the electoral laws. They had a major constitutional inquiry in 1958 that recommended total revision of the Electoral Act, but did not touch it. In 1983 we were left with one of the most anachronistic electoral systems; the Electoral Commission was down in morale and down in funding; we had a re-distribution system that was becoming a joke-all these things. We have spent a lot of time, money and effort to lift that. It has not always been done in a bipartisan way. On the minor stuff it has, but on a couple of the big issues we have had to disagree. Public funding is a classic example of it. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which Senator McGauran so disparages, often went out of its way to find a middle course to suit all political parties, because electoral laws cannot be drawn up on the basis of partisanship. If they are, it will eventually backfire on those who draw them up.

Then Senator Knowles threw out the big line that we have heard often in this debate about rorts and multiple voting. I challenged her by way of interjection and said, `Name them'. She said, `Oh well, Senator Ray knows what I am talking about'. Well, I do not. I want to hear about it. There were 11,000 possible multiple voters in the last New South Wales Federal election on first view. I think it came down to about 15 unexplained cases after investigation-something like that-out of three million people voting. There is always potential for abuse in a user friendly system, but at least provide some proof that there has been abuse because, if there has been, then we will have to tighten it up. It would have to be tightened up probably by way of computer, by way of terminals in the polling places to prevent any multiple voting. But just to make the accusation that there are rorts and multiple voting and not adduce one example is a very pathetic approach.

Then we are accused of being masters of gerrymandering because in the last Federal election-this was not made quite clear by Senator Knowles-there was a swing to the Liberal Party but it lost more seats. Well, golly, gosh, can we have government back for 1954, 1961 and 1969-thanks very much? These things happen, but at least there has to be some electoral analysis as to why they happened, where the differential swings occurred. I think I am right in saying that the 1987 election was fought entirely on boundaries that had been fought on before, so it was not as though the boundaries had just been changed. There are such things as growth that lead to differential swings. Most people know, if there is any analysis at all, that the real gain for the Australian Labor Party came in Queensland, where in 1984 we missed out narrowly on four or five seats. This time we just tipped over the line in those four or five seats. That is why, with a slight swing against us, we were able to improve our position. Those things occur. It is also to do with the demography of cities. The old demography of cities very must hampered Labor, but as more middle class people are moving into inner city areas and the working class get forced out simply because they cannot afford to stay there any more-they have to go to where transport is more expensive-they are caught midstream in a great gentrification. At either end it will help the Liberal Party, but in the middle transitional process it will be of assistance to the Labor Party.

If Senator Knowles is to be listened to, why not go back and look at the 1966 election in Melbourne where Labor won eight seats with 40-odd per cent of the vote, all concentrated in the western and northern suburbs? These things occur. It is not a gerrymander; it is just the way the cookie crumbles. If Senator Knowles wants to take that a bit further and say that the current boundaries are gerrymandered, she should walk outside this chamber and say, `Look, Professor Hughes, Justice Morling and the rest of you have been involved in a grubby exercise to rig the boundaries for the Labor Party'. Those opposite are not willing to do that; they are just willing to make the general, smearing accusation and then retreat.

I thought the daddy of them all was to introduce Western Australia. It is actually the first time that it has been raised in this chamber. I put on the record that Labor won a majority of the seats without a majority of the votes. That is the first time it has been raised here since the State election. Why? Because straight after the State election members of the Liberal Party had a caucus meeting in Western Australia where they all broke down and cried and said, `If only we had let the Labor Party electoral reform Bill through, we would now be in government'. Five times we were defeated in the upper House when we put the proposition to reform the Western Australian electoral laws. The sixth time we got a compromise; we got part change. We lost a Minister out of it-Mr Tonkin, who was still a purist. He said, `No, that is not good enough. You should never compromise'. But that very compromise, which still led to malapportioned electorates, grievously cost the Liberal Party at the start of 1989. If any party has been hoist with its own petard and deserved it, it would be the Western Australian Liberal Party. It has to cop it in the neck because it refused. If we had had one vote one value, the Western Australian Liberal Party would have had a much better chance-it would have been almost inevit- able-of winning power in Western Australia.

Two consistent issues were raised by Senator McGauran and Senator Knowles on the question of prisoners. I have always had an open mind on that. I have always worried about double jeopardy and, as Senator Macklin would know, I have always been one of the floating voters on this matter. Why should we put two penalties on a prisoner? I have always worried about where we draw the line; I have always had a problem in that regard. Ultimately, we should perhaps have left it, by way of amendment, to judges to determine, when they convict someone, as to whether they think their voting rights should be taken away.

So much for the speakers today. I will not refight the battle of Castlereagh, which was refought in the chamber in the debate on this Bill. I simply put my views on Castlereagh on the record, and I do not wish to say any more than this. I repeat my invitation to Senator Bishop to come into the chamber and apologise about that and clear the stain off what I regard as a very promising political future. Senator Puplick made a number of points that he will pursue in the committee stage, so I will not go over those now. From my reading of Senator Puplick's speech this morning, he covered a whole variety of different rounds, and I do not particularly want to respond to any of that.

Finally, I want only to say that, in many ways, I think it is a pity that this Bill appeared in the way it did. But for an early election it would have appeared as a complete Bill in 1987. At that stage part of those reforms were enacted because we needed to get the Senate voting system in for a new election. We already had the redistribution stuff drafted, so it was shoved through then; and this Bill has been introduced while we are still awaiting a committee report recommending further amendments which just cannot be drafted in time before the next election. I think that is a matter of regret. But this Bill, on the whole-we have to remember that at least 95 per cent of it, in terms of its technical amendments, is agreed-will improve the running of the next Federal election, whenever it is. As such, it is welcome. No doubt we will have some vigorous discussion on three of four of the amendments proposed to this Bill. I wish the Bill a relatively speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Clause 2 (Commencement).

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, subclause 2 (1), line 8, leave out ``1 and 2'', insert ``1, 2 and 3''.
(2) Page 1, subclause 2 (2), leave out the subclause, insert the following subclauses:
``(2) Subject to subsection (3), the remaining provisions of this Act commence on a day or days to be fixed by Proclamation.
``(3) If a provision referred to in subsection (2) does not commence under that subsection before 30 September 1990, it commences on that day.''.

These amendments are primarily to do with the date on which the Act receives royal assent. Clause 2 is also amended to provide that any provisions not proclaimed by 30 September 1990 automatically come into force on that day. These are standard provisions that have virtually come into practice post-dating when this Bill was first brought in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports these amendments. As the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has said, they are technical amendments. However, I draw attention to the provision of the amendment to add a subclause (3) to clause 2 which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: If a provision referred to in subsection (2) does not commence under that subsection before 30 September 1990, it commences on that day.'.

I think it is a very good practice to insert in legislation specific dates on which provisions will come into effect, rather than simply leaving them all to come into effect on a day to be fixed by proclamation. Senator Macklin, who is in the chamber at the moment, will recall that on a number of occasions we have had debates about unproclaimed legislation, some of which has remained unproclaimed for about 60 years. As the Minister has said, the provision of specific dates is now becoming standard practice, and it is very much to be welcomed.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 14-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter in relation to clause 14, and to ask the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) for some clarification. I quote from page 2137 of the Hansard of 29 April 1988-some considerable time back-when the Minister, in making his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill provides fixed formulae for the representation of Territories and new States in the Federal Parliament.

Honourable senators will recall that there has from time to time been considerable discussion about the provision for the representation of new States in the Commonwealth Parliament. People will recall that this matter was the subject of a specific inquiry by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, largely on the initiative of the honourable member for Sturt, Mr Ian Wilson, who sought to provide in electoral law a fixed formula in advance for the way in which the representation should be accorded to new States. Clause 14 provides for an advance formula for the way in which future representation of the Territories is to be handled in the Parliament.

I simply raise the issue and ask the Minister to indicate why, although the second reading speech indicated that a formula would be inserted for the representation of new States, it is not reflected in the Bill. I think I am correct in saying that this may derive from the provisions of section 121 of the Constitution, which states:

The Parliament may admit to the Commonwealth or establish new States, and may upon such admission or establishment make or impose such terms and conditions, including the extent of representation in either House of the Parliament, as it thinks fit.

I presume, therefore, that the argument is that this is not a matter than can be settled in advance; in fact, it can be settled only after the new State has been admitted. I just want to clarify that as an explanation of why something which is referred to in the second reading speech does not occur in the Bill. I take this opportunity to put it on the record that it is the view of the coalition parties that, in what I guess is the unlikely event of new States being admitted to the Federation, their formula should be fixed, in terms of representation, in much the same way as is currently provided in the proposed amendment to section 40 of the principal Act by clause 14 of this Bill, which sets out the formula which will in the future govern the provision for representation of Territories in the Commonwealth Parliament. I just want to clarify the reasons why questions of the States are not referred to in the legislation itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure I have the answer right in front of me at the moment. The general philosophy of this, as Senator Puplick correctly asserts, came from an initiative from Mr Wilson, who pursued it at the constitutional conventions but could not bring it to any form of fruition. What we have endeavoured to do here is to lay down a formula which is not binding if statehood occurs. Again-this is the second time I have had to use this word today-moral sanction was the intention of it. There was a fear, if you like, that without having something in legislation there was the potential for rorts. There would be nothing to stop a Federal government so minded, if it had a majority in both Houses, to declare the Australian Capital Territory a State, give it 40 senators and flood this place. There is still nothing to stop that except that at least we now have some impediment in the legislation that will make that a little harder.

SPEECH.PARA: As for new States coming in, it was the original intention of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform to have the same sort of formula apply. But again that cannot be enforced because it is a matter for negotiation at the time they come in. I make one other observation: I know that some people are very keen on giving 12 senators to the Northern Territory on its accession to statehood. All I can say is that insistence on that will probably prevent statehood. I really do think people would see that as the major impediment to statehood. A different formula is needed. I do not suggest a miserly formula but I really think that with 12 more Collinses or Tamblings there would be no room for any of us in the debates. They have made a big contribution down here-I have to say that; they can both use that on their pamphlets-in terms of time taken up. I do not know whether that has thoroughly answered Senator Puplick's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just asking whether it is in fact constitutionally prohibited to put it in in advance of the representation of new States.

—We can put it there but the Constitution overrides it. That is quite clear. If a new State is created next week, this legislation will be used only as a guide; it cannot be imposed. But, if we put it there, Parliament is giving a guide for future generations. Without it there, if some future government wanted to rort it, we think it would be much easier to do so without this guidance. That was as far as we could take it in the Select Committee and that is as far as this chamber can take it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 14 deals only with Territories. Senator Puplick and Senator Ray both referred to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I put in a dissenting report from the majority on that Committee. I was the only person on the Committee who felt that new States should be treated in exactly the same way as existing States. I argued at some length in that report that to do otherwise would set up two classes of State-the old and the new-which, further down the track, would lead to the most enormous constitutional difficulties. It seems to me that the federal system that we should follow in this country is the federal system of the United States of America which, regardless of territory, regardless of numbers, elects identical numbers of senators from each of its States.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure what Senator Tambling, the only Northern Territory senator in the chamber at the moment, thinks about this. I do not want to misrepresent Senator Collins, but when Senator Collins was the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory he was the Northern Territory delegate to the Constitutional Convention which met in Brisbane. He and I argued on the same platform-I must admit we were not joined by many others-that, if the Northern Territory became a State, it should become a State on exactly the same basis as the other States of the Commonwealth. The population number is irrelevant when it comes to working out how many senators there should be. It is a very relevant item when it comes to working out how many members of the House of Representatives there should be. The method of choosing senators is to choose them by State. The method of choosing members of the House of Representatives is by population number. I do not resile from that position. I think, ultimately, that that position will be adopted, not the position of having two senators from a territory.

The other item Senator Ray raised by way of comment is still an enormous problem in the Constitution and that is that it is up to the Commonwealth Parliament to determine how many senators those new States will get, or even how many senators a Territory will get. That is an absolutely extraordinary time-bomb probably waiting to go off, and undoubtedly that will go off at some stage in the future. I am quite sure that neither this Government nor the incoming government will use it but I am sure a government will try to use it at some stage if there is overwhelming support in a particular territory for one party or the other. At the moment the general circumstances are such that the major parties in this country have about even support in the Territories and hence it would be an unlikely occurrence.

I too read the Minister's second reading speech and I could not find anything in the Bill on new States, so I welcome this information. The argument about new States will have to be fought at a later stage when the Parliament decides upon what basis the Northern Territory will be admitted as a State. I think probably at that time the view that I have, which was the lone one on the Committee, may become a slightly more popular view. It needs to be argued on the basis of the merits of the case rather than on who will get people elected and who will not. A new State to be admitted should be admitted on terms identical with the current States. Anything else would lopside our Federation for the ensuing future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond only very briefly but I want to put on record the view of the Opposition on that issue. Of course, Senator Macklin is correct in referring to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform of November 1985 entitled Determining the Entitlement of Federal Territories and New States to Representation in the Commonwealth Parliament. Its recommendation is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . no new State should be admitted to the Federation on terms and conditions as to its representation in the Parliament more favourable than those that the Committee recommends for representation of Commonwealth Territories.

That is the position which the Opposition parties endorse. The fundamental difficulty with Senator Macklin's position and with the analogy that Senator Macklin draws with the United States of America is that the United States Congress is not blessed with the nexus provisions in its Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not blessed?

—Despite the worthy attempts of the Parliament to persuade the people of Australia to break the nexus, they decided in their wisdom not to do so. Therefore, the question of representation in the Senate is not a matter without consequence for the size of the House of Representatives whereas the question of the size of the House of Representatives of the United States has absolutely nothing to do with the representation of the States in the United States Senate. So the addition of new States in the United States certainly increases the size of its Senate but its House of Representatives is determined purely on a national population basis regardless of the composition of numbers in the Senate. That is the fundamental difference in the analogy that Senator Macklin drew between Australia and the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 15 (Casual vacancies for places of senators for Territories).
