SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 6, clause 15, lines 27 to 30, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Casual vacancies in places of senators
for Territories
``15. Section 44 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by inserting after subsection (2) the following subsection:

``(2a) If the place of a senator for a Territory other than the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory becomes vacant before the expiration of his or her term of service, the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, sitting and voting together at a joint sitting convened by the Governor-General, shall choose a person to hold the place until the expiration of the term, but if the Parliament is not in session when the vacancy is notified, the Governor-General may appoint a person to hold the place until the expiration of 14 days from the beginning of the next session of the Parliament or the expiration of the term, whichever first happens.'';
(b) by omitting from paragraph (5) (a) ``and'';
(c) by adding at the end of subsection (5) the following paragraph:

`` ; and (c) in the case of a senator for a Territory other than the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory-the President of the Senate shall notify the Governor-General of the vacancy.'';
(d) by inserting after subsection (6) the following subsection:
``(6a) The name of any senator chosen by the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives under subsection (2a) shall be certified by the President of the Senate to the Governor-General.''.

This amendment relates to casual vacancies for places of senators for Territories. This amendment is required as a consequence of the recent amendments made to the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act. Clause 15 amends section 44 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act to provide for the filling of casual vacancies for places of territory senators other than senators in the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Section 44 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act has been recently amended by the ACT Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988 to provide that casual vacancies for Australian Capital Territory senators shall be dealt with by the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly. I wish all ACT senators good health. The amendment of clause 15 inserts a new clause which provides that casual vacancies for places in a territory other than senators for the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory shall be filled by a joint sitting of the Houses of Parliament or, if the Parliament is not in session, by the Governor-General until the expiration of 14 days from the beginning of the next session or the expiration of the term, whichever first happens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this occasion the Opposition has decided to allow principle to overweigh evidence in relation to the judgment which we make about this particular matter. We will support the Government's amendment. It does put the Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory in exactly the same position as State parliaments in relation to the filling of casual vacancies. I am the first person who came into this Parliament under the provision of revised section 15 of the Constitution.
—Sibraa and you.

—Senator Sibraa and I were appointed by the Parliament of New South Wales on the same day. We were appointed under the provisions of that section of the Constitution after it had been amended to require that the senator replacing a senator whose position has become vacant should be from the same party.
—On the day on which they are sworn in.

—That is correct. Any dirty work at the crossroads between the time of their selection by the Parliament and the time of their swearing in would be avoided. Indeed, it simply means that if they want to rat they have to rat later. But because we have that provision of section 15 which guarantees that the replacement senator will be from the same party we are prepared to overlook the question of parties in the Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory just at the moment and what constitutes parties in that worthy deliberative chamber. Because this is a matter of putting the Territory assemblies on the same footing as State parliaments in the filling of casual vacancies the Opposition will support the Government's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 16 to 24-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 24a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 9, after clause 24, insert the following new clause:
Redistribution Committee to make proposed
redistribution
``24a. Section 66 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting `and' (last occurring) from subparagraph 3 (b) (iv), and adding, after subparagraph (3) (b) (v), the following new subparagraph:

`and (vi) the extent to which the representation in the House of Representatives, of the people of the State or Territory reflected the views of the electors as evidenced by a majority of the formal votes counted towards the election of candidates in the State or Territory at the last general election or the general elections that occurred since the last redistribution of the State or Territory.' ''.

This amendment inserts a new clause 24a which would insert into section 66 of the principal Act a new subparagraph. It would omit a word and add a new subparagraph relating to the way in which redistributions are to be carried out. At the moment the electoral commissioners are enjoined under the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act to take certain matters into account in determining electoral boundaries. Those matters are as follows: section 66 (3) (b) states that the Redistribution Committee:
. . . shall give due consideration, in relation to each proposed Electoral Division, to-
(i) community of interests within the proposed Electoral Division, including economic, social and regional interests;
(ii) means of communications and travel within the proposed Electoral Division;
(iii) the trend of population changes within the State or Territory;
(iv) the physical features and area of the proposed Electoral Division; and
(v) the boundaries of existing Divisions in the State or Territory.
Our amendment seeks to add subparagraph (vi) in the following terms:

. . . the extent to which the representation in the House of Representatives, of the people of the State or Territory reflected the views of the electors as evidenced by a majority of the formal votes counted towards the election of candidates in the State or Territory at the last general election or in the general elections that occurred since the last redistribution of the State or Territory.
This matter has been quite extensively canvassed in the second reading debate. I do not propose to canvass it very much further.

Senator Ray is right in referring to the fact that in 1954, 1961 and 1969 the Australian Labor Party obtained a majority of the votes cast but did not secure a majority of the seats in Parliament. In 1954 the Labor Party polled 50.7 against the coalition's 49.3. In 1961 the Labor Party polled 50.5 against the coalition's 49.5. In 1969 it polled 50.2 against the coalition's 49.8. Of those perhaps 1961 was obviously the example where there was the closest conjunction in terms of seats and votes with the Government in the House of Representatives ending up with a majority of one. We have drawn attention to the fact that in the 1987 Federal election the Australian Labor Party polled 45.8 per cent of first preference votes, which was down from the 47.5 it had polled on the previous occasion, but its representation rose from 82 seats to 86. The Liberal Party polled 34.6 per cent, having increased from 34.4 per cent in the previous election, but its representation fell from 45 to 43. The National Party polled 11.5 per cent, up from the 10.6 per cent which it had polled on the previous occasion, and its representation fell from 21 to 19 seats. In other words, there was a swing to the coalition parties of something in the order of one per cent. As a result of that swing the coalition parties actually lost four seats.

Complaints have been made that a party which polls an increase in its vote should not be penalised with a decrease in its representation and a party that has its votes cut should have its representation increased. Senator Ray has quite rightly drawn attention to the difficulties that a political party faces when the swing which is obtained is concentrated in the seats which are not the most marginal of seats. Quite clearly, where there is a major swing to a political party we find situations where we need a one per cent swing to win a seat and we get half a per cent or we need an 18 per cent swing to win a seat and we actually get 15 per cent. Overall, those distortions do occur. They are inevitable in any system which has a single member electorate and they occur where the system does not provide for a precise reflection across the whole State of the representation of the political parties. We have seen in Europe and elsewhere the use of the list system in order to overcome this.

Nobody argues for the moving away at the Federal or State level, other than in Tasmania, from a system where we have single member constituencies. Certainly those advocates of proportional representation and of other systems have attacked this system. They make a legitimate point in that regard. We, however, believe that we should retain single member constituencies. In order to have both the single member constituencies and the result in those constituencies most accurately reflect the overall position, we have moved this amendment, which in fact casts in legal form something which we suspect is not entirely absent from the minds of the electoral commissioners when they go about their work anyway. They are not required to have regard to this particular matter. Section 66 of the principal Act does not enjoin them to bear this question in mind. They bear all sorts of questions in mind with the best will in the world and I say to them that they should undoubtedly bear in mind, when doing the redistribution in Victoria, that Wills and Kooyong should always look pretty good. It would be a very bold Electoral Commission that decided to turn Wills or Kooyong into a marginal seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do know they will take Kodak out of Wills, which you have not picked up yet.

—We are fully aware of where Kodak was and it would be an interesting exercise for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to go out there and say, `When Kodak was in my electorate we agreed that it would get $60m. It is only when we moved it into Mr Howe's electorate that the Parliament decided to knock it off'. Undoubtedly Mr Howe will have to explain to his constituents why the Prime Minister could make the announcement that an area in his electorate would get funded but, at the end of the day, could not deliver. I am sure that the Prime Minister will have an equally convincing story for the electors on exactly the same point.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the redistribution commissioners bear those sorts of things in mind. After all, they want to be in a position where the electoral redistribution is protected as far as possible from attack. Of course, we now have a situation in which the Parliament itself does not play the same role in electoral redistributions as it did some years ago when whole redistributions were quite frequently rejected, and everybody knows the basis on which that occurred.

What the Opposition amendment is simply saying is that this matter shall be taken into account, that it shall in fact be given, as the introductory words in section 66 (3) (b) say, `due consideration'. We believe that simply drawing to the attention of the Electoral Commission the fundamental principle that, as far as possible, the outcome of the election overall ought to reflect the views of the electorate overall is a fair and proper thing to be said.

We have therefore cast this amendment as one of the factors, the sixth factor, to which the Redistribution Committee shall give due consideration when it is in the process of actually determining the electoral boundaries. Because we believe that it is a fair principle, it should in fact be written as a fair principle into the legislation. As I say, in other parts of the debate this argument has been adequately canvassed and I do not propose to take it any further at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to put the record straight in respect of a matter raised earlier by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). It touches upon this amendment. It is the nexus between the number of seats and the quantity of votes. As the Minister quite properly commented, the last election in Western Australia was the first election in the history of Western Australian elections at which a party won government with less than 50 per cent of the votes. It is interesting, if my memory serves me correctly, and I am not nearly as close to these things as I used to be--
—You will get back in power; don't worry.

—I was referring to the machinations that take place in Western Australia generally. It is interesting that in State elections in Western Australia the nexus between the number of votes and the number of seats won has inevitably been closer than is the case in Federal elections. If I recall, it was in 1980 or perhaps 1977 that the Liberal Party held 90 per cent of the seats with slightly less than 60 per cent of the vote. The present Labor Government holds 77 per cent of the seats with marginally more than 50 per cent of the votes. The nexus between those two things is decidedly more removed than has traditionally been the case in State elections where they do not have the tolerance and are further removed from the argument of one vote one value.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to that issue in Western Australia and again to the extent it impinges upon the amendment, the Minister in charge of electoral reform in the Western Australian State Labor Government, to wit, one Arthur Tonkin, resigned from his ministry in writing. He attended a Government Cabinet meeting in Geraldton at which it was determined that a proposition would be put up that was so outrageous, so preposterous, that it would fail in the upper House. Mr Tonkin was so disgusted with the Labor Government, because of its determination to ensure that there would be no electoral reform and no legislation that would be acceptable to the Opposition so that the Government would not be stuck with the fundamental principle of one vote one value, that he resigned. He resigned because of the shonky tricks the Labor Government was getting up to in terms of its purported attempts at electoral reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberals had some bad luck at the last Federal election and now want to change the system. I find this a very strange proposition. Having spent most of my life writing submissions to redistribution commissioners on the very basis of what Senator Puplick wants to take into account now and having to disguise that matter, I find that Senator Puplick, having done the same thing for the last 20 years, now wants to bring it out into the open. Obviously, each political party puts a submission to a redistribution commission on the basis of what is to its own advantage. If any honourable senator can find an example of where a party has not done so, I would like to know.

SPEECH.PARA: Asking the commissioners to take into account voting patterns to achieve some sort of equality between outcome of votes and number of seats is just impossible. They would have to anticipate what would happen next time. They would have to assume that voting patterns and swings are even right throughout. Then they would have to juggle that with growth figures. Really, I think that this particular proposition just comes out of one defeat.

We must be careful about figures, too. I deliberately threw in 1954 to see whether I would get a bite. The reality of the 1954 figures is that they look dreadful but are explainable. For a start, Labor failed to contest six conservative seats which the conservatives would have easily won by 20,000 votes per seat. Those 120,000 votes were never counted. Three other seats were contested by communists versus Labor. All of the Liberals voted for the Labor candidate, so again a primary vote was artificially bolstered.

I do not complain on behalf of the Labor Party about winning in 1954. It was not that the Party rigged the boundaries in 1949, but its submission to the Electoral Commission could have been identical to the smarter Liberal Party submission, which concentrated on marginal seats whereas Labor concentrated on safe seats. The misfortune of 1954 was of Labor's own doing in part and was also a statistical aberration.

The other problem with Senator Puplick's amendment is that it goes only to the first stage of redistribution. What happens at the augmented Commission? Under the Opposition's amendment it will not be entitled to take these things into account, so the whole thing will break down. The augmented Commission has different powers and responsibilities from the original Commission. Also-this is no reflection on the Opposition as I know how difficult it is to draft clauses-the Electoral Commission itself cannot work out now what is meant by this draft clause and to put it in legislation would be a great weakness.

Senator Puplick was right in one part of his remarks, when he said that generally electoral commissioners do not abolish the seat of the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition-at least, we do not think they do. They certainly did not mind abolishing the seat of Henty, where I have lived for the last 25 years. I thought I had given the Electoral Commission a bit of help over the years, but it did not mind knocking off the seat where I live. It went bang-straight out the back door. I do not know whether I will ever forgive the commissioners for that. We had a very good campaign operation in that seat, which was looked to by other sections of the Labor Party as a model for their own performance. So I am not sure how far the commissioners would go. I think that is the only exception, although a few victims hit the fence in the latest redistribution, such as Tony Lamb.

Things have changed. In 1971, in a casual conversation, as Laurie Brereton passed Askin, Askin said, `Goodbye, son'. Brereton said, `What do you mean?'. Askin said, `I am about to have a redistribution'. Brereton said, `What do you mean?'. Askin said, `Last on, son, first off. See ya'. Sure enough, when the new boundaries came out six months later Brereton's seat did not exist. I do not think we are in quite that situation any more, where the commissioners take such things into account, mostly because of the growth provisions. The overriding growth provisions have really dominated redistributions, and the rest of the factors have to trail in after them. I would very much like to see an electoral system under which it is always the case that if a party wins an increase in votes it gets an increase in seats. Senator Crichton-Browne has obviously never looked at the cube rule of politics, and he should. It is sometimes known as the bogus majority. He should look at it to get an understanding of single member constituencies. I recommend that he do some reading in that regard.

It should be acknowledged that, in the last election, overall Labor got a majority of preferred votes-not a big majority, but an overall one. There was a slight swing against the Party, but that occurred in certain areas. Some people would say that we campaigned better than the Opposition in marginal seats. I do not know whether that is true but, certainly, having sitting members working hard in those seats helped the Labor Party, as it probably helped the Liberal Party in its marginal seats. I do not recall Labor making many gains in seats such as Deakin, in spite of an enormous effort. We could now be recognising the old truism that marginal seats swing the largest. Maybe now they swing the smallest-who knows?

I cannot accept this amendment, drafted as it is. I do not think it will achieve the ends. It binds only the Redistribution Committee and not the augmented Commission, which I think is a problem. The amendment is drafted in such a way as to not give really clear instructions. Does it refer to the previous election or to all previous elections prior to the previous redistribution? If there is a half-Senate election, should past voting patterns be taken into account? All these problems are associated with the amendment. In the end, it would open the Commission to an enormous challenge on the grounds that it has rigged political boundaries. I can say with a fair degree of honesty that the Federal electoral boundaries have been remarkably free of interference over the years. We would like to say the same about every State, but we cannot. We know that. We know that each political party at different times has been guilty to an extent of altering boundaries to its own advantage. I think the situation is getting better right across Australia at a State level, but I am certain that at a Federal level the system is basically clean.

I have to say to Senator Puplick that every now and then one has some bad luck. All I can say is that I am glad it is the Opposition's bad luck and not ours, but I am sure we will be in exactly in the same position in two, three or five years time. In an election there will be a swing towards a party but that party will not pick up the commensurate number of seats. I do not know how a commissioner can guarantee what the Opposition wants guaranteed. Commissioners are not that sophisticated and I doubt there is a political operator in Australia who is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The amendment moved by Senator Puplick on behalf of the Opposition seeks to do what most of us recognise is probably done in some vague way, although I remember in a hearing of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, as it then was, asking the Electoral Commissioner whether the Electoral Commission took the political complexion of seats into account in redistributions and being told that it did not. Looking around the table, I did not think many people took much notice of that reply. Obviously, some account is taken in the redistribution exercise of the political complexion of the seat. Indeed, if I had been drafting this amendment I would have sought to amend clause (3) (b) (i), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . community of interests within the proposed Electoral Division, including economic, social and regional interests;

I would have inserted the world `political'. I have no idea what it would have done, because the difficulty in assessing economic, social and regional interests is already massive. The difficulty in assessing political interests is even greater, particularly under a system which is supposed to be secret. How would one know, other than by taking a particular polling booth, what a particular area is likely to do? We live in a mobile society. I have never voted in the polling booth nearest to my home, and the same can possibly be said for other people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even once?

—No. I think most people tend to go to the one which is on the corridor of communication, and that is the one that the road leads to rather than the one that one would have to work one's way across a suburb to get to.
—It depends on how many stops you are making on the way.

—It depends on how many traffic lights there are. Senator Puplick's city may be different from mine. The road system in Brisbane being what it is, it is often a lot easier to get to somewhere further away than to somewhere close. The difficulty this would load on the Electoral Commission would be immense.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a more important reason why we should not tamper with this clause. This clause was discussed at enormous length in the Committee originally. We sought to do something which was not previously in the Act, to give a paramount position to one item-population. We sought, by inserting a range of items such as the three-six year exercise, to give paramount weight to the number of people in an electorate. As the Act is now set up that is done, because the rest of those items are subject to that overwhelming interest. I am not at all sure how much the other items are taken into account in particular urban areas, because it is excessively difficult to do that and still maintain the first item.

The last point I want to make is that when I first read this amendment, I must admit, I was probably in the same situation as the Electoral Commission. I could not quite work out what it would do in practice. It is drafted in a very interesting way. I found a number of difficulties with the drafting exercise. Having sat on that Committee for a number of years, I tend to err on the conservative side with regard to inserting additional items in the area of the redistribution commission. It is working very well at the moment and reflects the overall philosophy of the Act.

The insertion of this item will not improve by one iota the major issue that Senator Puplick raised-that is, the disparity between representation in the House of Representatives for any particular political party and the number of seats it gets. As Senator Puplick himself acknowledged, that is an inherent part of a single member electorate system. It is just one of the defects in that system which cannot be overcome. To overcome it one would need to adopt a proportional representation system or some variant of that. I have argued in the past that that is precisely what we ought to be doing in the House of Representatives. It is a minority view and one which I am sure neither the Government nor the Opposition will embrace at this point, although on various occasions they have come close to it.

If the Opposition proposes to stick with a single member electorate system in the House of Representatives it will have to wear the defects. The transferable vote through the preferential system improves it vastly over some other methods, such as the first past the post method. Even with that preferential system we will still get some of the anomalies operating. Theoretically, in a single member electorate system all we really need to win under the preferential system is a little over 25 per cent and that will give 50 per cent of the seats. It has never happened but it is possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is mathematically possible.

—Yes, winning anywhere between 25 per cent and 50 per cent, but the closer a party gets to 50 per cent the better the system is working. At the moment as a single member electorate system, I think it is probably operating at its optimum. That system will always have the inherent defect that it can turn up lesser percentages for majorities of seats. It did in Western Australia. Undoubtedly it will do it again.

SPEECH.PARA: We will have an election in Queensland on 2 December. If honourable senators want to look at an odd system operating, they will see one operating on 2 December. Some extraordinary things will occur in that particular election not because of gerrymanders as such-they are relatively minor in Queensland-but because of the massive malapportionment that operates in that State. That is the major difficulty. If we are staying with the single member electorate system the current pressure on the equality of votes is where it should remain and the introduction of this amendment will not do anything in the areas that Senator Puplick wants to do something about.

There are other methods. We can go to some type of top up or whatever else we want attached to a House of Representatives system. It is perfectly feasible, even without going to a proportional representation system, to actually have a top up system on the House of Representatives to overcome that defect. If we are willing to stay with this system at the moment I think that this amendment will not improve it; hence, we will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak very briefly in opposition to this amendment. I agree with all the remarks that Senator Robert Ray made. I want to bring one particular point to the attention of the Senate. As I understand it in 1976 South Australia was the first State to adopt one vote one value in its electoral system and also to establish an independent electoral commission that had the absolute right to determine boundaries. It was one of the great achievements of the then Dunstan Labor Government. The Australian Labor Party as we all know fought for that process for about 30 years.

SPEECH.PARA: As a party official I was involved in the preparation of the party submission to that very first electoral commission in South Australia chaired by Justice Bright. Representatives from the Liberal Party of Australia turned up at the hearings, after 30 years of rigging boundaries, and malapportionment particularly in South Australia, and suddenly started arguing before the commission the exact intent of this amendment-that the commission should draw electoral boundaries according to the voting political preference of people to ensure that the expressed wish of 50 per cent plus one of the voters was reflected in seats. This debate in the commission went on for days. I do not wish to attempt to bring in the whole transcript and seek to have it incorporated or tabled but if Senator Puplick is interested in this debate I draw his attention to the transcript of that debate before the electoral commission in 1976. In the end the electoral commission comprehensively rejected this proposal. It rejected it in principle. The commission hit it right out of the ground in a practical way trying to point out how it could possibly draw boundaries taking into account the way people should vote.

As Senator Ray said, votes change from election to election. Polling booths do not reflect the same vote every election. We can draw boundaries based on the previous election and still get a result at the next election which means that 50 per cent of the vote plus one would not automatically be guaranteed to win a majority of seats. I think that process in South Australia was very thorough. It rejected this notion that has been put forward in Senator Puplick's amendment. Like Senator Robert Ray I also note that people in the Opposition-as seemed apparent from Senator Crichton-Browne's remarks-do not understand that in a single constituency system there is a proportionate amount, or what we call a bonus to the winning side, involved. If the boundaries are fair, winning 51 per cent of the vote does not mean winning 51 per cent of seats. It probably means the party wins close to 60 per cent of the seats. The definition of fairness is that, if at the next election the other side gets 51 per cent or 52 per cent of the seats, it will actually get into government.

Charges and accusations have quite rightly been made that proportionately sometimes the cube rule, in its pure sense, has shown that some governments have been elected in a change of government and they have been underrepresented. The majority actually should have been bigger. I accept that that is a valid criticism. The real point is that the government changed when we had one vote one value and fairly drawn boundaries by an independent electoral commission.

I find the situation in Western Australia deliciously ironic. The Labor Party wanted one vote one value. The Liberal Party rejected it in the upper House and stuck with a malapportionment system. Because the Labor Party through good campaigning, good management and the good attitude of the voters in the outback areas of Western Australia won seats that the Liberal Party did not presume it would win the Labor Party was able to win government. Had a one vote one value system been introduced it is probable that the Liberal Party would be in government in Western Australia today. It is the first time of which I am aware that a party has been hoist with its own petard-a classic phrase-by not supporting one vote one value. I trust that the Western Australian Liberal Party is now willing to support one vote one value in that State because it may well mean that it has a better chance of winning government.

In a practical sense as well as in a principle sense, I think this amendment should be rejected. As in Senator Robert Ray's anecdote about politicians drawing boundaries, there is also a classic case in South Australia. In 1953 Don Dunstan won a seat off the Liberal Party in a major swing to the Labor Party-a seat that had been held by the Liberal Party for many years. There was a redistribution under the Playford Government between 1953 and 1956. The boundaries were redrawn. Dunstan lost the best Labor voting area of his electorate and picked up a very strong Liberal voting area. When the Parliament was dissolved and the speeches made on the last night of the Parliament, Tom Playford took great delight in pointing the finger at Don Dunstan across the chamber saying, `One thing is for certain: the honourable member for Norwood will not be back here after the next election'.

Dunstan was back after the next election with an increased majority which proves that even the best laid plans of Premiers like Tom Playford could not get it absolutely correct in rigging boundaries against someone such as Don Dunstan. I think we all have anecdotes on this situation. I want to conclude by saying that this amendment should be rejected because it is impractical and it will not achieve the result that Senator Puplick would like it to achieve.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 12.45 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to sessional order, the Senate will now proceed to a discussion of matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's Age newspaper states that yesterday the Australia Council notified the Melbourne Theatre Co., Anthill, that its grant for operating costs for 1990 would not be renewed. That represents a cut in funding to Anthill of between $130,000 and $140,000 and will almost certainly mean the demise of the theatre company known as Anthill-the Australian Nouveau Theatre. That decision was leaked. It was forecast in the press a week ago that the Australia Council intended doing this. I find that extraordinary and unconscionable in itself but it is nothing compared with the actual decision that has been taken. No explanation has been given to Anthill or anyone-certainly not to the public-as to why this decision has been taken. It appears to have been taken to meet the whim of the Victorian Minister for the Arts who has asked for a cut in funding to theatres and art in Victoria so that money can be redirected towards so-called initiatives-not one of which has surfaced as yet and been made publicly known.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision has been greeted with dismay by virtually everyone who has had anything to do with Anthill and has any knowledge of the major contribution that it has made to theatre not only in Melbourne but right throughout Australia, for many years. It is the theatre which has, in the words of Patrick White, for example, kept the banner of innovative theatre flying. The company commands the respect of Richard Wherrett of the Sydney Theatre Co.; Neil Armfield of Belvoir St Theatre; Ray Lawler-all the greats of Australian theatre-and virtually all the general managers or executives of theatres and art groups in Australia. For example, Ken MacKenzie-Forbes, the General Manager of the Victorian State Opera and a member of the arts delegation, has said that the Victorian Minister, Mr Walker, who appears to have had a very important part to play in this decision, was being poorly advised if he believed that initiatives that his ministry has funded, such as a pancake race at a cost of $20,000, could take precedence over the continued existence of companies such as Anthill. An outraged Ray Lawler is quoted in the Australian of 19 October as saying this about the then proposal, now the actuality, to abandon funding:

During my years with the Melbourne Theatre Company as a director and literary adviser I was strongly conscious that Anthill's program offered a genuine alternative to the flagship offerings of the MTC, both in style and choice of material. I was particularly aware of the Anthill treatment of European classics, which were staged with a flair and insight that I had not seen elsewhere in the country.
Later as a playwright I watched John-Pierre Mignon-
he is the director of Anthill-
bring the same flair and insight to two productions of Summer of the Seventeenth Doll-
giving both audiences and me a Lawler's own-
fresh and stimulating slant on seemingly hidebound Australian subject matter.
Lawler goes on to say:

It is this ability to break the parochial mould that enables Anthill to make a unique contribution to our theatre scene, and I believe that the company and its artistic director fully deserve government support.

It is John-Pierre Mignon who has made Anthill famous. Earlier this year he was awarded the Order of Australia for his work as artistic director of Anthill. He enabled Anthill, through his brilliance and work, to be voted one of the best three offerings at the Hamburg Drama Festival. The list of people speaking in support of Anthill and the continuation of its funding is very long indeed. I have read the names of some and there are many others. For example, the Melbourne Theatre Co. General Manager, Andrew Kay, said that the closure of Anthill-and that is virtually inevitable-would savage the city's exciting and vibrant theatre scene. That is just one of a range of very typical statements about this quite extraordinary and shameful decision. It is taking place at a time when Arts Council of Australia funding is going to a whole myriad of other projects which quite obviously are being funded because they are the playthings of the mates of the Australian Labor Party.

The funding to which many of us in this chamber have drawn attention from time to time is for trade union arts activities and projects, such as the women in the arts: a gender bias study, at a cost of millions of dollars. The trade unions have received funding through the Arts Council and they have received other forms of government funding. The list is endless. If the Hawke and Cain governments believe that the decision to cease funding Anthill is in accord with the priorities of the development of innovative theatre in Australia, which is important to the development of a culture that will make Australia a country of theatrical and artistic excellence, their sense of priorities is drastically wrong. It is in the public interest that theatres such as Anthill be encouraged to flourish and, as I have said, anyone who has witnessed an Anthill production recognises that the priorities of these governments are to be absolutely condemned.

I have had an opportunity to speak about this matter with my friend and colleague the shadow Minister, Senator Puplick. I know Senator Puplick agrees with me that Anthill is the sort of theatre that the Liberal and National parties in government would fully support. The Liberal and National parties arts policy, which was released some time ago, says this about the Commonwealth's role in the arts:

Adequate direct federal support will be provided for our major arts institutions, and for what will be designated Companies of Excellence. These companies which may already be established with a national focus or may be more regionally based will be those which act as pacesetters in contributing to the improvement of standards throughout Australia. They will be encouraged to further develop a sense of true national responsibility and international outlook. They will be funded through our Major Organizations Unit and with appropriate support from the States.
Later the arts policy document, under the heading `Major organizations', states:

Within the Department there will be a separate Major Organizations Unit to advise the Minister (in conjunction with the Department of Finance) on the appropriate level of direct funding for the major performing arts bodies and the major national cultural institutions. These will be expanded to include not only the major companies such as The Australian Opera, The Australian Ballet and the various State Theatre Companies but also the major arts education institutions, in particular the National Institute of Dramatic Art, the Australian Ballet School and the Film, Television and Radio School. These organizations will be funded directly by the Commonwealth and will be guaranteed funding on a triennial basis, subject to their continuing to meet standards of excellence.

As I understand it, companies such as Anthill would be eligible to be considered, depending on their merit, as companies of excellence and, therefore, would be eligible for funding and support through the major organisations unit. I repeat that I believe, as I think most Victorians do, that the decision announced yesterday to cut to nil Australia Council funding of the operating costs of Anthill is a disgrace. It is illogical and it is a major blow to theatre in not only Victoria but Australia. I urge, in the strongest possible terms, the Australia Council and the Victorian Government to look at this shameful decision.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXOTIC ANIMAL DISEASE CONTROL BILL 1989DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1989EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989LAYING CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989MEAT CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill 1989 and six related industry amendment Bills is to establish an Exotic Disease Preparedness Consultative Council, to raise levies and to provide financial assistance for purposes related to the control and eradication of exotic animal diseases. The coalition parties support the Bills. Their importance is not reflected, I might say, in the Government's decision that they be brought before the chamber during the lunchtime debate on non-controversial matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Any outbreak of exotic disease in Australia would be enormously costly for the nation and primary producers. It would be disastrous for Australian primary producers. But it goes further than that. Given Australia's current economic situation, with our overseas debt in excess of $110 billion and our current account debt running at a rate of approximately $20 billion per annum, if we had an outbreak of exotic disease in this country it would threaten our very economic survival. Such an outbreak would place virtually all exports of livestock products at risk at an estimated cost of about $8 billion a year. As I say, under this Government the nation simply cannot afford to lose the revenue. The result not only would be disastrous for primary producers but also could threaten the very economic survival of the nation.

The Government has agreed to fund the industry on a dollar for dollar basis up to $750,000 a year for an Exotic Disease Preparedness Consultative Council which will assess the adequacy of exotic disease control procedures and the human and capital resources associated with those procedures. The Council will also inquire into the social and economic implications of exotic disease and the compensation principles and advise on how to monitor the efficiency of veterinary emergency plans.

The National Farmers Federation agreed to take up the Government's offer because it saw the need for an independent body to look at these matters rather than an interdepartmental committee being bogged down with them. Honourable senators who have had the pleasure of watching the Yes Minister program know that referring a matter to an interdepartmental committee is often just a means of deferring action for the foreseeable future. The National Farmers Federation decided that it would rather go the other way.

The Council will consist of eight part time members, two of whom will be from the National Farmers Federation. There will be a representative from the Australian Agricultural Council, an officer from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and three people with special and appropriate qualifications. I am delighted to say that a sunset clause provides for the termination of the Council on 30 June 1995. However, I hope that it will be able to complete its important work in a much shorter period.

There is some concern about duplication, as the Australian Agricultural Council has a committee developing a plan associated with exotic disease preparedness and related matters, and some States have been funding their own preparedness plans. The Council will need to liaise closely with those other bodies to ensure that duplication of effort and wastage is avoided.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills raised some concerns in respect of the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1989 because the Bill provides for amounts of levy to be set by regulations, with no provision to limit the amount of the levy. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has agreed that industry contributions to the trust account will be subject to a maximum limit of $750,000, thereby setting a final limit to the annual contributions made by the red meat industry.

There is also some concern that the Council may be used as a backdoor means of transferring more of the total cost of the quarantine program to protect our livestock to a group of agricultural industries, when other beneficiaries including, for example, the general public are not and non-agricultural quarantine costs continue to be borne by the Government. The operations of the Council will need to be monitored carefully to ensure that the levies raised are used for the purposes stated in the principal Bill and are not used to pay for work currently undertaken by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy or some other government body. We wish the Bills a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Opposition for seeing the wisdom and insight of the Government. Nothing in Senator Austin Lewis's--
—Don't push your luck.
—I thought we had an outbreak of bipartisanship here. It is a short moment in parliamentary history to be celebrated and luxuriated in by us all. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 October, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The principal Act imposes an annual levy on all borrowings by Commonwealth semi-governmental authorities other than those which are engaged primarily in the business of financial intermediation. The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill is largely a housekeeping exercise designed to include in the relevant schedule of the Bill two new authorities-the Civil Aviation Authority and Aerospace Technologies of Australia-in order to render them subject to the borrowing levy arrangements. At the same time, the amending Bill will delete from the present schedule the ACT Electricity and Water Authority. That is a proposal which is pursuant to the recent provision of self-government to the Australian Capital Territory and will have the consequence that in future the Authority will be treated on all fours with authorities of the States and the Northern Territory; in other words, not subject to the Commonwealth borrowing levy. The Bill also incorporates some definitional changes which will allow this levy to be applied to any relevant authorities which may be created in the future and also, of course, to the subsidiaries of Commonwealth authorities and companies. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Collection Amendment Bill is a purely machinery measure to give effect to the proposals which I have already outlined. The Bill provides that the ACT Electricity and Water Authority will cease to be liable for payments of the former Commonwealth guarantee charge. The Opposition supports this Bill also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of Senator Stone's remarks, there is nothing for me to say. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL DEBT SINKING FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 October, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Debt Commission was established under the National Debt Sinking Fund Act 1923. Under that Act the Commission comprises the Chief Justice, the Secretary to the Treasury, the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia and a representative of the States. In 1971 I was Secretary to the National Debt Commission and later on, between 1979 and 1984, in my capacity as Secretary to the Treasury, I was a member of the Commission. The Bill arises from a request by the Chief Justice that the position of Chief Justice be deleted from the membership of the Commission. I understand that the Chief Justice put forward this view on the grounds that the activities of the Commission have no relationship to the responsibilities of the Chief Justice and that ordinarily a Chief Justice is unable to contribute any economic expertise to the Commission's deliberations. As to legal expertise, because the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department is already an ex officio member of the Commission, there is no particular need for additional legal expertise of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Mr Peter Morris, wrote to the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, in February this year outlining these circumstances and indicating the Government's intention to amend the principal Act. In his then capacity as shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock replied indicating the Opposition would not object to that amendment. Accordingly, the Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge and take note of the service Senator Stone has given to the National Debt Sinking Fund. In view of his remarks, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 1.19 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask: Did the Minister give as Cabinet's reason for withholding permission for the development of Coronation Hill that-and I quote the Minister's words-`We've got no assessment at all' of other proposals needed to determine the impact on the Kakadu National Park of additional mining projects being allowed to proceed? Were the Prime Minister and Cabinet advised by the Minister of the existence and contents of the report from the Minister's Department entitled Assessment of Potential Environmental Impact of Mining in Rockhole-El Sherana-Palette Area, Kakadu Conservation Zone which, in fact, did assess future mining development in the region and which flatly contradicts many of the Minister's assertions? If so, was this report simply ignored by Cabinet? If the report was not available to Cabinet, does the Minister agree that the Prime Minister should now re-open Cabinet's consideration of this vital economic policy matter to consider this report and the personal submissions of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the story by Peter Gill in this morning's Australian Financial Review upon which Senator Puplick appears to have based his question. I think he could have done better in looking for a source. The real story is very different to the one told by Mr Gill this morning. In January last year I visited the area. I had a look not only at Coronation Hill but also at El Sherana and other sites in the region including Rockhole. BHP made it clear to me that the environmental impact study (EIS) for Coronation Hill would be quite some time off and that it wanted to drill El Sherana to determine the extent of the oil body there. As a result, my primary concern was to get some impression of what would happen at El Sherana and in its immediate vicinity if exploration or mining were to go ahead. I knew that I would be asked to give advice on that matter, on whether or not we should have some environmental assessment of the drilling, and I knew that that advice would be asked for fairly soon.

ANSWER.PARA: The resulting report, which was dated July 1988 and to which Senator Puplick has referred, was not on Coronation Hill. It was a preliminary examination by two officers in the Department of potential problems associated with mining in the Rockhole-El Sherana-Palette area. They are all prospects which are immediately adjacent to the South Alligator River. It was not and could not have been a scientific assessment. I still do not consider that I have any advice before me, any proper assessment before me, upon which I could base any advice either to Stewart West for the specific purpose of drilling or to the Cabinet at the time of the Coronation Hill conservation zone debate.

The report which we are speaking about and about which Senator Puplick has asked me is based on the information, the very small amount of information, which was available 18 months ago. It has since been drowned in a flood of scientific and technical work on Coronation Hill and the region that has become available in that period. It includes the Coronation Hill EIS, which has some examination in it of the Dames and Moore report on the area's natural and cultural values, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation report on the area's biological values and the public environmental report (PER) on exploration at El Sherana.

While Mr Gill acknowledges in the article that some government departments were sent copies of the report, he failed to acknowledge all of the information that he had and that my office had made available to him and just how widely it was distributed. I tried so hard to keep this report secret that I sent it to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. The report was also made available to the Northern Territory Government. That is how secret it was.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—The others got it in July last year, the Northern Territory Government in March of this year. So all the main players in the game-every single one of them-had this report well before the Cabinet debate. The fact that none of them used it in the lead-up to the Cabinet decision or in its immediate aftermath suggests just how really significant it was. It had no significance and no relevance and was used by no-one. But, of course, those who do not like the Government's decision-in particular, that means Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-have been searching their records, combing their files till late into the night, to try to find some way of discrediting the decision. They are going to have to do a lot better than this. Mr Gill claims that after the Cabinet decision I said `We've got no assessment at all' of other mining activity. In fact, I had said that we had no assessment at all of the impact of processing ore from other mines and El Sherana at Coronation Hill. Mr Gill quotes the report as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed Coronation Hill mine plant, tailings dam and associated infrastructure seem to have the capacity to cater for other moderate-sized mines in the valley.
That was an accurate quotation, but when one selectively quotes one always gives the wrong impression. The very next sentence is worth reading in conjunction with the first. It says:
The location of mine workings, waste rock dumps and access roads will need to take into account the results of detailed cultural and natural studies of the area.
BHP made it clear that its final EIS only assessed the processing of Coronation Hill ore. That EIS says:
It is inappropriate to discuss other future developments that are not known or defined at this time.

The conclusions of the report on which I have been questioned by Senator Puplick make it quite clear that there was insufficient information to make a decision about mining impacts. It also points out the many potential detrimental effects of mining. I will read just two of those five conclusions. They are very short. I am quite happy to table the conclusions. The second of the conclusions states:

The lack of project definition at this stage means that it is not possible to determine whether mining could proceed on the current prospects in the upper South Alligator valley without causing significant environmental impact.
It is interesting that Mr Gill could not get that into his report. The fifth conclusion states:

The major environmental risks associated with mines in the valley, including Coronation Hill, arise from run-off and leachate from waste rock dumps, leakage or spillage from the tailings dam and spillage of cyanide, diesel or other chemicals resulting from vehicle accidents. All these events have the potential to affect detrimentally the water quality of the South Alligator River and the World Heritage wetlands downstream.

So even that report, had it been produced and had it been appended to the Cabinet material, would have done me much more good than harm. But, of course, when it comes to the kind of newspaper report we got today, what can one rely on? Mr Gill has a great flurry in conclusion. He suggests that it is terrible that the Cabinet would refer this strip from Coronation Hill through to El Sherana and Rockhole to the Resource Assessment Commission when the report had made it clear that these areas should be subjected to existing processes. That was quite reasonable at the time. The difficulty was that the Resource Assessment Commission did not exist then. How could Cabinet recommend that it go there when it did not exist and Cabinet had never heard of it? Really, in view of all of those inaccuracies, this piece this morning is no more than a scandalous piece of yellow journalism. I would have thought that a newspaper of the supposed quality of the Australian Financial Review could have and should have done very much better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I first of all ask whether the Minister will table not just the recommendations but the text of the report from which he quoted-that is to say, the entire report, not just the conclusions. Secondly, I thank him for his answer in which he dumped on his officers and ask him by way of supplementary question: Since he has conceded that the document was not made available to Cabinet as part of its deliberations when he said `had it been appended', does he stand, therefore, by the statement that he made on 17 October `when you have a long debate in Cabinet it's not possible to believe everything wasn't taken into account'? Finally, since the Minister has conceded that there is now, to use his words, `an absolute flood of information about this subject', can he possibly explain why in the name of reason the matter now has to go to the Resource Assessment Commission for further evaluation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —First off, I reject absolutely any suggestion that I have dumped on any officer in my Department. The two officers concerned who visited the site for a few days are both valued officers in my Department. They are people whose opinions I respect very much. I am only suggesting-and there is certainly no attempt from the Department to deny it-that this was a very quick preliminary assessment which was done before a great deal more information was made available. That is in no way dumping on them. Officers can report only on the information that they can get at. That is the first point that I want to make.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, I was asked whether I stand by the statement that, after a Cabinet debate of this length, everything was taken into account. Of course everything was taken into account. The statements that are put in this report were all argued. They were argued out at very considerable length-not just a little bit but a great deal. Since that time there have been, as I said, an EIS on Coronation Hill, which included some assessment of biological values in the area from Dames and Moore; a PER at El Sherana on drilling, not on a full scale mining operation; and, as I have already said, a CSIRO report was made available as well.

All of those reports helped. They take us further down the path to making the right decision. But Cabinet decided, in my view rightly, that that was not enough, that there are more studies to be done to determine just what effect these mines are going to have on the South Alligator River.
Senator Boswell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not have worried me whether the election was next week or 10 years off. I would have been putting the same case. I would have been putting it because it is right and it has been accepted. The fact that neither Senator Boswell nor Senator Puplick cares about what happens to the South Alligator River does not concern me absolutely one bit. We know where they stand. They are all for filling in wetlands. They are all for not caring about world heritage. Basically, they are a joke. We do not have to worry about it because the world knows it.
—Order! I remind the Minister that he was asked whether he would table a document.
—I am happy to table the conclusions. The report is being copied now for Senator Puplick and he can have it this afternoon.
—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate whether the proposed vote of no confidence in the Prime Minister of Pakistan is likely to undermine democracy in that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I give this answer with some caution in the light of the presence in your gallery of a delegation from the Pakistani Senate who know this subject much better than I. But on 23 October, three days ago, Opposition members in the Pakistan National Assembly did move a motion of no confidence in the Government of Ms Benazir Bhutto. The Pakistan People's Party (PPP) Government of Ms Bhutto holds power in the National Assembly in coalition with several smaller parties, including the Mohajir Qaumi Movement (MQM). The MQM has, however, announced its decision to end its coalition with the PPP and some members of the MQM are believed to support the no confidence motion. The vote is not expected to be taken for some days-possibly not until early November.

ANSWER.PARA: All I can really say about the Australian Government's attitude to this matter is that we did, of course, very much welcome the return to democracy in Pakistan with the election of the new National Assembly in November 1988 and Ms Bhutto's appointment as Prime Minister in December last year. We hope that the outcome of the debate on the vote of no confidence will not jeopardise the progress that has been so obviously, manifestly and attractively achieved in returning Pakistan to stable democratic government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably an appropriate time to draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Pakistan Senate, led by Senator Wasim Sajjad. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I take the opportunity of saying that we are glad to see that the Minister has returned and we hope that he is fully recovered from his ailments.
—Speak for yourself.

—At the risk of having offended some honourable senators on my own side of the House, let me say that the Minister's side of the House has certainly been missing him. I remind the Minister that, in response to a question on 16 June last from Senator Hamer as to whether the depth of our economic crisis was much more serious than the Australian public yet seemed to realise, he said that in his `own subjective judgment . . . the public does not realise the situation fully'. In the light of the September balance of payments deficit of over $2 billion, in seasonally adjusted terms, announced yesterday and the September quarter consumer price index (CPI) figure of 2.3 per cent announced today, does the Government itself fully realise how serious our situation is? What are the consequences for the Australian people of these continuing enormous additions to our foreign debt and this still rising inflation rate of 8.3 per cent for the 12 months ended September?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question on the inflation rate, I do not believe any sensible person would suggest that an inflation rate of above 8 per cent-or 8 per cent or above, depending on which way one likes to look at it-over a 12 month period is desirable or even acceptable. It is, however, better than the inflation rate of 11 1/2 per cent which prevailed for the year ending, I think, the March quarter of 1983--
—What was the peak inflation rate under the Whitlam Government?

—Senator Lewis wants me to tell the Senate what the peak inflation rate under the Whitlam Government was. It was, if I remember correctly, 16.9 per cent in the September quarter of 1974. If Senator Lewis wants to go back further in history, it was 25 per cent for the year ended the December quarter 1951 under the Menzies Government. That was the government that was going to put value back into the pound. I do not know whether Senator Lewis wants any more discourses on the history of inflation in Australia. But I can tell him that that 25 per cent is the highest inflation rate that has ever been recorded in Australia in any 12-month period, or at least since anything like statistics have been kept.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone referred to the answer that I had given to Senator Hamer several months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four months.

—I do remember the question and I do not doubt that he quoted me correctly in that part of the answer. But I do not remember all that clearly the rest of the context of it. The reference that he made to a current account deficit in excess of $2 billion for the month of September, seasonally adjusted, may be correct. But I am aware of no accepted seasonal adjustment for monthly current account deficits. The actual figure was $1.776 billion which, again, as with an inflation rate of 8 per cent-or some might argue, a bit above 8 per cent-is, of course, higher than any sensible person would like to see. This is with the possible exception of a number of members of the Opposition, I suppose, who, for quite cynical political reasons, would probably like to see both even higher because they think it would enhance their chances of getting into government. Of course, that always takes precedence in the Opposition's scale of moral values over the good of the nation.

ANSWER.PARA: On the last point, the consumer price index and the current account deficit are both higher than the Government would like them to be, but neither of those-the three-month accumulated current account deficit for the month of September or the consumer price index for the quarter ending September-are incompatible with the Budget forecasts which forecast a CPI increase of just over 7 per cent for the 12 months ending June and a current account deficit of the order of $18 1/2m billion, with the proviso that we expected the rate of both to be higher in the first half of this financial year. Therefore, it is true that the cumulative current account deficit is just above $6 billion for the first three months. The September quarter CPI is running at a quarterly rate which, if annualised, would be higher than the Budget forecasts. Because it was explicitly spelt out at the time of the Budget that we anticipated both of these figures would be higher in the first part of the financial year, they are not incompatible with the Budget forecast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President. I ask a supplementary question. First, I ask the Minister to explain his comment that he was unaware of any acceptable basis for a monthly seasonally adjusted balance of payments figure? Is the Minister unaware that the Australian Statistician now publishes month by month seasonally adjusted figures for the current account of the balance of payments? If he, as I would have assumed, was aware of that fact, is he therefore saying that the Statistician does not know what he is doing and that these figures are not worth the paper that they are written on? Is that what the Minister is saying? Secondly, in view of the Minister's disquisition upon the budgetary presentation of the balance of payments forecasts-the $18.5 billion figure in the Budget Papers-and as he himself acknowledged the over $6 billion of deficit in the first three months of this year, is he saying that in the second half of this year we will be down to a balance of payments deficit of something like $1 billion a month, or maybe just a shade over $1 billion a month? If so, what will bring that about? Am I correct in thinking that the Minister is now acknowledging the recession which is written in the Budget Papers and which the Minister has never acknowledged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the first part of the supplementary question, I did not know that the Statistician was publishing a monthly seasonally adjusted figure for the current account. Perhaps I should have known, but I did not know that.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of the question is: does consistency with the Budget forecast imply a monthly current account deficit of $1 billion for the rest of this year? The answer is no, it implies no such thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second half.

—That cannot be answered because we do not know what it will be for the next three months. That is just speculation. But if the monthly current account deficit averaged $1 billion for the next nine months-let it be noted that I am not forecasting that will happen-the annual figure would be $15 billion instead of the $18.5 billion that was forecast in the Budget. I did not explicitly spell this out in responding to the first question, but it is true that there is a seasonal pattern in the monthly current account figures, but there is also superimposed on that in this year in the Government's judgment-and this was spelt out in the Budget Papers-a cyclical pattern; that is, we expect the economy to slow down in the second half of this year, total demand to fall, and probably demand for imports to fall more than proportionately to the decline in total demand.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade tell the Senate what is the current state of play of the United Nations convention on the rights of the child? In particular, what is Australia's position on the convention? Will the Government take any special steps to promote the convention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter in which a number of senators and members have taken an interest. Maybe my answer will relieve some of the pressure on my office as a result. The current session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York will consider the adoption of a draft convention on the rights of the child. The current text is the result of 10 years of protected negotiations by a United Nations working group in which Australia was an active participant. Earlier this year the United Nations Commission on Human Rights endorsed that draft convention and passed it to the General Assembly for possible adoption.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government strongly supports the adoption by the United Nations of the draft convention which will set new, internationally agreed standards for the protection of children and will provide a framework for advocacy on behalf of children and families. However, the draft convention does contain a number of issues which could be regarded as controversial and which remain subject to divergent views. In particular, the text contains a definition which recognises that every child has the inherent right to life. Although a reference to the rights of the child `before as well as after birth', taken from the 1959 United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child does appear in the preamble of the draft convention, at the same time a statement in the travaux preparatoires-the preparatory materials-makes it clear that the contentious issue of the child's rights before birth is a question to be determined by individual states parties.

The other matter of controversy is an article in the draft which sets the minimum age for military service at 15. A number of countries, including Australia, strongly oppose this, arguing that the age of 18 should be the minimum. However, the convention will set minimum standards only and individual states parties will be able to determine an age beyond 15 for military service should they so wish.

Australia recognises in these circumstances that the current draft does not entirely meet all our objectives, nor those of some other like-minded countries. However, we are conscious of the risks to the adoption of the convention should these issues be re-opened for general debate at the General Assembly. Australia will therefore resist attempts at the General Assembly to re-open contentious issues which could jeopardise the early adoption of the convention.

No decisions on Australia's ratification of the text can be made in advance of the emergence of an agreed final text, although preliminary consultations between Federal and State governments have commenced. Might I suggest that any further questions, concerning in particular the right to life issue, or on communications between Federal and State governments on the processes of Australian ratification of the rights of the child convention, be directed to the Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given Australia's current trade deficit which I understand is running at somewhere between $4 billion and $5 billion and the consequent need for consumers in Australia to buy fewer imported goods and more locally made products-that is if they are going to buy goods at all-can the Minister say why one of the biggest purchasing organisations in the country, namely the Federal Government, does not follow this principle? In particular, can the Minister say why sections 4a, 4b, 4c, sections 5 to 8, 8a and 8b, sections 9 to 16 and 17 to 20 of the Procurement of Goods, Works and Services Act 1981 have not yet been proclaimed and are therefore not yet operative? For the benefit of others, if not the Minister, I point out that those sections of that Act relate to the preferential buying of Australian goods by Commonwealth authorities. Is it correct that these sections were not proclaimed in 1981 and have not been proclaimed since then despite having the approval of the Parliament, because some Ministers and some bureaucrats objected? If this is correct, which Ministers and which bureaucrats objected, and why were they objecting, to the implementation and proclamation of those sections? If it is not the reason for the failure to proclaim these sections, what is the reason? Will the Government reconsider the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to that question. I will begin by identifying the part I cannot possibly answer which is: Am I familiar with those sections of the Act--
—Well, I told you what they were about.

—I thank the honourable senator, but I would like to look at them myself some time in order that I might have my own view and inform myself from a different source, impeccable as the honourable senator's source may be. I do not know why those sections of the Act to which Senator Haines has referred have not been proclaimed; in fact, until she asked her question I did not know that such an Act existed and I certainly was not aware of the particular sections. Accordingly, I do not know which Ministers and which bureaucrats are obstructing the proclamation of those sections of the Act.
—You had better have a look.

—The honourable senator should wait until the next Estimates committees and then she can yakety-yak away. Accordingly, I do not know which Ministers and which bureaucrats have been, obviously successfully, opposing the proclamation of these sections of the Act. If the honourable senator can give me their names, we will find out; she seems to know more about them than I do.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of government purchasing in this country has been a difficult one for various governments at various times. Numerous inquiries into it have been commissioned by governments, as far as I can remember, since the early 1970s, and different points of view have been advanced on the whole question of government purchasing.
