Earlier this year the Commonwealth introduced an entirely new system of Commonwealth government purchasing which gets rid of the traditional tendering system and provides for functional specifications by departments or government instrumentalities. The former tenderer now puts in a bid on the basis of answering the functional requirement of a department; not on the basis of bits and pieces of equipment and so on. That system has just been introduced. I believe that it will work much better once it is fully in operation, particularly in the interests of Australian suppliers. Specifications for tenders traditionally, for reasons which Senator Haines has identified in her question, tended to be written to suit overseas suppliers. If I might say so-seeing Senator Newman nodding her heard, I assume in agreement rather than nodding off-that has been particularly so in the area of defence purchasing. I do not have the figures in front of me but, if we look at the pattern of government defence purchasing under previous governments and at the pattern of defence purchasing and manufacture in Australia now, we see that there has been an enormous change in that area. I will have a look at the particular sections of that Act. I suspect that they might be subsumed by the new purchasing policies announced by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of reports in the media that, because of the financial difficulties of the Qintex group, there is now a doubt as to whether the Seven network, a subsidiary of Qintex, will be able to pay for the television broadcast rights for the Barcelona Olympic Games in 1992? Is the Minister concerned that, if this comes to fruition, the Australian public will not have access to the Barcelona Olympic Games on television? Will he encourage the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), out of its own resources, to bid for the broadcast rights to the Olympic Games if they become available due to the possible collapse of the Qintex group so that the maximum number of Australians have access to the Olympic Games without the intrusion of excessive commercial advertising?

—I am aware from reports in the press that the ABC is interested in television rights for the Barcelona Olympics. If those rights become available, the Government would certainly see it as appropriate that the ABC pursue them, given the capacity of ABC coverage to allow all Australians to see the Games. As to the funding issue, the Government has made available sufficient funding to allow the ABC to maintain last financial year's level of activity this year and next. It is up to the ABC to work out what it can afford for opportunities like the Olympics. The Managing Director, Mr David Hill, has given the Minister for Transport and Communications an assurance that the ABC will not be seeking any additional funding from the Government to cover the cost of any Olympics bid. It is not the Minister's place, as he acknowledges, to encourage the ABC in any particular direction. The purchase of these rights would be an ABC decision taken by it in the context of its own funding priorities.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Resources, follows the answer given by Senator Richardson to the question asked by Senator Puplick. Is the Minister aware of, and did he read, the report of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the subject of Senator Puplick's question, prior to the Cabinet decision being made?

—I am not in the habit of discussing in this chamber what documentation I read in terms of Cabinet debate. Nor am I in the habit of discussing-as Senator Chaney would know, having been a Cabinet Minister at one time-the proceedings of the Cabinet room.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I sympathise with the Minister, who is a junior Minister, in wanting to honour the proper traditions of Cabinet government. I am not in any way seeking to transgress that requirement. I just remind the Minister that the senior Minister has told the Senate that this report was given wide circulation. I am asking the Minister: Had he received a copy, had he seen the report and did he know of its existence prior to the relevant Cabinet decision being made? If he seeks guidance from his colleagues, I am sure that there will be no breach of any principle of Westminster government in his answering that question.

—Perhaps I should just clarify one point: Senator Chaney was charitable enough to describe me as a junior Minister. We have no such descriptions of ministerial responsibilities. There are Cabinet Ministers and there are Ministers. Perhaps I should just correct Senator Chaney on a point of proper address.
—We get paid the same.
—Senator Richardson gets paid the same.
—I am glad you cleared that up.
—I thought Senator Chaney deserved correcting. As to the other aspect of the question, I have nothing further to add to what Senator Richardson has said in this chamber.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of a recent survey which revealed that pharmacists were overcharging customers for medicines? Are pharmacists engaged in this type of overcharging breaking the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite may not want to join in the search for original information, but I am sure that Senator Devereux does and he is entitled to an answer. I am aware of a survey conducted by the reputable polling organisation, Roy Morgan and Associates. It provided data to members of a consumer panel for Australia and conducted an Australia-wide survey looking at the records and details of purchasing of a wide range of consumer items. During August 1989 panel members were asked to record details of all prescriptions collected from pharmacists by households around Australia. The findings of the survey showed that in New South Wales 89.1 per cent of prescriptions issued were overcharged by an average amount of $1.46; that in Victoria 88.8 per cent of prescriptions issued by pharmacists were overcharged by $1.10; that in Queensland 76.7 per cent of prescriptions issued were overcharged by 76c; that in South Australia, the lowest return, 55 per cent of prescriptions issued were overcharged by 25c; and that in Western Australia, the highest level, 93.1 per cent of prescriptions issued were overcharged by $1.93. Of all prescriptions issued, 83.7 per cent were overcharged, on average by $1.15.

ANSWER.PARA: The amount of overcharging, if aggregated across pharmacies, amounts to a windfall to pharmacists of $29m per annum. Fifty-seven per cent of overcharged items recorded on the prescription form account for the 25 prescribing net; therefore, it is a clear breach of the National Health Act. Drugs priced below the general patient contribution level of $11 attract no government subsidy when supplied to patients without entitlement or with free or concessional benefits. On the basis of that I advise the Senate that the Government will now, having identified a clear breach of the law, look at what legislation needs to be introduced in order to protect the consumers of Australia and ensure that they are paying the right amount of money--

TALK.START.PARA: —Price fixing, eh?

—I am surprised at that interjection on the basis that taxpayers of Australia contribute about $1.5 billion towards subsidies to pharmacies around Australia to ensure the availability of medication and treatment through pharmacies to patients. Because of that input of public funds, there is a real obligation on any government to ensure that the proper rates are charged and, where the law is broken, to do something about it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and follows those of Senator Puplick and Senator Chaney earlier. I ask why the Minister told the Senate nine days ago that any decision to allow mining at the El Sherana prospect in Kakadu National Park would require at minimum the doubling of a number of facilities such as tailings and storage dams when the report of his own Department concluded:

QUESTION.PARA: The proposed Coronation Hill mine plant, tailings dam and associated infrastructure seem to have the capacity to cater for other moderate-sized mines in the valley.
Practical engineering solutions are being developed which could prevent erosion of mine workings, access roads and waste rock dumps.

Did the subsequent environmental impact statement (EIS) at Coronation Hill and the public environmental report (PER) at El Sherana specifically weaken the earlier Department conclusions which only recently came out of the Minister's bottom drawer-in fact since the important Cabinet decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to inform Senator Tambling that they came out of the bottom drawer of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), not mine. I repeat that the report was sent to the Northern Territory Government, to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and to all those interested at the time--
—Everybody except Peter Cook, apparently.

—It went to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I would have thought that is not insignificant. I was asked why I told the Senate that mining at El Sherana would mean the doubling of tailings dams, et cetera, when the report referred to said that the dams at Coronation Hill `seem to have the capacity for other moderate-sized mines'. There is nothing in the report that argues against what I said in the Senate the other day. It is possible to believe now, on the information available to us, if the proposed dams at Coronation Hill were increased in size, they could have the capacity to accommodate other moderate-sized mines. Of course, it would depend on what one meant by moderate and whether one considered El Sherana moderate. It would appear that El Sherana will be at least as big as Coronation Hill, if not bigger. But we would not have known very much about that at the time because the PER was specifically about permitting a drilling operation to find out what was there. My understanding is that BHP is still not sure after that drilling program and may ask us to allow it to do some more.
—That will be a waste of money.

—That will be a decision for BHP, not me. All I know is that it is obviously a highly prospective site. There is nothing in the report that argues against what I said. They stand side by side. I have quoted extensively from the report today and it backs up the stand that I took.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I believe the Minister failed to address the specific second part of the quote and the second part of my question. The second part of the quote from his departmental report was:

QUESTION.PARA: Practical engineering solutions are being developed which could prevent erosion of mine workings, access roads and waste rock dumps.
The second part of my question that the Minister failed to address was whether the subsequent EIS at Coronation Hill and PER at El Sherana specifically weakened the earlier departmental conclusions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to answer all the bits. I must say that when we get asked as many questions as we seem to be asked in each question these days, it is difficult, unless one is accustomed to taking quick shorthand, to get it all down. But I will do my best. I was asked about the EIS at Coronation Hill and the PER at El Sherana and whether they specifically weakened my Department's advice. I quoted earlier from the EIS on Coronation Hill in which BHP specifically refused to address the processing from other mines in the region of Coronation Hill. So no information was available 18 months ago and still is not available on that issue. Of course, that is one of the things that the Resource Assessment Commission will take into account. Senator Tambling also claimed that I had not addressed the sentence that he read out about practical solutions being developed on a number of aspects. I can only go back to the conclusions of the report. He cannot pluck bits out of a report, one sentence here or there, and base his judgment on that. His judgment presumably must be based on the conclusion of the report. I quote again the conclusion of the report because he apparently did not pick it up the first time. It said:

ANSWER.PARA: The major environmental risks associated with mines in the valley, including Coronation Hill, arise from run-off and leachate from waste rock dumps, leakage or spillage from the tailings dam and spillage of cyanide, diesel or other chemicals resulting from vehicle accidents. All these events have the potential to affect detrimentally the water quality of the South Alligator River and the World Heritage wetlands downstream.
The report backs up the case that I put to Cabinet and backs up the Cabinet decision. Senator Tambling may not like that fact, but it is a fact nonetheless.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DETENTION OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS IN NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of recent allegations made in the New South Wales Parliament by the Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Mr Pickering, that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs failed to honour an assurance given to the New South Wales police in relation to the detention of 12 female illegal immigrants apprehended during a raid on Cabramatta brothels earlier this year? Is Mr Pickering accurate in alleging that those detained were held in New South Wales police custody for three weeks because the Department, despite giving an undertaking that this would be necessary for a maximum of only eight days, was not able to accommodate them at its Villawood detention centre after this time had elapsed? Finally, can the Minister say whether the Department of Immigration did meet its obligations in dealing with the New South Wales authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I did receive a letter from Mr Pickering on these matters. My immediate comment to my staff was, `I wonder whether I will read this in the Sydney Morning Herald tomorrow'. I did not; it was two days later when I read a reference to this issue. That is obviously the way Mr Pickering does business. When he writes to Federal Ministers it always gets leaked well in advance. That is a pity because every fact he put in his letter to me was basically wrong. It was our Department that was approached by the New South Wales police to assist in these matters and it was the New South Wales police who agreed to provide the accommodation as we pointed out that our detention centres at that stage were totally full. No persons were detained for 21 days in police cells; I think the maximum time was 10 days. Mr Pickering has all his facts absolutely wrong. I know he is not having a good spell at the moment. He has a few other issues to worry him, with the Blackburn case and a few other matters on which he is not travelling very well.

ANSWER.PARA: These differences between Federal and State governments could be avoided if just some element of courtesy were put back in. When State Ministers from New South Wales write to a Federal Minister, they should wait for a response occasionally rather than going public or leaking the issue or getting a dorothy dix question asked to get it all on the record. If they do that they will not be embarrassed by the fact that all the facts that they put in a letter to a Federal Minister happen to be wrong. That is not the first time this has happened to Mr Pickering. No doubt he has worries of his own. If he does not lift his game and if this is not the issue that sinks him, there are plenty of others around that might.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Does the Minister accept that it is economically and socially desirable to encourage the maintenance of the core unit of our society, that is, the family, by helping parents meet the extra cost of rearing children? If so, does the Government plan to match the Opposition's $1 billion commitment to help offset these costs by allowing tax rebates of $250 and $350 for the first child under 13 and under 16 respectively and $200 and $300 for second and subsequent children in these age groups? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government is committed to maintaining the Australian family unit. No Australian government has done more than the Hawke Government to assist families in so many ways. Yesterday in this place I said that it was surprising that, for all the talk of Mr Peacock's economic package and what he would do for families, he neglected to make any commitment to indexation of family allowance or the family allowance supplement.
—They are currently indexed. You have indexed them, haven't you?
—We have indexed them.
—That all stands. That is a clear position. It has not changed in the statement. It is there. You should be pleased.

—We seem to have to get these details from the Opposition day by day. There are contradictions day by day. It is quite clear from the absolute confusion that has taken place this week with regard to the Opposition's child care rebate that Mr Peacock, Dr Hewson and Mr Braithwaite know nothing about child care or child care policy. If they had taken the time to sit down and talk with those who are familiar with and responsible for community-based child care they could not have made the mistakes that they have made this week. We need go no further than a letter that appeared yesterday in the Melbourne Herald from the Women's Action Alliance. Yesterday Senator Hill criticised the Country Women's Association because it had expressed views against the coalition's family package. Today we have something from the Women's Action Alliance which I would like to take the time of the Senate to summarise. The letter is headed `Lip service no use for child care'. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Peacock Economic Action Plan contains a disappointing omission when compared with the tax package offered by Mr Howard before the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they the people Senator Walsh described as hairy legged feminists?
—I should not respond to Senator Puplick's interjection but I hope he was not suggesting that the Women's Action Alliance is made up of hairy legged feminists. The letter continues:

ANSWER.PARA: The Howard package had tax rebates for child care, balanced by a carer's allowance of $800 a year, paid to families who provided their own child care, thereby forgoing one income.
The period during which a family exists on one income is a financially vulnerable one, and during that time families deserve financial support.

In this instance the Hawke Government agrees totally with the Women's Action Alliance. That is why the family allowance supplement was introduced to assist families in that position. The letter continues:
Under the Peacock package, a two-income family of two adults and two children, aged 11 and 4 years, will get $2010 a year extra assistance, but a single-income family will get only $450 a year.

That is what the Women's Action Alliance thinks of the Peacock family policy. It is most unfortunate that in this place the Government keeps getting this kind of criticism without any acknowledgment of the fact that it was the Hawke Government which introduced the indexation of the family allowance and family allowance supplements. Yet this afternoon we hear from Senator Chaney that Mr Peacock will include indexation but he has not said so. The Opposition spokesperson for the status of women has not mentioned it. I think it is up to Mr Peacock to indicate quite clearly. It has been raised again and again in the other place. Mr Peacock has not been intervening to make that point clear. Is it a fact that the coalition's family package includes indexation of family allowance and family allowance supplements? The community does not know. I would hazard a guess that Mr Peacock does not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I have been very patient but it is quite clear that the Minister has forgotten the question that was asked. She has been canvassing issues that are not at issue and are not in dispute. She has been asserting things that are certainly not true and quoting from other people-trying to boost her own answer. This is not the supplementary question yet but I remind the Minister that I asked whether the Government will match the proposals that have been put forward by us.

—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Reynolds was asked a question on child-care. I have no power as to how a Minister answers a question. It has been a very long answer to the question and I ask Senator Reynolds to finalise it.
—I have finished, Mr President.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Having heard from the Minister that she does accept that the family is important, I again ask: Given that, does the Government plan to match the Opposition's $1 billion commitment to help offset these costs by allowing tax rebates of $250 and $350 for the first child under 13 and 16 respectively and $200 and $300 for the second and subsequent children in these age groups? The third part of the question was: if not, why not?

—I have already given an answer that indicates that the Government and the community are extremely sceptical about the promises that Mr Peacock is making in the run-up to the election. The Hawke Government will continue to maintain its commitment to Australian families and to develop policies accordingly.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Before directing my question to the Minister I note and welcome the fact that the Government has made an additional 1,000 places available to private sector employees through its new work-based child-care program. Unfortunately, these places and the Government grants are available only to those employed in the private sector, thus public sector employees are being discriminated against. Is the Government going to implement a similar work-based child-care program for public sector employees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been asked another question on child-care. In the theatre of the absurd played out on the Opposition benches over the past few days we have had actors such as Peacock and Hewson being contradicted by Connolly, then corrected by Peacock, then contradicted by Braithwaite and now corrected by Peacock. Every day of the week the Opposition adopts a different position on child-care. Well, well. I am sure that we will have Mr Peacock correcting Senator Chaney's interjections today. Let me say in reply to Senator Powell that I am aware of the pressure that has been exerted by some unions for child-care facilities to be made available in Commonwealth offices.
—How do you get time to read the papers after you read your own speeches?
—I will not take that interjection. Senator Vanstone was relegated to the back bench by her Party and therefore to irrelevance.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. I ask the Minister to ignore them.

—Thank you, Mr President. I will. The Government's position on the provision of child-care services for the public sector has been stated on a number of occasions. The main emphasis of the children's services program is community based, work related care targeted to high need areas and accessible to low income families. I remind the Senate that public servants are members of the community and their child-care needs are taken into account in this process. The industry initiative is a small component of the children's services program, which is targeted to low income private sector employees. The Government has decided at this stage that the initiative will not be made available to public sector employees. Our principal concern is to improve access to child-care for the whole community through the national child-care strategy rather than putting funds towards services specifically for public servants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the question asked of me by Senator Haines on 17 October concerning the Symposium on the Participation of Women in the Political and Parliamentary and Decision-making Process. The conference is to be held under the auspices of the Inter-parliamentary Union (IPU) and was due to be held in Madrid in October 1989. The IPU is an association of parliamentarians. The Speaker is the Chairman of the Australian Parliamentary Group and therefore makes decisions in relation to the IPU.

ANSWER.PARA: In August, the Spanish IPU delegation announced that it was unable to house the conference and it was transferred to Geneva. Recently, Geneva contacted the IPU to see whether any parliamentarians could attend. Following consultation with the office of the Speaker, a cable went back to Geneva saying that there was no Australian parliamentary delegation going to the conference, but advice of the conference was circulated to all members of parliament, indicating that they could use their travel entitlements to attend the conference if they so wished.

Advice was provided to Parliament, following the eightieth conference in Sofia in September 1988, of the upcoming Madrid conference. This advice was conveyed to the Presiding Officers. They, through the Whips, conveyed advice of the conference to members of parliament. It was also discussed by the IPU Executive at the Executive meeting on 31 May.

I would like to take this opportunity to point out that Australia is sending an historic all-women delegation to the Commonwealth Meeting on Delegated Legislation in November. Senator Giles, Senator Bishop, Senator Crowley and Senator Patterson, accompanied by Ann Lynch, an officer of the Senate, will attend. I think this is a very welcome reflection of the increasing representation of women in this chamber, which currently stands at 22 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I should like to take note of a couple of points raised in the report of the Dairy Research Council. All pastoral industries, whether it be the dairy industry or farming generally, are subject at the moment to fantastically high input cost increases. This is something that many people do not comprehend. The consumer price index is running at 7 or 8 per cent and it may be higher by the end of the year. Farm input costs are running in excess of 10 per cent per annum. This is highlighted in the dairy industry as much as in any other industry. The dairy industry has been subject to some changes by this Government. It is a resilient industry. However, I fear the competition that will come from across the Tasman in years to come.

The report makes a point about research into aspects of pasture and other matters. Research is one area in which the Government stands condemned because it has cut back the research funds for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which has been a great help in all areas of Australian industry and, in particular, to the dairy industry and the other pastoral industries. The report notes the spread of exotic dung beetles throughout the dairying districts. Even though in my area in north-western New South Wales we are not involved in the dairying industry, the dung beetles there are doing an outstanding job in dissipating the cattle dung so that it can go back into the soil for the betterment of the pasture. I commend to the Senate the fourth annual report of the Dairy Research Council.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The first point I would like to make in my brief discourse on the annual report of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is that on the very first page the report says, `The corporation is a public authority with a private enterprise philosophy'. With the greatest of kindness to the FAC, if this is the practical application of a private enterprise philosophy, we had better find a new system by which to run our private enterprises because, if one statement can be made of the FAC, it is that it is simply not a commercially successful operation. One of its great problems stems from the fact that it simply does not understand how the aviation industry in Australia works.

It is interesting that the FAC reports a profit of $43.7m this year. As the report was distributed only this morning, I have not had time to go through it in detail, but I will do so and find out how the Corporation claims to have made its money. I must draw attention to the fact that it has charged the users of its airports $242.7m this year in fees and other levies.

The basic problem with the Federal Airports Corporation is that it does not understand how the aviation industry works and, as a consequence, taxes every user in every way for every service that it can possibly conceive. In so doing, it is driving business away from the airports that it owns. I am well aware that, for the two years for which we have had annual reports and from the times we have had the FAC before parliamentary committees, it has maintained that the users of its fields are increasing. That is simply not true of all of the fields of which I have had experience. There are some that have shown increases but the use of the great majority of fields, the secondary airports, is not what it was four or five years ago.

The FAC is labouring under the unrealistic belief that it can make every airport it owns profitable. The report before us today shows that the load of generating profit is being carried purely by Sydney and Melbourne, and the losses being generated by some of the secondary airports, shown by the FAC's accounting system, are quite staggering. For example, Essendon is estimated to be losing $3.7m a year; Bankstown, $4m a year; Moorabbin, $2 1/2m and Archerfield, $1.3m. They are quite big losses, but I have to qualify that by saying that the accounting systems used by the FAC are often quite strange and may bear no relevance to the true costs involved.

One of the difficulties under which the FAC is labouring is that the Government transferred the airfields to it at grossly inflated prices. All those airfields have been paid for by the Australian taxpayers. Once again, there was a bit of creative accounting by flash Harry, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in an attempt to get the airfields off budget and, at the same time, make a profit, so the Civil Aviation Authority and the FAC were created. The creation of two authorities where one existed before has led to gross duplication of management and resources associated with it, such as buildings at the airfields, and all these costs have been borne by a very small taxation base in Australia, because the aviation industry is quite small.

The thing that is really wrong with the FAC is that the Government, in getting it off budget, set it up as a statutory authority, legally answerable to no-one. In actual fact, it is at the end of a phone for the Minister of the day to ring up and propose things to it if he does not agree with what it is doing. But there is no-one to whom the FAC or, for that matter, the CAA is answerable. They are certainly not answerable to this Parliament. What is wrong with that is that the Government has created a monopoly and said to it, `You go and live off the aviation community for your income'. That is quite a different matter to setting up Qantas Airways Ltd, for example, where alternative air carriers are available. But if we want to use the primary airport for Brisbane, Melbourne or Sydney we have no-one to go to but the FAC, and if we do not like the way in which it is doing business we certainly cannot get Parliament to intervene on our behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) was covered by Estimates Committee B of which I am a member. I hold similar views to those which Senator Panizza expressed the other night at the Estimates hearings on the subject of the FAC. He remarked during those hearings that there seems to be a general dissatisfaction within the general aviation sector with the Federal Airports Corporation. Certainly, the early impression one had about the new Corporation was that it seemed to be engaged in a flurry of activity, erecting rather large and fancy signs at various airports. At the time those signs were going up I hoped the Corporation would be as efficient and enthusiastic in other areas of its responsibilities as it was in putting up its new logos.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate that there have been some difficulties in its stated objectives of making Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport runways as passenger efficient as possible. That is a matter I have spoken on quite often in this place, and on which I have presented many petitions. The FAC has had to contend with air traffic controllers disputes, the pilots dispute, increased air traffic generally and a shortage of runways at many airports. I know, from the Estimates hearing that one area in which the FAC has been pretty efficient is in charges imposed on airline operators, even to the extent of charging operators for hangar space when the plane in question was in a stripped-down condition and could not fly anyway. It seems that operators will be charged for planes whether they are in the air, on the runways or parked in the hangars. The FAC seems to have a public relations problem. There is a criticism that the FAC does not talk to the users of its facilities and, instead of operating in a commercial and professional manner, at times gives the same indications as an inefficient bureaucracy.

Turning specifically to the annual report which, incidentally, relates only to the year 1 April 1988 to 31 March 1989, I suggest that next year's report will tell an entirely different story because of events that are going on at the moment. I note that the year in question traded with an operating profit of $43.7m and declared a dividend of $12.8m. The Chairman, Mr Sullivan, claims that 1988 was an exceptional year. I would say that that is an understatement for what is going on at the moment. I wonder what words he will use to describe this year.

Only four airports were profitable last year: Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane and Coolangatta. I would be interested to learn what proposals there are for increasing profitability at other FAC-owned airports and what contingency plans there are for improving profitability this year, given the difficulty of the operating conditions which are now in place. I note that Bankstown Airport lost the most money last year, despite the fact that it had a record year of activity with nearly 400,000 movements. It is not clear whether this is the result of expenditure on the airport or other reasons. Again, it would have been very useful for us to know the reasons for that.

The Corporation has supported the Federal Government's announcement to proceed with the development of a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport. I say three cheers for that! Let us hope it eventuates. I wish I could be as confident in and as believing of the Government as the FAC is. It seems to me that while the Federal Government has been stalling and fiddling with the third runway, and flying all sorts of kites in the meantime, the FAC has been going hell for leather acquiring land at Badgerys Creek and surprise, surprise, will announce that the second airport could be built quicker than a third runway. All this will be done to protect the marginal seats around Kingsford-Smith Airport. It will be a totally wasted exercise because we will win the next election and build the third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport. The FAC has had a stormy short history and I do not predict it will improve in the short term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the annual report of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), I draw the attention of the Senate to that section of it which deals with security, particularly that at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The Federal Airports Corporation has many questions to answer on this score. I hope it is frank and fulsome in its explanations which are due to this chamber because of the disgracefully misleading and deceptive press report put out by the Corporation following the release last month of an Auditor-General's report on the security at Sydney Airport. The annual report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Corporation has worked closely with the Department of Transport and Communications, the airlines and other organisations to ensure the security of its airports.
A review was undertaken at each airport and security has been improved with the establishment and training of some 200 security staff.
The Corporation engaged a full-time security consultant to establish procedures, prepare security manuals, train staff and monitor security performance.
The Corporation is represented on the Aviation Safety Advisory Committee which provides policy advice to the Minister.

However, the Auditor-General demonstrated the appalling lack of security at Sydney Airport-during which members of the Auditor-General's staff were able to gain access to the tarmac area without any identification or authorisation-and that report, which came out last month, was responded to by the FAC-with a press statement which said, `Yes, we were aware of some security problems but we fixed them up back in April'. If, in fact, the FAC was aware of some security matters which were fixed up back in April, how quaint that this report does not dwell on the seriousness of those matters which were allegedly fixed. Let us recognise that that press statement was false, and deliberately false, which no doubt amuses the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button).

TALK.START.PARA: —You told us all this at the Estimates Committee.

—Unfortunately only Senator Button was present at the Estimates Committee. The rest of the Parliament is unaware of the extent to which the Federal Airports Corporation sought to mislead the people of Australia in a press release claiming that the matters referred to by the Auditor-General had been corrected. That was false.
—I told everybody how good you were at the Estimates Committee.

—I thank the Minister for that acknowledgment. But that statement was false, and apparently deliberately so. The matters referred to in the Auditor-General's report, despite the claim by the Federal Airports Corporation, were not matters that had been dealt with in April. They were matters that were brought forward in June and July by the Australian Customs Service at various meetings and are to be the subject of discussions this week because the Australian Customs Service has advised us that it is very concerned about these elements and this lack of security that the Australian Customs Service pointed out to the Auditor-General. Meetings will be held this week with the Department of Transport and Communications. I hope those meetings deal fully and properly with a matter that the Federal Airports Corporation has sought to sweep under the carpet. I believe the FAC should be required to withdraw and correct its misleading press release. The matters have not been resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone reading the report who is concerned about the prospect or the possibility of terrorism at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, who recognises that we are a major international air travelling area vulnerable to the potential of terrorist activity, would have every right to be deeply concerned about the lack of action, the lack of competence and the lack of honesty by the Federal Airports Corporation in dealing with this matter. I hope that the FAC, perhaps as a result of this speech dealing with its annual report, will at last come clean on how bad security is at Sydney Airport and will respond properly to the concerns of the Auditor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I have not brought these reports with me but I have scanned them. The reports give honourable senators a wonderful tour de force of the enormous range of activities undertaken by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). I noted in the reports that there has been a change in policy direction for the use of funds in that research has been directed away from basic research into applied research and the funds spent on research are to be immediately and measurably productive. In other words, the research has to have some economic application forthwith. In itself that is not all bad as a policy change particularly when we have a Government that has run itself and the country out of money and the NHMRC wants money as quickly as it can get it. But it is a very short-sighted policy.

I noted particularly that the research funds for AIDS have been doubled and yet the research funds for our eight centres of excellence have come to the end of their time and their funds are to be cut and they are to be brought to a dead stop. Mr Acting Deputy President, you might remember that those eight centres were created nine years ago under the Fraser Government. They were funded under three triennia and they have been world leaders in their fields. Curiously, not only have the centres been able to come up with products that are saleable in several instances but they have also been able to provide teaching and demonstrations for the world scientific community. It will be a pity to see them go because they are so specialised in their fields that if they are to be thrown into the open market and have to apply for funding with the ordinary everyday run of scientific organisations, they are competing in the wrong race. They will have to find fields in which they can operate. It seems to me to be very unfair to be doubling the funding for research for a disease like AIDS when the funding is being cut out altogether for these centres of excellence.

Another thing I noted was that we have an enormous number of diseases that are now covered by immunisation and vaccination: measles, mumps, whooping cough, diphtheria, tetanus, et cetera. The Council has recommended that Australians carry an immunisation card with them. Not only do very few people have the card but the take-up of people who have been immunised has been very small. I was quite surprised by the number of people who are not immunised in Australia today. That is not a good thing because as the population's immunity falls we become liable to suffer from an epidemic-even a pandemic-of these diseases which were so devastating in the past and indeed at times have had the Angel of Death's wings flapping in the country. I hope people take note of that.

I am sure that honourable senators will not be able to read all three of these reports but if they pick the eyes out of them there are enormous areas of interest, one of which deals with the ethics of gene therapy. The Opposition has taken a big interest in that matter. A Senate committee has inquired into human embryo experimentation. This is really an extension of what has gone on since then. I recommend that honourable senators pick the eyes out of these reports and read the matters of interest to them. I particularly draw attention to the lack of immunity status of our nation and our inability to get immunity cards for ourselves.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report from the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on manufacturing industry revitalisation was a unanimous report. It was submitted to the Senate earlier this year. I note with some degree of satisfaction that the Government response to the recommendations in the report, contained in the paper I am speaking to at the moment, have received general acceptance from Government. It would have been hoped that the report would have received general acceptance from the chamber and from all political parties in Australia. Unfortunately, that does not seem to be the case. For example, in the Australian Financial Review yesterday I noted in a column by Peter Roberts that one of the Opposition spokesman accused the Government that its drive to plough resources into speculative high-tech areas has proved a disaster.

Some of the major features which our Committee submitted to the Parliament put a very high degree of emphasis on the development of high technology and getting the work force and management of Australian industry to accept that there is a need to get into high technology if the manufacturing industry in Australia is to be revitalised or is to survive. Unfortunately, it would seem that the Opposition parties collectively are hell-bent on turning things around and destroying the manufacturing industry in Australia. I support the contention I have just made by referring to the economic policies which were announced by the present Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Peacock, some two weeks ago, the Economic Action Plan. Page 17 of the economic and tax policy plan states:

Decades of protection have discouraged firms from investing in new technologies, and fostering non-market competition, leaving Australia lagging behind comparable overseas countries in terms of technology use and research and development.

On the one hand, the Opposition wants us to get into high technology but on the other hand individual Opposition spokespersons say that really we should get back to the mines and the farms. One does not know who to believe. In regard to the `decades of protection', the Opposition parties were in government for 30 out of the last 40 years. So the comment is a condemnation by its own hand of what the Opposition sought to do to Australia's industry over that time. It is only because of the good work of the present Government, under the leadership of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, that our manufacturing industry is now venturing on to the world stage in terms.

Let us examine further the Opposition's plans announced two weeks ago. A major facet of the Government's action plan to bring Australian industry on to the world stage has been the very useful facility of Austrade. The Opposition parties would slash funding to that body by some $20m. They would slash research and development funding under the grants for industry research and development scheme and the National Industry Extension Service (NIES) by an estimated $50m if they should come to office. I do not think the NIES scheme is perfect. One of the problems with it is that it is fractured through the States. Each State competes with the others. This would be further exacerbated by the Opposition parties should they ever come to government as they would hand NIES over to the States and ask the States to fund it. Whilst NIES may not be perfect at the moment, one can be sure that, if its total control were ever handed over directly to the States, what achievements have been made to date would rapidly move backwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that I presented a minority report to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry Science and Technology entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it Together, which the Government does not seem to have commented upon. That is a pity, because I pointed out that there was a need to hold up an alternative economic model to what the Government was doing. As an example of that, I drew attention to the so-called Button car plan. I note that the most fuel efficient car which Mitsubishi currently makes, the Mitsubishi Colt, will probably go out of production because an insufficient number of cars of that model are sold, whereas the large gas guzzlers will continue to be manufactured at a time when the Government seems to be committed to cutting fuel consumption, CO2 and other greenhouse emissions by 20 to 40 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The other comment I make relates to the Government's non-acceptance of the Committee's principal recommendation of imposing strict monitoring on foreign investment to ensure that it complies with stringent conditions relating to research and development skill levels and export. The Government says that this would be counterproductive and that the benefits of foreign investment may be indirect, that there may be a benefit in terms of the balance of payments and so on. It is quite clear that the Government has no idea whatsoever of exactly where foreign investment is going in this country. Against a specific recommendation it has come up with a lot of airy fairy hogwash. It is a great pity that the Government, in the absence of any clear evidence to the contrary, has seen fit not to accept this very sensible recommendation of the Committee. We desperately need to know what foreign investment is coming into Australia and precisely where that foreign investment is going so we can attempt to direct it into those areas which are going to be most productive and most useful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of Government papers is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the report of the Committee entitled, Report on a visit by the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the New Zealand House of Representatives, together with the minutes of proceedings. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Australian and New Zealand parliamentarians have participated in annual official delegations during the past 10 years, under the Fraser-Talboys Agreement. The purpose of the delegations was general fact-finding, aimed at increasing the general knowledge of parliamentarians about a near neighbour. In 1988 the then New Zealand Prime Minister, Mr Lange, held discussions with the Presiding Officers in Australia on the possibility of joint meetings between Australian and New Zealand parliamentary committees. After further discussions it was decided to institute joint meetings in place of the regular delegations, for a two-year experimental period. The first meetings under the new system were to be between the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the New Zealand House of Representatives.

The visit which is the subject of this report was to Canberra in August 1989. It was an exchange for one made by members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to New Zealand in April of this year. It completed the first round of visits under the two-year experiment. The central activity under the experimental system is the joint meeting between committees of the New Zealand and Australian Parliaments which share similar interests and responsibilities. It was fortunate that the first series of visits was between committees which have so many common preoccupations. Discussion ranged across issues which are relevant to this Parliament and Government, as well as to the two committees involved: issues such as the South Pacific; defence; immigration and the environment. Two of the recommendations made by the joint meeting addressed the protection of Antarctica and protection from drift-net fishing.

The New Zealand and Australian Committees involved in this first series of joint meetings agreed that the new system is a great improvement on the exchange of general delegations. It may be that the subject matter which concerns our two committees had a great part to play in the success of the two visits. Indeed the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommended that joint meetings with its New Zealand counterpart be held on a regular basis. If this were to happen it would have to be in addition to the current two-year experiment of replacing general parliamentary delegations with committee exchanges.

I would like to make a few personal comments about some of the major matters dealt with in the report. As my introductory remarks say, we were fortunate that both the joint foreign affairs and defence committees were dealing with issues that there was considerable preoccupation with in both countries, no doubt the major one being the defence arrangements between both countries and, in particular, the standing of the Anzac frigate project. In our meeting in April this year in New Zealand and again in August there was considerable discussion of a controversial nature between both countries and between the members of both committees of each country about the nature of that project.

Since the Committee had its meeting in August, the New Zealand Government has decided to proceed with participation in the Anzac frigate program. I am delighted with that decision. I believe that whatever the controversial nature of the program, particularly in New Zealand, in the long run it will mean that the defence arrangements between our countries will become closer. It will in no way affect the sovereignty of either country. It will mean that we can have a more cooperative, more efficient and more common interest in regard to defence arrangements in the region of immediate concern to both countries, that is, the South Pacific.

Though there was considerable criticism in New Zealand about participating in the Anzac frigate program, I think even the critics in New Zealand, in particular, agreed that both Australia and New Zealand have a responsibility in terms of our relations with countries in the South Pacific. The other day the Deputy Prime Minister of the Cook Islands made it quite clear informally at a meeting of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that he was quite supportive of the Anzac frigate program. He saw this joint venture between Australia and New Zealand as being in the interests of the Cook Islands and indicated that he had made his views known in New Zealand. I am aware that these comments were made at a private meeting of the Committee. But it was quite clear that he had made his views known publicly, so I do not think I am breaking any confidences in mentioning what he said.

The Committee's report also deals with the question of the Antarctic Treaty and the protection of Antarctica. I think all members from both committees took the unanimous view that we want to protect the fragile environment of Antarctica. There is, of course, a difference of opinion between the two countries. The Australian Government has made it clear that we will not sign the so-called mining convention of Antarctica whereas, at a meeting in August, New Zealand was quite supportive of that convention being signed. However, there have been developments since then and I detect that we may be moving towards a position where both countries will be closer to reaching an agreement about the establishment of a world wilderness park in Antarctica. I think Australia and New Zealand have a special responsibility in leading the world debate on that issue.

Drift netting is an issue which, I suspect, is not of great interest to many Australians. But it is of extraordinary interest in the South Pacific. The Committee supported all moves by both countries in the South Pacific Forum to oppose drift netting because of the enormous impact it is having on fish stocks and the long term commercial viability of the fishing industries of the South Pacific countries. Hopefully, over the next year or so, Australia, in combination with New Zealand, can convince countries such as Japan and Taiwan to desist from using drift netting in the South Pacific. Although the report does not make a recommendation on the so-called Hawke initiative for the development of an economic forum for the Asia-Pacific region, the report does mention it. Despite our various partisan differences on other issues, there seemed to be general agreement that this initiative was worth while and should be further explored.

The final point I wish to comment on is the question of future meetings. Although the report says that the visit was an experiment in holding joint meetings across the Tasman, I think all of us who participated, and particularly those who participated in New Zealand and Australia, found the meetings extremely valuable. Therefore, we recommend that irrespective of any other joint meetings between parliamentary committees, because of the particular and special nature of the expertise in the joint foreign affairs committees of both parliaments, we should have a regular exchange at least once every two years. I certainly would encourage the governments and the Presiding Officers of both countries to accept that recommendation and to make sure that funds are made available.

I am reminded of one of the discussions we had in New Zealand with Russell Marshall, the Foreign Minister of New Zealand, who said that when he became a Minister the first time he visited Great Britain three times before he made his first visit to Australia. That is an extraordinary commentary on how often in the past relations between both countries have been on the back-burner, so to speak. Though we have been the closest of neighbours, we have seen our interests as being elsewhere and have acted accordingly.

I believe that the meetings of the foreign affairs committees of both parliaments are an excellent step. I would also encourage the appropriate committees in both parliaments which deal with other matters to arrange joint meetings from time to time. Rather than the parliaments sending general delegations, I think the members of both parliaments who have a particular interest by being involved in particular committees will get a lot more out of these visits if they can meet on that basis. So I certainly support very strongly the recommendation that the Australian Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee continue to meet with the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the New Zealand Parliament at least once every two years. I commend the report to the Senate. Obviously my colleagues will address some of the substantive issues in the report. I also commend the notion of joint meetings between Australian and New Zealand parliamentary committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, endorse the concept of regular meetings being held between the two joint foreign affairs committees of Australia and New Zealand. I think it is very important to establish and maintain very close links with our nearest neighbour across the Tasman. I certainly support the statement that we should work towards a joint position on Antarctica, to conserve it as a wilderness area free from the threat of mining. I think it is very important that Australia and New Zealand work on that together. I also endorse the joint activities to ban drift net fishing. I endorse the remarks of Senator Schacht on both those points.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some rather critical comments about the nature of the discussions that took place between the two committees. It was my observation in participating in these discussions that we treat the New Zealanders somewhat like cousins and, of course, many of us are literally cousins. We have a very close cultural identity with our neighbours across the Tasman. There were often elements of teasing, cajoling and even denigration in the discussions. I felt on many occasions that the New Zealand delegation was not really taken seriously. Although we want relations to be friendly between the two countries, I do not think the Australian members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, particularly in cases where differences emerged, were prepared to take the differing views of their New Zealand colleagues seriously. This was especially so in respect of the New Zealanders' attitude towards the frigates which, as Senator Schacht said, have dominated the two meetings which have taken place between the two committees.

Members of the Australian Committee found it almost impossible to understand that New Zealanders think differently about their peacekeeping role in the region. Members of the Australian Committee found it almost impossible to accept that the New Zealand peace movement ran a very effective anti-frigate campaign. Over 70 per cent of New Zealanders opposed the purchase of these frigates on economic and social grounds, and they had very good reasons for doing so. Members of our Committee found it almost impossible to accept the New Zealand perception that Australia was bullying it into buying the frigates. This was very clear from the attitudes of some members of the New Zealand delegation.

When the views of the peace movement were put in formal discussions as well as before the Australian Committee, it was very obvious that members of the Australian Committee could hardly believe that this perception of bullying was really serious. But it was very serious. Minister after Minister in the New Zealand Government changed his mind-and they were all men-on this issue. A year ago the frigates deal was unanimously opposed at the Labour Party Conference in New Zealand. Within six months, people who had not protested at that conference had all changed their minds. They had been regularly visited by their Australian counterparts. So that perception of bullying was very lively in the New Zealand community. But the Australians found it very difficult to accept that that was the case. Probably since the visit, members of the Australian Committee would find it impossible to understand the New Zealand Labour Party's policy review committee's finding that Australia's regional policing role in the South East Asia and south-west Pacific regions is seen as being destabilising and worrying to our trans-Tasman neighbours. Of course, our Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has had to come in and defend his position. The report to which I am referring was written by Chris Tremewan, who co-chaired this Labour Party review committee with Miss Katie Boanas; and they had a lot of support within the New Zealand Labour Party for the views that they put to the recent Labour Party Conference. It was as though our Committee just did not want to hear all that.

The messages from the New Zealand Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence were not taken seriously. As I said earlier, the New Zealand Committee was not actually unanimous. I believe that we need to respect the differences that exist between the two countries rather than denigrating our Tasman neighbours because they do not happen to agree with us. It is very important that we see New Zealanders as our close neighbours. When there are fellow Labor parties, it strikes me as being very odd that Australia chooses to side with a very conservative administration on the other side of the world rather than with a fellow Labor government across the Tasman. I refer here particularly to the debate on the differences that have emerged between the United States and New Zealand on the question of nuclear warship visits. Far from just staying out of the argument, which would have been the proper thing to do, Australia went in to bat on behalf of the Americans against our New Zealand neighbours.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong.

—That is not wrong. There was a letter written by our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the then Prime Minister of New Zealand, David Lange, and it was very clear that the Australian Government went in to bat for the Americans and made it more difficult, I believe, for the New Zealanders.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to some of the paragraphs in the report. Paragraph 2.16 states:
It was suggested that New Zealand had an obligation to share the defence task of securing the Pacific area as part of the Western strategic alliance.

I do not think that the New Zealanders have shied from that responsibility. New Zealand has always done its share. We have fought in many battles with New Zealanders on foreign soils to protect the Western alliance. They are now seeing things a little differently perhaps in terms of the nuclear question, and I applaud them for that. The Australian view seems to be that, if New Zealand did not buy into the Anzac frigate projects, it was not pulling its weight. Pulling its weight, in terms of the Western alliance in the Pacific, should not have been equated with purchasing these particular frigates. That was a real red herring in the issue and I really resent the fact that New Zealand people and politicians and members of this Committee felt that New Zealand was criticised for not pulling its weight because there was some question at that stage about whether it would buy these frigates or not. We need to question the Western strategic alliance, which we are meant to be upholding. I do not support the view that we should be hosting any nuclear facilities in support of the Western strategic alliance.

The New Zealanders have often said that they were not trying to get out of ANZUS, that it was the Americans who pulled the rug from underneath them, and that the Americans refused to meet with them after they refused to host the visits of nuclear warships to their ports. It was quite within their democratic right to make that decision. The ANZUS Treaty does not commit countries, even Australia, to hosting the visits of such ships. So New Zealand was quite within its rights to refuse. Paragraph 2.21 states:
A Government member of the Australian Committee gave it as his opinion that a majority of people in Australia appreciated New Zealand's stance on defence issues, but this was hotly disputed.

I want it on record that I am one of those people who support New Zealand's stance on defence issues, particularly in relation to the nuclear question, which I have already mentioned. Paragraph 2.32 states:

There were misconceptions about the connection between anti-nuclear sentiments and anti-Americanism. Most New Zealand members felt that there was not a widespread anti-American sentiment in their country; on the contrary, New Zealanders felt warmly towards America.

I would go so far as to say that the same could be applied to the Australian situation. The peace movement in Australia is opposed to things nuclear, not any particular country. The anti-nuclear movement in this country has lobbied very strongly against French testing, Soviet testing and United States testing of nuclear weapons in the Pacific. I think that that misconception should also have been included. We are saying that we are opposed to the nuclear machinery which threatens us all and not that we are opposed to a particular country which is a proponent of that model. Unfortunately, from the Australian point of view, it is the American presence that we see here more often than any other and American bases are on Australian soil, and we must oppose them because they drag us into the nuclear network. It is also very important to notice that public opinion in Australia is very firmly becoming more anti-nuclear. Another point referred to in the report was the strength of the New Zealand peace movement, which I think was generally regarded as being stronger than the peace movement in Australia. That is referred to in paragraph 2.20.

I remind the Senate that only 30 per cent of Australians support visits by nuclear-powered warships and only 26 per cent support visits by nuclear-armed warships. They are very small percentages of support. So much for the critics who keep trying to paint the anti-nuclear group as a minority: we are in the vast majority on that question. Support for the ANZUS alliance has dropped to 65 per cent, while support for the United States bases is only 39 per cent; so we are hardly a minority. I am quoting from the September polling of Frank Small and Associates. I seek leave to table five pages of the documents from Frank Small and Associates giving those figures.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Paragraph 2.34 states:

SPEECH.PARA: As the international political environment continued to improve the unfortunate nexus between the US alliance and nuclear issues might decrease.

It is unfortunate that there is such a connection, but it is a very real connection. I think it is rather amazing that it was put into the report in quite those terms, because we can hardly deny the connection. The nexus between the United States alliance and nuclear issues is absolute because of the bases in Australia and because of the visits by American nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered warships. But that is not the only nuclear connection that we would rather see the Pacific area free from.

In conclusion, I emphasise the need for a close relationship with our nearest neighbours which needs to be based on mutual respect. I hope to see more of that mutual respect in evidence in future meetings of the joint committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to say a few words on the report on a visit by the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the New Zealand House of Representatives. There is a temptation to let it pass because it refers to a relationship that is perhaps too often taken for granted, that between Australia and New Zealand, which temptation arises out of the proximity and familiarity of that relationship. Events of recent times would demonstrate to us that it should not be taken for granted; in fact, it is a relationship that needs to be worked upon and to be improved to ensure that there is better and more effective communication between us. That really seems to me to be the effect of the report of the visit of this delegation, which of course was preceded by a parliamentary delegation from Australia to New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the continuation of parliamentary delegations not only of this nature, dealing with foreign affairs and trade issues by virtue of our foreign affairs and trade committees, but also of other specialist committees of the Parliament. I am sure that with a continuing and ongoing program of delegation visits, rather than the ad hoc visits that have taken place in the past, there can be better understanding between our two nations.

There are really three heads under which I wish to make a few comments about the relationship. The first is defence, on which there has just been some debate. The second is the economic relationship, which is critically important to Australia and perhaps even more critically important to New Zealand. The third is the regional responsibility which we both share and ways in which we can both contribute to regional stability and prosperity.

The defence relationship, I guess, has been that most stressed in recent times, particularly because of New Zealand's decision to depart from what we see as a critical part of the ANZUS pact; that is, preparedness to accommodate visiting naval vessels. The point I specifically wanted to make was that, despite that difference of policy, there has remained a particularly good and cooperative relationship at what I might describe as the officials level. We see it in many ways-in our defence forces-in reciprocal exercises, training commitments, and common standard operation procedures. We see it at regular meetings at high levels within our defence forces-annual meetings of the Australia-New Zealand Defence Consultative Committee, the Australia-New Zealand Defence Policy Group, the Defence Supply Working Group, and others.

Only yesterday I had one further demonstration of just how special that relationship is in contemporary terms, perhaps adopting something of historical significance. I learnt that New Zealand Defence Force members are operating within the Australian observer force in Namibia, wearing New Zealand uniforms, and that special exemptions had to be obtained through United Nations mechanisms for this to occur. I think it demonstrates the depth and historical importance of the relationship and brings home to us the importance of our not allowing it to be taken for granted but playing our small part in working on it and overcoming any contemporary difficulties. Certainly, upon coming to government we will urge a change of defence policy by New Zealand. We trust that we would be more successful than this Government has been; nevertheless, the underlying relationship will remain important to us and be recognised as such.

The second area I said I would mention is that of economic relations and, in particular, the closer economic relations (CER). In that area we can see an incredible achievement in a relatively short period. Mr Acting Deputy President, I remind you that that process started with a coalition government. I take you back to March 1978 to the declaration known as the Nareen declaration, which followed a meeting between former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser and the then Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand, Brian Talboys. That was the start of the CER process and it has proceeded at a pace that I think would have surprised those who were involved in its original conception. It is fair to say that CER is now a reality and free trade nearly a reality. That is good to note, and I think it is related in some way to the fact that trade has significantly and substantially increased between Australia and New Zealand during the period of CER. In 1985-86 the total trade figure was just under $3 billion and it is now nearly $4.2 billion-a very significant increase. The benefits are obviously financial, but they go further as we look to the harmonisation of labour markets, business laws and regulations. All of this will bring our two countries closer together psychologically and reinforce this long and important relationship.

The third area I said I would mention is our mutual responsibility-or what we on this side of the chamber certainly see as a mutual responsibility-to work to overcome difficulties which are apparent within the South Pacific region at the moment and difficulties which may well occur in the future. One need only briefly think of the problems of Fiji, the problems Papua New Guinea is experiencing, the problems of Vanuatu and the problems New Caledonia has been through and which, I assure the Senate, it still faces. One sees a particular responsibility for Australia and New Zealand, as the two developed industrial nations of the region, to help these small Pacific states, often very economically dependent, through their problems. That will be not only for their benefit but also for our mutual benefit.

I commend the Committee on its work. I commend to the Senate its recommendation that these visits should continue on a regular basis in order that our communications and understanding of each other can improve. I take this opportunity to recognise those in the chamber-on my side, Senator Chaney and Senator Archer, who has just come into the chamber-who have taken a particular interest in the Australia-New Zealand relationship and have been prepared to work on that relationship for the benefit of all within this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to commend the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on its report entitled Report on a Visit by the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of the New Zealand House of Representatives. As Senator Hill has said, I have had a long involvement and interest in the New Zealand question. Fundamentally, it comes down to the fact that what we have is a fact: it is there and it is working. What we need to do now is to make sure that it works as well as it can. Visits such as this make that even more possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, when I was on a visit to New Zealand, we were discussing the defence question and, of course, we were asked about the frigates and whether we thought New Zealand ought to participate. My response then has not changed in the last 12 months. I said, `Yes, I do, if you want them'. I do not think there has been any pressure or any imposition on New Zealand, as has been implied by certain people subsequently. I would not want to think that New Zealand had bought the frigates out of any question of obligation or duty. My view is that, if New Zealand wants them, it should buy them; if it does not want them, it should not. I believe that that is a decision that the Government should make in its own quiet time, considering all the elements that are involved.

We do have a regional responsibility. It was only when I was talking to delegates from the various island states at the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference over the last week or two that I realised how much they depend on us for a whole variety of things. Australia and New Zealand together have to look at matters of education, training, police, quarantine and a whole lot of things that they need us to provide the people of those states to look after in their own way.

We must go forward with this. We have to eliminate the little problems that may appear from time to time and we have to work out a program on how to share the future. I immediately come back to things such as research. I think it is quite useless for us to be researching the same things the New Zealanders are researching. I believe that we should cooperate far more in these areas and find ways in which we can get the best value for our dollar. I am looking for much greater education and business interchange. I do not think we are doing nearly enough about those areas yet. We have already started looking at the question of business and how to go about getting business legislation on a similar basis so that we can do business more easily with one another.

There is no doubt that to date New Zealand has played its part in this agreement better than we have, and I give it great credit for that. I could see right from the start that it was likely to, and the further it has gone the more that has become apparent. New Zealand has also used this agreement to bring about the considerable economic restructuring and change that has gone on there in the last year or two. It has learnt this and, as a result, has gone way past Australia. It does not have an 8 per cent inflation rate at the moment, it is not paying 19 or 20 per cent bank housing interest rates, and it is not tied to the same economic constrictions that we are because it has been through the situation.
