It saw it coming and made the changes. We have to learn from New Zealand just as it has to learn from us. We can learn from one another in various ways, but we have to get greater cooperation in manufacturing and in commerce generally. We have to decide who will do various things and which one of us can do things better than the other. We have to cooperate so that we do not duplicate things and fight with one another on the markets. Cooperation in marketing, particularly with our primary produce, is changing. There have been times when we have gone out and competed with one another and beaten the price down to the absolute minimum to the advantage of the purchasers, not the producers. We have to look at those things as we proceed.

As Senator Hill was saying, the increase in trade to $4.2 billion is very significant and we need to build on that even more. We have to be one another's best customers in so many areas. When we are not one another's customers, we have to go out and do the best we can to cooperate in the field. I commend the report. I would like to see these parliamentary tours increased. I would like to see the relationship between us and members of the New Zealand Parliament improve and I believe that if we all work on it we can do that. Nothing is more important in this zone than for us to get on with New Zealand to the best possible extent. I thank the Committee for the work it has done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: )-by leave-On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I table a summary of its report on Drugs, Crime and Society entitled Rethinking drug policy. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In May this year the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority presented to the Parliament a report entitled Drugs, Crime and Society. The report dealt with the trade in illegal drugs in Australia and the strategies used by law enforcement agencies to combat that trade. It outlined the social costs of the present policy of prohibition and examined alternative ways to reduce the harm caused by the abuse of illegal drugs. The Committee found that there was ample evidence that the policy of prohibition was failing to achieve its objectives. It was failing to prevent the supplies of illegal drugs from reaching those who wished to use them. Illegal drugs were available throughout Australia for anyone who wanted them. Prohibition simply made the price of the drugs higher than it would otherwise be.

The Committee noted that for many years governments had attempted to use the criminal law as a means of reducing supply to the market-place. The report clearly demonstrated that such an approach had limitations. To the extent that its stated aim was to prevent illicit drugs from reaching the market-place, it had demonstrably failed. The Committee argued that, if the present policy was not working, it was time to give serious consideration to alternative policies however radical they may seem. Although the present policy of prohibition gave the appearance of tough controls on illegal drugs, in reality there was an absence of government control over the chemistry of the drugs being sold, the outlets where drugs were being sold and the persons to whom the drugs might be sold. This may not have mattered so much if the policy had been succeeding in its original aim; in other words, if none of the illegal drugs were being sold or if there was even a realistic possibility that the trade was being brought to a halt. This was not the case and the Committee argued that it was time to consider alternatives to the present policy. It recommended that the Federal and State governments and the community at large should give earnest consideration to the options by which government might impose more control on the sale and marketing of the presently illegal drugs.

The Committee expressed the hope that its report would be a vehicle for public education. However, it recognised that its call for a debate within the community on drug policy would be mere empty rhetoric if it did not take some more steps to facilitate that debate. To that end it has prepared this summary of its report under the title Rethinking drug policy which I have tabled for the information of honourable senators today. Besides tabling it in the Federal Parliament, the Committee intends to send copies of the summary to members of the State and Territory parliaments. It also intends to send a copy to every secondary school in Australia and to persons running relevant courses at tertiary institutions. The summary has been prepared in a format that will enable it to be copied for study purposes and the Committee hopes that this will occur. The Committee also hopes that by disseminating the summary it will stimulate further interest in its original report.

The Committee recognised in its report that, before any change was made to the present policy of prohibition, there was a need for the Australian community to gain a better understanding of the properties of the prohibited drugs and of the costs imposed on the community by the present policy. It is hoped that the information contained in this summary and in the Committee's main report will assist in this process. The summary attempts to set out some of the facts about drug use and examines the strategies adopted by law enforcement agencies in attacking the illegal drug trade and explains why the Committee believes that those agencies cannot stop the trade. The summary outlines the social costs of the present policy of prohibition, including the cost of drug related crime and the threat that acquired immune deficiency syndrome might spread through the intravenous drug-using population.

Finally, the summary attempts to provide a concise account of some of the alternatives to the present policy of prohibition. Although most countries are signatories to international conventions which require them to prohibit the trade in cannabis, cocaine, heroin and amphetamines except for medical or scientific purposes, there are significant variations in their approaches. With accurate information it is therefore possible to make sensible comparisons between different policies based on the experience of those countries which have tried them. Unfortunately, such information is not always readily available. The Committee's summary will assist in making some of this information more widely available and its report provides more detail and appropriate references.

For example, a number of countries impose the death penalty for trafficking offences but it is quite clear that this policy has proved ineffective in stamping out the drug trade in those countries. The Netherlands permits the sale of limited quantities of cannabis in cafes and youth centres while retaining heavy penalties for trafficking. Cannabis use in that country has been low and has remained so. Until 1968 the United Kingdom allowed doctors to make available on prescription heroin and cocaine to addicts. The system broke down once addicts began to seek drugs for recreational use. They were receiving massive doses for their own use and were reselling part of what they received, thus feeding a growing black market. The British Government therefore acted in 1968 to restrict the power of doctors to prescribe. Rather than prescribing addicts with the maintenance doses of heroin the British clinics now generally provide only methadone, as in this country.

The provision of methadone is seen as one form of treatment to assist addicts to stop using heroin. It is no longer considered possible to undercut the black market for heroin by competitive prescribing. A policy of prohibition has applied to heroin, cocaine and cannabis in Australia since the 1920s. For over 40 years it must seem that this policy was a resounding success. The single convention on narcotic drugs signed in 1961 and ratified by Australia in 1967 was meant to set the seal on this success. Instead it ushered in an area in which the consumption of prohibited drugs has increased beyond the most alarmist predictions.

The Committee's point is simple: if the policy is so obviously failing, it is time to consider alternatives. There are no easy solutions in this area. The Committee hopes that by bringing down its report, and now this summary, it will enable a more informed debate to take place in this community on drug policy. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION FUND INVESTMENT TRUST PROPERTY FUND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to refer briefly to the annual report of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust Property Fund because I have been concerned about the manner in which Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT) has operated in the past in terms of its reporting to the Parliament. I am now concerned about the creation of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust Property Fund, which is aimed at broadening the potential scope for investment in this Trust beyond Public Service superannuation funding. This is now only 97.75 per cent owned by the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and there is a 2 1/2 per cent external interest which, it is intended, should be broadened by the selling of units to the private sector.

The annual report shows that in its six months of operation the new Fund has returned 7.63 per cent before tax, which the report describes as `pleasing when assessed against a background of recent high interest rates and tapering property values following three years of exceptional growth prior to 1989'. If it has been faced with tapering property values, I wonder why on earth and for what purpose the property values have been revalued up in this annual report by $94m within six months of this Fund acquiring the properties from the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. I find this a most extraordinary document, unless the purpose of some of the curious transactions that seem to have taken place has been to try to engineer a good earnings record to make it easier to sell units in this Property Fund by undervaluing the sale of the properties from SFIT to the Fund and then revaluing them and making appropriate sales by transferring the benefits from the SFIT to the Fund. To the extent that there is a slight loss of value to members of the SFIT, that is, the public servants whose superannuation is being used, and to the extent that there is a slight difference between the ownership of the SFIT and this Property Fund, then of course there are some problems involved.

I am also concerned about the fact that the one major transaction that involved a profit was apparently needed to take place in order to offset some sales that took place at a loss or the writing down of some debenture loans. I do not know why there should be such a loss on debenture loans in Kern Property Trust (KPT). That this loss of something like $12m on debenture loans should have taken place, offset by various other actions but apparently requiring the sale of Northern Securities House at a profit of $6m in order to break even, quite frankly bemuses me. Why was Northern Securities House sold? Was it simply to avoid the appearance of a loss from other investments which apparently have not done brilliantly well? Partly offsetting the debenture loan loss of $12m on KPT was a $6m profit on Kern Corporation Ltd property trust sales.

The most intriguing thing is how so many of these properties managed to get revalued up within six months, because the Fund was constituted on 19 December 1988 and began operations on only 1 January 1989. This report is for the six months to June 1989, yet we have had these huge revaluations, including one, the Wintergarden, in one day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the section of the report which deals with the change in the treatment of mortgage interest rates in the consumer price index (CPI), which has brought about a significant reduction in the apparent inflation rate in Australia. I say `apparent inflation rate'--
—Another Keating rort.

—It is certainly another interesting change. That would be a polite way of describing it. It is a change brought about in the method of assessing inflation despite the advice of the Australian Statistics Advisory Council. The annual report of that Council outlines its concerns. There is no doubt that the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) was worried that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the credibility of the CPI as a measure of inflation could well be called into question if it departed by too wide a margin from other ABS measures of the inflation rate when it was using an approach for the treatment of mortgage interest which was conceptually less thorough than an available alternative.
The Council, however, had a lengthy look at this matter and its:

. . . members expressed concern at the prospect of changing the measurement method of mortgage interest charges between the major five to six yearly reviews. While accepting the technical arguments for making the change, they pointed out that to do so in mid-stream, so soon after public criticism by Government leaders-
particularly Mr Keating, I interpose, who bullied the Australian Bureau of Statistics into changing the method of calculating the inflation rate-

could be widely interpreted as succumbing to political pressure. It was felt that such a perception could seriously damage the credibility of the ABS as an independent provider of impartial and reliable official statistics.

It is interesting to note that the concerns of the ABS were that the consumer price index (CPI), as a measure of inflation, could well be called into question if it departed by too wide a margin. Let us see what the facts are. Compared to the gross domestic product (GDP) deflator as a measure of inflation, the CPI has lagged well behind even though, in the latest figures which were released today, the inflation rate is 8 per cent. In fact, the implicit price deflator for GDP is showing an inflation rate at the June quarter of 9.6 per cent, well above the CPI figure. The same applied in the past. In March, when the inflation rate according to the CPI was 7.2, the deflator was 9.8. The figure for the CPI, I think for the June quarter, was 2.4 and it has now come out at 2.3; certainly in the same ballpark.

This shows that inflation is a disaster for Australia. It shows it at a rate approximately double that of the great bulk of our trading partners and worsening and it shows that the deal done by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) with the unions-with Simon Crean in particular and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-about the accord must now be at some risk because members of the rank and file clearly have been duped.

As Dr Hewson said in the other place, in negotiating the current version of the accord they have agreed to hold earnings growth to 6 1/2 per cent on the expectation that inflation would fall to 3 to 4 per cent in 1990, as the Treasurer predicted. But it has continually increased since then and the bottom line for all Australians is not only that the Government has locked itself into an inflation rate of 8 to 9 per cent but also that interest rates will stay higher even longer than the Government has been prepared to admit.

There is no doubt that sustained upward pressure on interest rates was evidenced again today with another jump in the Reserve Bank of Australia's rediscount rate to 18 per cent. There is no doubt that inflation is on the way up, so what will happen now to the deal that the Treasurer did with the big four banks on interest rates to try to hold them down? This latest inflation rise will clearly put added pressure on interest rates and the deal that the Government did at public expense will clearly soon be broken.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the annual report of the Official Establishments Trust, I remind the Senate that consistent comment has come from me, going back to my time as Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, about the enormous amount of money being spent on Kirribilli House and other residences occupied by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The justification for the enormous expense on the massive renovations at Kirribilli House, which had allegedly been urgent for many years, was that the fabric of the building was at risk and that the delay in fixing the problem could no longer be allowed to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: That may well be so, but it certainly managed to be deferred during the time of the previous Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. The annual report of the Official Establishments Trust then kept pointing out-I think it was first pointed out in 1977-that money could or should be spent. It is remarkable that it was only under Mr Hawke that hundreds of thousands of dollars were spent doing up Kirribilli House, allegedly because it was to be used by distinguished visitors to Australia, particularly in the bicentennial year. Of course, we all know that that was absolute nonsense. It was hardly used by any official visitor during the bicentennial year largely because the work was not finished. The main reason for this expense was that the Prime Minister of Australia decided that, apart from having the Lodge at public expense, he should also have Kirribilli House as his Sydney residence. He happens to represent a Melbourne constituency but he wanted a Sydney residence.

This property, which has been refurbished and structurally fixed up at immense cost to the Australian taxpayer, was used, we found out from a Senate Estimates Committee hearing of 23 October, only on approximately eight nights in the latest 12 months by any official visitor. The reason this Parliament was given, when the money was appropriated here, that it was for the purpose of refurbishing the place so that official visitors to Australia could be accommodated, was total bunkum. It was done to make it a nice place for Hawkie to live in when he is in Sydney. It is fascinating that he has decided to spend the great bulk of his time in Sydney. In response to a question which I asked, the Committee was told:
From October 1988 to September 1989 the Prime Minister stayed at Kirribilli House on 20 occasions-
that is not just 20 nights, but 20 occasions-

on 17 of which he was accompanied by Mrs Hawke or other members of the family. That involved a total of 102 days including overnight stays. In addition, Mrs Hawke stayed at Kirribilli on seven occasions involving 10 days in total.

One can see clearly that the reason the foreign dignitaries did not use Kirribilli House is that it was continually being occupied by the absentee landlord of the Melbourne seat of Wills, Mr Hawke, who spent one-third of the year living in Sydney, at public expense, in Kirribilli House, which is supposed to be for the purpose of foreign visitors. That is absolutely disgraceful. The place is simply not being used for the purpose for which it was intended, and is not being used in the way it was used when the previous Prime Minister was in office. If the Prime Minister really does not like Melbourne, does not want to live there and prefers to live elsewhere, why does he not stay at the Lodge where his accommodation is paid for by the taxpayers whether he is there or not? Why does he have to live in Sydney? I can assure the Senate that we do not want him there. We particularly do not want the taxpayers of Australia to have to pay for these huge renovations and the cost of looking after the Prime Minister for one-third of the year in Sydney, so far from his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—That concludes consideration of Government papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) is of the opinion that, as the pilots' dispute remains unresolved, Ansett and Australian Airlines and the Government have failed to apply the terms of the Two Airlines Agreement and the Airlines Agreement Act 1981; and
(b) calls on the Government to terminate that agreement to enable other carriers to fly scheduled services no longer provided on the Australian trunk route system.

The background to this motion is that under the Airlines Agreement Act 1981 certain routes in Australia-roughly, the routes between the capital cities-are defined as the trunk routes and section (6) (1) (d) provides a contractual obligation on the two major carriers, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines, to provide scheduled services on those routes. If they fail to do that the Minister has the power to allow another operator to come in and operate those services. The fact that another operator comes in does not in any sense deny the present two major airlines the right to continue to have access to those routes even though they are not using them in the way in which the Act requires them to. In one sense, Ansett and Australian Airlines have absolutely nothing to lose by this motion.

It is very clear that the airlines are not meeting their contractual obligations under the Act. There is not now an effective air service in Australia on the trunk routes as is required under the Act. This is causing a huge cost to the Australian community. We argue that there is a legal remedy available under the Act to resolve this situation. I would like to take a few moments of the time of the Senate to reflect on the history of how we got into the present position. I have a very strong belief that neither the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) nor the management of Ansett and Australian Airlines is the principal reason why we are in the trouble we are in today. I would argue that the principal reason we are in the mess we are in is the Airlines Agreement Act of 1981. It did not provide the commercial competition between the two major airlines that would have guaranteed both of them some economic efficiency. It allowed both managements to indulge in soft practices and to give in to pressure groups, whether they were the pilots, the baggage handlers, the flight attendants, the fuellers or the Transport Workers Union of Australia. Management conceded to any group that put pressure on it over the eight years since this agreement came in, as it had in previous times-since the early 1950s when the first two-airline agreement came in. There was not the commercial pressure on the management to perform and, therefore, the management conceded without cognisance of the long term economic effects of the concessions it was granting. The consequence is that today there are very high numbers of employees in both airlines and, as a further consequence, high fares.

It is not only in manning that there are bad practices. There is the absolutely absurd position of very large numbers of aircraft types, relatively speaking, in the fleets that the companies are operating. I think Ansett has 30 or 40-odd aircraft, and six different types. There are the F50s, which it has got rid of recently because of the strike, the 727s, the 737s, the 767s, the BAe146 and the new A320. An airline cannot make money with such a huge range of aircraft types and a small fleet of the size the airlines have. The pilots cannot be blamed for that. One can only go back to the non-competitive airline environment under the existing Airlines Agreement Act.

I go back to the history about how it all came about. Like most things, the problem did not arise de novo and it is worth reflecting on how we got into this position. In 1945 the Labor Government of the day decided it would set up an airline, called the Australian National Airlines Commission, which traded under the name of Trans-Australia Airlines (TAA), to run a monopoly air service in Australia. The major airline operating at the time was the second Australian National Airways, which succeeded the first ANA started by Kingsford-Smith and Charles Ulm, which failed at the time of the Great Depression.

The second ANA was the dominant airline in Australia from the late 1930s through to the end of the 1940s. The Labor Government, being imbued with a socialist philosophy, sought to destroy the private enterprise airline, as it was then, the second ANA, and created TAA and legislated to give it monopoly powers. That legislation was thrown out by the High Court and a rather uneasy situation existed for some years in which an airline backed by the resources of Government was competing in the marketplace with what was a genuinely private enterprise airline which had to raise its own capital, without any help from the Government, and satisfy its shareholders.

Adding to the burdens of the old ANA was the fact that it made a bad decision with respect to equipment. It recognised the economic superiority of aircraft such as the DC3 and the DC4, and both the economic and mechanical efficiency of the Douglas designs, and in an age which saw new aircraft types coming on it stuck with the old manufacturer and bought DC6s, both A and B models. TAA, which was then very well-managed and very aggressively managed, with a bunch of ex-Royal Australian Air Force pilots running the company, was buying the latest equipment and running an excellent service, and it got the major part of airline traffic. ANA was in a great deal of difficulty, coupled with its bad equipment choices and, what must be admitted, its bad management. It started to correct things and it was on the way back-from a management point of view-when Ivan Holyman died in Honolulu and Reginald Ansett agreed to take over and operate the then ANA. He was in a position where he could not compete against an airline that was funded from a public purse the way in which TAA was. It had virtually unlimited call on the financial resources of the Government and, most importantly, had an influence on the regulatory and licensing procedures of the government of the day, particularly if it was a Labor government.

The proposition was advanced that the two airlines be combined and that we have one carrier in Australia. That was rejected by the Menzies Government which was then in power because it certainly did not want a monopoly in Australia, whether it was a privately owned monopoly or a government owned monopoly. That led to the creation of the first two-airline Bill to provide ground rules under which the two major airlines competed so that one did not get an advantage over the other. While it was necessary at the time the airlines agreement kept on being renewed. It was made initially in 1952 but there were successive agreements in 1957, 1961, 1972 and 1973. The whole of the economic and travelling climate in Australia changed dramatically from 1952 to 1981. The 1981 Act at present governs the trunk operation of the Australian air routes. It was a great improvement on the Bills that went before it.

It did three quite dramatic things. First of all it recognised and set up procedures by which TAA could be sold. While this is now 1989 and the two-airline Act was set in place in 1981-which is some reflection of the glacial pace of parliamentary progress-it will be about the middle of next year before TAA, or Australian Airlines Ltd, as it trades now, is sold to private enterprise. The second thing the Act provided was a separation of freight traffic from passenger traffic whereas before the two were linked together. It recognised that there were special attributes in both classes: the passenger trade was one thing and freight needed different skills, different attitudes. It made provision for freight airlines to start up. Most importantly, it set up a deregulation inquiry. As a consequence of those moves today we know that deregulation of the airline system will take place in 1990. While I was not in favour of the Bill at the time, I recognised, as I said in my speeches, that it was a signal advance on the legislation in this field that had preceded it. I was not in favour of the Bill at the time because I foresaw that it provided no commercial competition and that the events that face us today would occur. It is not very often that I can stand up in this Parliament and say, even though it gives me absolutely no satisfaction to say so now, that the events that I foresaw in 1981 have now come to pass.
I want to turn to the Act itself. The Act provides in the schedule, in paragraph 6.1 (d):

Without derogating from the objectives of sub-clause 1 (a), the parties acknowledge that nothing in this agreement shall preclude the Commonwealth, the Minister or the Secretary from permitting a passenger operator to develop specialised scheduled passenger air services over trunk routes of a nature which in the opinion of the Minister are not adequately provided for either by the Commission-
in the words of the Act, the Commission equates with the current Australian Airlines-
or the Company-
which is currently Ansett-
and for which after receiving a request in writing from the Minister neither the Commission nor the company has, within a reasonable time, provided a service to the satisfaction of the Minister.
Paragraph 6.1 (a) of the Schedule to that Act provides:

The parties shall take all reasonable action within their powers to ensure that the Commission and the Company are the only two operators which provide scheduled domestic passenger air services over trunk routes within Australia.

The first subparagraph of paragraph 6 provides that the only two companies that can operate are Australian Airlines and Ansett. The relevant section that is the subject of the motion before the Chair at the moment is paragraph 6.1 (d) which gives the Minister the power, where the two major airlines are not delivering the service that they have a contractual obligation to provide, to allow a third or other operators in.

If Australian and Ansett do not operate services the Government has every legal right to allow someone else to come in. We believe that there are great benefits in that being done. I propose to put before the Senate evidence which shows beyond dispute that the airlines are not meeting their contractual obligations. I would like to go off on a tangent for a moment and read another paragraph of the Schedule to the Act. Paragraph 15 (4) states:

The Commonwealth agrees that, during the currency of this agreement, it will not enter into air service arrangements or agreements with other countries which will permit any foreign airline to operate scheduled domestic services, provided that a foreign airline may, if authorised by the Commonwealth, carry international passengers and international freight on domestic sectors as part of its international services.

Paraphrasing that, it means that the Commonwealth has no right to allow an international operator interlining rights in Australia. Yet, this is precisely the action the Commonwealth, or the Government, has taken in the present instance where it allows international operators to pick up domestic passengers on the routes on which the international operators are flying and to transport them around Australia. There is absolutely no way the Commonwealth can argue that it has any right to breach paragraph 15 (4). But that is not the subject of the motion that is before us.

I said that there was abundant evidence that the airlines are not meeting their contractual obligations. The very first point I make refers to the evidence on the public record of the airlines. The airlines-both Ansett and Australian-are telling the Australian public, groups of tourist industry operators and anyone else who is interested that it will be Easter 1990 before normal services are returned. The degree to which services are provided is a matter of dispute. The airlines say they are doing one thing: the Pilots Federation, the tourist operators and anyone else who is trying to travel around Australia say something quite different to what the airlines are saying. But that is irrelevant in one sense. The important point is that the airlines are saying that by Easter next year they hope to get back to a normal service. That is a prima facie case, a frank admission, that they are not meeting their contractual obligations.

I stress the point that whether the airlines claim they are providing 60 per cent of services today or whether the truth is that they are providing 40 per cent is utterly irrelevant. In my judgment probably less than 50 per cent of the predispute services are available to the travelling public today.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what the Prime Minister said.

—That is true. I am coming to what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, as I have on so many occasions, a little later in my speech. We have had evidence given to a Senate Estimates committee on the actual number of seats that are being provided. I do not wish to get down to the fine detail of that but the evidence provided to the Senate Estimates committee within the last few weeks on actual passenger seats occupied is at great variance with what the airlines have claimed and are still claiming. Of course, throughout the last eight to 11 weeks all of us have had personal experiences of having tickets issued, seats confirmed and not being able to get on those services.

SPEECH.PARA: Dealing with the shortcomings in the service, the first point that is beyond dispute is that there are some ports in Australia between which no services are operating. Some of those are the Adelaide-Brisbane route, the Perth-Alice Springs-Cairns route and reverse, and the Cairns-Darwin route. A whole host of places in Australia are getting very poor services. The classic case is Tasmania. One simply cannot fly to Launceston other than via a Royal Australian Air Force aircraft. There are no commercial services operated by Ansett or Australian Airlines which are flying or which have flown to Launceston, one of the most bustling commercial centres not only in Tasmania but in Australia. One cannot fly there by Ansett or Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the brightest people live there.

—Yes, some of the brightest and most attractive people live in Launceston and they are isolated-put in Coventry-from the rest of Australia. Try to travel to the Northern Territory and see the difficulties that Territorians have. Even Senator Collins confesses to that when he comes in and bleats about the airline system. It is very difficult to get to Western Australia. It is very difficult to get to Queensland. On the figures I have for the last week, if we look at the services operated by Ansett and Australian, on a Monday to Friday basis last week by my estimation less than 30 per cent of the predispute figures were operated. I estimate, too, that of that 30 per cent of the services operated, the actual component provided by Australian and Ansett with their own aircraft and their own crews is probably about 10 per cent of the services they were offering before the dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: In my own State on Tuesday of this week, only two days ago, there were 15 movements of aircraft operating for Ansett or Australian. That means charter operators or these fly-by-night people the airlines have brought in to bolster the service. There were 15 movements out of the port of Brisbane on Tuesday of this week against the normal figures of 48. I do not wish to go into further detail about the figures because I recognise that it is a very contentious point. It is hard to get proof. But having taken an interest in this, I believe that the figures I have cited conform to the pattern of traffic available today.

I briefly touch on a personal experience I had last week. I had two boarding passes issued in Canberra for a flight from Canberra to Sydney and from Sydney on to another port. When I got to Sydney, although my boarding pass for the next sector had been issued only three-quarters of an hour beforehand I was told by one of the major airlines, `Your flight has been cancelled'. I said, `What are you going to do for me?'. They said, `Nothing'. I said, `Why won't you put me on the next flight?'. They said, `Because the next flight is full'. The best I could get, having departed from here on the first flight in the morning was a promise of a hold-over and a waitlisting for the last flight of that day. Fortunately, something turned up and I got away earlier. We have all had experiences where the scheduled services that are promulgated are simply cancelled, often without any reason being given at all. This, I believe, is one of the reasons why the airlines no longer publish in the daily newspapers the services they claim to operate. They are not publishing them because there is an acute morale problem with their staff at the office counters. The staff selling the tickets look at their visual display units. They see those flights advertised. They sell tickets for them and they know as they are selling those tickets that at the end of the day a very high proportion of those flights will have been cancelled and they will have had to cope with justifiably angry fare-paying passengers.

The situation with respect to scheduled services has been further bedevilled by the flood of propaganda. A great deal of misinformation has been fed to the community. Senator Messner reminded us of the many occasions when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told us that the strike would be over in a day or two, that normal services would be resumed. He has been saying that for nearly 12 weeks now and the gloom of the strike is as heavy upon us as it ever was. Sir Peter Abeles is not blameless in this. I go back to 14 September, to a transcript from the Parliamentary Library of an interview he did on A Current Affair with Jana Wendt, and note that this is 14 September:
SIR PETER ABELES: By Sunday or Monday, you'll see about four or five of our group planes flying, and I'm not talking of chartered planes or the American planes that are here.
JANA WENDT: All right.

SIR PETER ABELES: Next week, you won't see just six or seven planes. You will see very rapidly us, whichever way it goes, to have half our fleet flying again, much faster than I would have dared to say a week ago.

Sadly, that has not come to pass. We have had all these stories in the newspapers saying `PM puts job on the line'. I wish he would. If he had any honour, if he had any integrity, if he could find the shoe box that he once used to keep his integrity in, the one that the cartoonists used to draw him with, he would call an election and go to the people of Australia now on the way he has mismanaged this strike, for the grievous injury it has done to the Australian economy. While we are talking about the economy, he ought to let the Australian public pass judgment on the huge foreign debt that he and his incompetent Treasurer (Mr Keating) have built up. We get into emotional fields here because there has been so much misinformation fed out by the parties in this dispute. But that is all irrelevant. Clearly, the actual percentage of services being operated is about half of what we need. Therefore, Australian Airlines and Ansett are not fulfilling their legal obligations.

If one reads the Airlines Agreement Act one will find that there is no let-out for the major airlines. There is no force majeure clause. There is no special circumstance. There is nothing which allows Ansett or Australian to plead a special circumstance and to be excused from the consequences of section 6 (1) (d). I might say, inferentially, that since the airlines have not shown the slightest inclination to negotiate with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots they thereby have contributed to breaching the Airlines Agreement Act. I know very well the absolute disfavour in which the AFAP is in, in the eyes of the management, but if the airlines have an intention to honour the Act they have to overcome their displeasure in dealing with the pilots and enter into meaningful negotiations with them.

In summary, the two-airline agreement has clearly been breached by the inability of Ansett and Australian Airlines to provide the scheduled services which they contracted with the Commonwealth to supply. In that case, the Act provides the Minister with the opportunity to let in a third party or a fourth party. The Minister must act in that way because it is in the national interest that he so does. The airlines are certainly suffering. The pilots are certainly suffering. But the people who are really suffering are the members of the Australian community. We have had damage done to us-which is going to cost us, in the fullness of time, billions of dollars-by this unnecessary strike.

Tourism, the biggest single export earner of this country, is suffering grievously. The tourism industry is saying that it will have at least a 40 per cent reduction in this year's income as a consequence of the strike-and this is the biggest export income earner of a country which is destitute because of the financial policies of this Government. Only yesterday we had another record balance of payments deficit. We have high inflation. We are in very bad shape economically. Yet our principal economic export industry is being destroyed by this strike.

By way of example of the effect on the tourism industry, I am advised that the hotels at Ayers Rock and Alice Springs have less than 10 per cent occupancy. In the tourist areas of our State of Queensland, Mr Acting Deputy President, the occupancy of the big hotels is under 30 per cent. In aggregate, it is estimated that the losses to the tourist industry are in excess of $550m so far. More than 16,000 staff have lost their jobs or been stood down. That number, sadly, is going to increase in the months ahead because there is no resolution in sight.

Many small businesses not only are in difficulty but will go to the wall and will never recover. Not only the small families will suffer. The big tourist operators, as we can see from reading the financial pages, are in great difficulties because their occupancy rates have been cut back so significantly.

There are only two alternatives. The first is to get the airline management of both companies to meet with the pilots and thrash out some agreement. I believe that that must be done. It certainly cannot be done by refusing to negotiate, as the airline management does with the pilots, because the dispute now is about not money but personalities. Both sides have to compromise, concede and get together. If we do not do that, the only other recourse is for the Minister to follow the direction given by the Senate this afternoon, exercise the legal powers that he has under the two-airline agreement legislation and allow a third or a fourth competitor in on the trunk routes. If that happened we would find that the blocks to negotiations between the airline managements of Australian Airlines and Ansett and the Pilots Federation would disappear overnight.

While I am not so concerned about the welfare of the airlines or the airline pilots, my primary concern is the national interest and the interests of the people of Australia. It is time that this strike was finished and resolved. It could have been resolved about 10 or 12 weeks ago but for the pig-headed actions of the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate and Senator MacGibbon's opening contribution to it are very fine examples of the hypocrisy and superficiality which have become such hallmarks of this Opposition in the seven years that it has been blundering around the Australian scene, always irrelevant and seldom very far from self-immolation. I think the hypocrisy of it all was very well exposed yesterday in the House of Representatives by my colleague the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley. He described this resolution, as moved yesterday in the other place, very accurately as a manifestation of the axis that the Opposition has formed with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) in order to deprive Australian citizens of air services. While crying national interest or public interest crocodile tears of the kind that we have heard again here today from Senator MacGibbon, the Opposition, in its own twisted way, does, of course, see an opportunity to make some cheap political mileage out of extending the dispute at the expense of the Australian travelling public.

SPEECH.PARA: Let there be no doubt that holding out grains of hope, setting up straw men of the kind that are involved in this motion, suggesting that there is some fast and easy way through the dispute, is a way of guaranteeing its extension. The only way this matter can now be resolved is not through a resumption of negotiations between the airlines and the Federation of Air Pilots. The time for that has come and has gone. It came and it went weeks ago. It was rejected by the Federation when it had the opportunity to sit down around a table and do the thing properly within reasonable parameters. It had the opportunity again a few days ago before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

That opportunity has gone. It has gone, of course, because the airlines have had no alternative but to go out and hire pilots elsewhere around the system. A situation has now been created where it is simply impossible for the airlines to re-employ all those who have left their service. That is why the only way to resolve this dispute is through the pilots recognising the reality of the situation and coming back individually and signing the contracts that will get them back on board. Every grain of hope, every straw man that is erected by the Opposition or anybody else suggesting that there is some quick and easy way of going back to the pre-existing situation, will have no other result than to extend that dispute and, of course, its extension is exactly what the Opposition wants. Despite the claims of public interest, despite the claims of national interest, it wants nothing of the kind.

The other dimension of the hypocrisy of all this is that members of the Opposition are now calling for the termination of the two-airline agreement which they themselves created and perpetuated-most recently in 1981 over the opposition of those of us on the Labor benches at the time. It was the Hawke Government which had the courage, the foresight and the stamina to appreciate the extent to which the two-airline agreement was creating the sorts of featherbedding arrangements that have contributed to the whole background and underlying cause of this dispute. It was the Hawke Government that took the issue on after years of wimping and avoiding the issue-years of ideological commitment but practical incapacity and the absence of any kind of will on the part of the Opposition to turn its alleged ideological commitment into deregulation, into a genuinely competitive environment and into any kind of reality. It was the Hawke Government that picked up the issue and actually put into train the course of events which is now operating to terminate the two-airline agreement properly within the terms of the present legislation.

A decision was made in October 1987 when I was the Minister following a motion of relevance in the two Houses to achieve the termination. This was followed by executive notice being given on 30 October creating a situation for the airline agreement to be terminated on 30 October 1990. It is not an agreement which is capable of being terminated any sooner than that.

So much for the hypocrisy of what honourable senators on the other side are saying. The superficiality of their approach is also spectacularly apparent. The motion before us and the reasoning behind it simply do not stand up to any kind of scrutiny. Let me very briskly demonstrate why. Four questions are raised by this motion. They are: first, have the airlines breached their obligations under the Act; secondly, even if they have breached them, is the Commonwealth obliged to terminate the agreement; thirdly, if the Commonwealth were to seek to terminate the agreement, would the airlines have a good legal defence or, moreover, a case for damages; and, fourthly, even if the agreement could be terminated without a massive cost penalty to the Commonwealth, would there be any advantage to the travelling public? They are the relevant questions and I am glad to have an acknowledgment of their relevance from the Opposition bench.

Let me now address the answers. The first question is: have the airlines breached their obligation under the Act? Of course, under the Act-and the relevant provision is section 12-the airlines are obliged to maintain certain trunk services. But neither that nor any other provision of this particular agreement would be interpreted by a court with the kind of mindless, absolutist literalism that is being claimed by Senator MacGibbon and the Opposition. Obviously, attention would be paid to the intention of the airlines to maintain the services in question. Obviously, attention would be paid to the capacity of the airlines, in the real world that we are presently operating in, to maintain the services in question.

To adopt any other view is to be caught in a situation of manifest absurdity. Is one to say, for example, that if weather conditions are such that it is impossible for the two airline companies, or one of them, to maintain a trunk service for a significant period, that could immediately trigger a notice of termination? Are members of the Opposition saying that if services cannot be maintained because of some sustained industrial dispute, that is itself enough? Are they saying that if it is a dispute of three months, yes, but of two days, no? What are they saying? What they would have to say is exactly what a court would say-that is, we have to look at all the circumstances of the particular situation in order to determine whether or not there is a breach of the relevant clause. It matters not that there is no explicit force majeure provision any more than it matters not that there is no such provision if one is trying to work out what the situation would be if the agreement could be terminated in the context of a simple two-day strike or a one-day weather interruption.

The question in issue in terms of maintaining services is: in all the circumstances of the case, is there the intention to maintain and the capacity to maintain? What is in issue in this situation is that there is the intention, but there is not the capacity for reasons which are quite beyond the capacity of the airlines to influence. They are continuing to provide to the best of their capability services over the trunk route network, including by the use of leased aircraft as well as their own aircraft. It is simply nonsensical to say that there is any kind of case, even a prima facie case, for saying that the airlines are in breach.

Nonetheless, let us go on and ask the rest of the questions: Even if we assume that there is a breach, is there any obligation on the Commonwealth to terminate the agreement? Does it follow automatically if there happens to be a literal breach of the legislation that the agreement would be terminated? Of course it is a normal principle of law that a party to a contract can forgive a breach when it believes, as we do, that the circumstances are such that there is benefit from maintaining the contract and certainly no advantage from cancelling it. It is the case, I repeat, for exactly the same reasons as I mentioned before, that the airlines are continuing to provide to the best of their capability services over that trunk route network and there is simply no foundation, no conceivable justification-I will reinforce this point a little later on-for doing otherwise than maintaining that agreement in existence to run its full and normal course.

The third question is: if we are to assume a technical breach and if the Commonwealth were to seek to terminate the agreement, what would be the situation in terms of the capacity of the airlines to defend any such action by the Commonwealth and, indeed, what would be the possibility of the Commonwealth finding itself liable for significant damages? The same points are very much relevant again. The airlines could very easily demonstrate to any court obliged to deal with this matter that they stand ready and indeed are making strenuous efforts to perform under the agreement, that they are providing substantial services meeting up to 60 per cent of the demand now and expecting to meet up to 80 per cent of that demand by November. They can obviously make the point that to the extent that they are unable to perform in full it is because they are being frustrated by events beyond their reasonable control, not least the resignation of their entire staff of pilots. That is the situation we are confronting-they simply do not have the employees on board; they are scrambling actively to obtain some, but do not have them. All of that means, when it is added up, that the Commonwealth could well be legally stopped from pursuing the course of action that is being urged upon it by the Opposition or, worse, that if it did seek to terminate the agreement in this way it could be liable for massive damages not just of the order of magnitude that the Commonwealth is presently paying out, the relatively small sums to keep the maximum number of services going, but it is very easy to contemplate in the event of the Commonwealth acting unilaterally to terminate the agreement in the way that is here proposed that the Government would be liable for literally hundreds of millions of dollars of damages for the loss of profitability the airlines could credibly claim for not being able to see out the terms of the agreement until October 1990.

This is what the Opposition-I have assumed that it is not a totally mindless exercise; I will give it the benefit of the doubt in assuming that it is a cynical exercise-whatever the motivation, is urging us to do and that is some of the down side that is associated with it. Most importantly of all-I am giving this motion far more serious and reasoned attention than it deserves-let me address the final leg of the argument. The question that has to be addressed here is: in terminating the two-airline agreement, would the travelling public be advantaged in any conceivable way? The point here is that there is simply no evidence at all that this would result in any improved service to the Australian people on conditions that would be economically or socially acceptable. The two airlines have already scoured the world for lease aircraft which meet our rigorous safety and operational standards and, to the extent that they have been able to find them, they are either in operation now or will be very shortly.

Again, if we are talking about opening up to potential new entrants, as Senator MacGibbon seems to want us to do, the reality is that none of the potential new entrants is yet in a position to introduce new capacity in any kind of time frame which is remotely relevant to the settlement of this particular dispute. The truth of the matter is that there are no airlines operating in Australia which are capable of immediately providing the service anything like that which is presently operated by the major carriers. Nor could any such airline or any new airline immediately established start up any such new services for literally months ahead. Is it the case that the international carriers could make any difference were they to be entitled to come in and operate in a totally deregulated environment of the kind that the Opposition is urging upon us? The international carriers have been offered the option of extending services and carrying domestic passengers, but due to operational commitments of those airlines and the existing, ever growing demands which are upon them all round the rest of the world, the reality of the matter is that within any kind of reasonable time frame they are simply not capable either of putting new capacity onto Australian routes. I do not know what the Opposition really expects, if it has any degree of credibility of seriousness about the proposition that it is putting to us, could possibly flow from such an immediate termination exercise.

Finally, if the Opposition is suggesting that some new entrant could do a back door deal with the AFAP outside the wage guidelines as a basis for providing alternative services-if that is the sub-text of what is being suggested-all I can say is that that would be totally unacceptable not only to the Government, but also to the Australian public. We have not gone through all the pain and stress of the last few weeks, and the Australian public has not stood by and endured that knowing and understanding the reason for it in terms of the wage break-out potential of capitulating to the dispute, in order simply to hand a bomb to the AFAP to blow up the Government's wages policy which is obviously such a critical factor in maintaining economic activity and employment in this country.

I repeat-I have probably devoted more serious attention to this motion certainly than it deserves and I suspect rather more than the Opposition expected me to-firmly and precisely for the record that this motion has no legal basis, it has no practical basis. It can do absolutely nothing to help resolve the dispute or assist the travelling public and, like most of the things which occupy the Opposition's time these days, it has been I think yet again a spectacularly evident waste of the Senate's time; and the Government rejects the motion accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a refreshing occurrence to have the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) participating in debates once more. I listened with great attention to his presentation. Firstly, I indicate that the Australian Democrats will support the motion for the reason that we have always opposed the two-airline system, parallel scheduling and all the evils it has brought upon this country and, to be consistent, we will support this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I did take on board the Minister's analysis of the situation. I do agree to a certain extent that there is a lack of instant availability of aircraft. However, if this strike continues, as apparently it will for many months, if we could start immediately to send signals to Compass Airlines, Southern Cross Airways and Capital Airlines, the three proposed entrants into the airline system after deregulation-in fact, they might have a place in the scheme sooner than they thought-perhaps they could get their leasing arrangements in order quicker. If efforts were made to speed up the procedures for introducing these aircraft, I wonder whether the Opposition would actually approve of such procedures. It has been very critical about any operations in the past which would facilitate the bringing into Australia of aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was yesterday.

—`That was yesterday' said Senator Collins. I hope that, if the airlines are capable of bringing in new equipment, the Opposition will see it in a different light and support wholeheartedly the efforts of the Civil Aviation Authority to streamline its procedures in order to get the aircraft flying on Australian routes.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans launched a rather petulant attack on the Opposition but he failed to note that, to a great extent, the Government is responsible for the situation which exists in Australia today. If the Government had not agreed to compensate the airlines to the extent that it did, the dispute would probably be over. This is not just my view; it is the view of Tony Harrington, one of the aviation writers for the Australian Financial Review, who said on Wednesday, 25 October 1989:

The Federal Government's decision to compensate carriers for wages bills incurred during the dispute simply prolonged the issue, enabling the airlines to last indefinitely against recalcitrant pilots.
The result? A substantial erosion of public confidence in the airline system, and a vastly reduced market for air travel.
So I think that, if the Minister were being completely honest, he would have taken some responsibility for the present situation.

In passing, Senator Evans talked about international carriers. I asked a question about this and I got a kind of half-answer. I have been informed that there are many empty seats on international carriers' aircraft flying around the country simply because of difficulties in booking them. Bookings are presently made through Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines and apparently they often simply do not bother to assess the availability of seats on international carriers. I think the situation should be looked into and every available seat should be utilised by the travelling public.

Deregulation, in general terms, has always been something which I have favoured. We saw the situation in the United States of America where deregulation was debated hotly and finally came about. There was much rhetoric in the United States before deregulation that aircraft safety would be endangered by deregulation but, after deregulation, the United States aircraft safety record is still as good as it ever was-which is quite good in the United States actually for the number of aeroplanes flying and the number of passenger miles operated. In fact, aviation in general is quite safe; it is about 400 times safer than riding in a car on the roads in Australia. If we look at the jet travel safety statistics in Australia we find that it is infinitely safer to travel in a jet because there has never been a jet airliner crash in Australia. I wonder how many of those 22 people who were killed in the bus near Grafton would have actually taken an aircraft if one had been available. It is ironic that the doctor who actually treated some of those bus passengers was killed in a road accident on his way back to his home. He was a pilot, yet he was killed in a road accident after treating those road victims. The skies are a lot safer than the roads.

Let me get back to the two airlines concept. It is a bizarre concept. It was a bizarre concept to me when, as a pilot, I came to Australia; I could not understand it. I found that it certainly limited competition and it forced the consumers, the users of the aircraft, to do exactly what the airlines wanted. It meant that profits were being guaranteed for the airlines but that the consumers were being herded like cattle into certain timeslots and given only certain features because both airlines basically provided the same services under the two-airline arrangement. It is interesting to note also that the major control exerted by the Federal Government, because of the peculiar way Australia is set up, was not over the airline routes themselves but over the ability to import aircraft. Of course, this is what kept East-West Airlines Ltd from expanding for so long.

The two-airline system and the regulation which it incurred did not really protect the consumer and the industry. Instead of needing protection, the private firm, Ansett, has now become the major operator in the industry and the Government firm, Australian Airlines, is the loser. Some 80 per cent of intrastate traffic is now controlled either by Ansett or by its subsidiaries. Of course, Australian and Ansett have a virtual monopoly over 18 designated trunk route sectors. Furthermore-and this will be more significant in the future when we get deregulation-Ansett and Australian have almost complete control over airport facilities through their leasing system. Even when we get deregulation the new airlines will have to deal with the existing big two.

Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd (TNT), which controls Ansett, is the biggest transport conglomerate in the world. It operates in some 80 countries and has earnings of well over $2 billion a year. Of course, it is backing Ansett, and Ansett is doing very well indeed out of the pilots dispute at the moment. The pilots dispute has come along at a time when both Ansett and Australian were worrying mightily about competition with the new airlines emerging in this country after deregulation. They knew that they had to streamline their services and that they had to meet the competition head-on but, with their old structures, they were fearful. The airlines dispute has given them the opportunity actually to streamline their operations.

Of course, this is taking a long time. As Senator MacGibbon has said, the industry itself is saying that it will not really have full services going until well into next year. If it were really interested in solving the dispute it could solve it quite quickly. It is obvious that it is not interested. The aviation writers in the newspapers are writing about the pilots dispute in the past tense. They are saying `The pilots dispute was an effort by the pilots to gain a 29.4 per cent pay rise', and that sort of thing. The aviation writers have accepted that we have a depleted airline service in the country and that the strike itself is no longer an issue. The strike will drag on now for months and months while the airlines restructure, to the detriment of the travelling public.

There is a danger with or without deregulation. Even with deregulation we will see a monopoly by Ansett. It has already taken over East-West; it has taken over Kendall Airlines; and it looks like Ansett will be in a good position to take over Australian Airlines. Australian Airlines is not capable of meeting the economic drain of a prolonged strike. It has already suffered because of the loss of its business class edge over Ansett. It was doing well with business class and Ansett was wondering how to make up the difference. It does not have to wonder any more because the business class advantage that went to Australian Airlines has now gone.

If there were enough movement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and he could generate enough clout to sell off Australian Airlines it would probably end up belonging to TNT and News Ltd-in other words, Ansett. The new airlines which are coming on are full of hope. Some of them are having trouble getting equipment. We will have Southern Cross Airlines, Compass Airlines-a no-frills airline-and Capital Airlines which intends to be at the top of the range. But they will be fighting for a dwindling passenger market which has been affected even more by the strike.

Australians fly about half as much per capita as Americans and about as much as Canadians. Between 1950 and 1975 the airline industry went through a lot of growth; it increased its passenger carrying capacity by about 8 per cent per annum. But since then it has only been rising at about 1.5 per cent per annum and aviation industry officials expect that demand will climb to about 80 per cent of pre-dispute levels some time in the new year. So we will see a number of new airlines entering into business at a time when consumer confidence is really quite low.

What about the future? What is the future of the airline system? I wish to quote from the report of the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation which I think says as much as needs to be said about who will dominate the industry. The May report stated:
Ansett Airlines is well-established and has very substantial financial mass. It is unlikely that Australian Airlines would pose a risk to its viability.

It may, in fact, be more reasonable to assume that in a completely deregulated environment Ansett Airlines' position would become such that only a government-owned competitor could be assured of survival.

Therefore, after deregulation, we could have only one airline anyway. The irony of the deregulation is that we may have to have a government-owned airline to ensure competition at least on the main routes. Deregulation in the freight area came in 1982 and some licences were given for pure freight operation. But there is only one major freight operator left, IPEC. It looks as though this deregulation may result in the same fate.

Much has been written and said about smaller centres and whether they will benefit or otherwise from deregulation. I believe that they will benefit. In the United States of America there was much hue and cry that the smaller centres would be abandoned when the larger carriers such as United Airlines and American Airlines Inc. could no longer serve them. But, in fact, a number of commuter airlines have sprung up, which give a more frequent service on smaller aircraft, which operate at the request of the commuter rather than the airline, which has turned out to be a healthy thing. So the smaller centres in Australia will probably benefit. In the short term consumers will probably also benefit as the industry shakes itself up. In the long run, however, given the structure that we have, it looks as though Ansett will probably control everything.

We need open skies. It is a good thing to work for. I do not see any way that we can keep Ansett from controlling everything. We certainly should open it up to competition. It may be that the competitors will be more able to compete than I have said; I hope so. But we certainly need to create a better climate for aviation in Australia, with both a streamlined Civil Aviation Authority structure and frequent, fast, efficient airline services. The combination of these two things will, of course, lure more people into the skies, which are far safer than the roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter of great importance to my State of Tasmania. As a Tasmanian senator, of course I feel the imposition of this airline dispute more than most. I would, firstly, like to skim over the matters which were raised by Senator Evans. I found it quite extraordinary that Senator Evans could so quickly dismiss the legitimate concerns of the Opposition as a cynical exercise. The questions which we properly raised concerning the implementation of any termination of the two-airline agreement-reasonable questions though they were-were answered quite inadequately by the Minister. I have to say that, while he may have had a good try on behalf of his Government in defending its stance on terminating the two-airline agreement, it was certainly not a successful try.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that the two-airline agreement has been breached. There is no doubt that the airlines are not providing, as they are required to do under the agreement, scheduled domestic air services over the trunk routes within Australia. It is clear that the Government can permit other operators to provide services on trunk routes which are not adequately provided for. The Government is not doing that. The airlines are in breach of the agreement. The Minister can, and should, be terminating the agreement. The Minister does have the power to terminate the agreement. Whether he wishes to, of course, is another matter. He is unduly concerned about liability for damages. In my view, if a party to an agreement is in breach of it, and in such substantial breach as in this case, there is no excuse under the two-airline agreement for events beyond the control of the airlines. The airlines are in breach of the agreement and the Minister needs to take better legal advice. Perhaps Senator Tate, as a lawyer and a Tasmanian, can have a quiet word with Senator Evans. But in my view there will not be liability for damages against the Commonwealth when there is such a clear breach of the two-airline agreement. If the Commonwealth were to terminate the agreement it would be on firm ground.

Senator Evans also talked about whether the travelling public would be advantaged by terminating the two-airline agreement. He says there is no evidence of that. I have to say to him that perhaps the question should have been, `Would they be disadvantaged any more than they are today?'. There is no doubt at all that the travelling public and Australia's industries are seriously disadvantaged by the lack of action by the Government and by the breach by the airlines of the agreement. That was one question which perhaps could be said to be a bit of a red herring. In my view, the public interest clearly demands that the Government exercise its right and its duty to terminate this agreement.

It was quite revealing that Senator Evans wound up his speech by talking about the Government's refusal to accept a new entrant into the airline industry who would, presumably, be making deals outside the wage guidelines. Therein lies the nub of the problem. He said, `We would not want to hand a bomb to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots'. The Government has such a fixation and paranoia about the Federation that it will not take any action which will be to the benefit of the public in case it also has any spin-off benefit for the Federation. I have to say, as one must always do in this place because of the Government's fixation with the Federation, that I hold no brief for the Federation nor for the airlines. But I certainly hold a brief for the travelling public, and particularly for Tasmanians. Any mechanism that can be used properly and legally either to end this dispute or to bring more services into the air would have my support. I would have expected the Australian Government to take action regardless of whether it might give any advantage to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots if it meant that the travelling public and Australian industries would benefit.

Mr Acting Deputy President, if you were a Tasmanian, you would understand, as I do, that 83 per cent of visitors to our State come by air. That compares with only 38 per cent of people travelling by air to other States. Therefore, this is a disaster for Tasmania. The implications of this dispute for us are just enormous and go down the years in front of us. The year 1990 was to have been, according to the tourist industry in our State, one of the best years yet for tourism. It is our second biggest industry. It accounts for 10 per cent of our gross domestic product and compares with only 5 per cent as the national average. Yet now we are told that this dispute may go on until Easter.

As the Tasmanian winter season does not attract many tourists, our tourist operators and the people associated with the industry must make their money during the summer months to carry them through the difficult days of winter. This summer season bodes so desperately badly for Tasmanian industries. The Tasmanian State Government, recognising these concerns and the huge impact on the State's economy, is talking about the possibility of investing $75m in a three-plane State airline. That is how much it recognises the effects on our State, yet the Federal Government seems to sit and wring its hands like Pontius Pilate. The extra blows we have received recently include the cancellation of discount flights, which are such an important mechanism for increasing the tourist industry. Now the extra flight by Qantas Airways Ltd has been cut out, which adds to our problems.

Only yesterday the head of the Tasmanian Department of Tourism, Sport and Recreation, Mr Annells, said he hoped that airline deregulation could be brought forward to encourage competition and he called for Federal Government assistance and for special measures for remote locations. So it is not just the industry but also State Government officials who recognise just what problems we face. Yet the Federal Government does not seem to.

Another sideline of the problems that have been faced as a result of the pilots dispute and the necessary airlift by the defence forces is that we had Air Marshal Funnell recently talking about the distortion to operations that it was causing to the Royal Australian Air Force and, therefore, to the training of the Force. The Tasmanian Government is now so concerned that it is talking of sending a delegation to Canberra to put its point of view. Mr Field says that he has already written twice to Mr Hawke. He has commissioned an Australian Bureau of Statistics report so that Canberra will get a better idea of what is happening. We are so worried in our State. But this Government will simply not take action, except to fund the airlines. It is interesting that when one of my constituents in a small business in Tasmania wrote to one of my colleagues in Tasmania about the problems he was facing in his industry the letter he got back stated:
. . . I am not sure why you look to me and my political colleagues for an immediate resolution, nor what you think such a resolution might entail.
He went on to say:
. . . it is a matter of judgment whether the only quick resolution possible would be more or less damaging to the economy in the longer term than the current impasse.

That was my Labor colleague Senator Coates. He seems to think that people should not be looking to him for any kind of resolution nor to his political colleagues. He was expressing a view that a quick resolution might be more damaging to the economy in the longer term than the current impasse. I just wonder what he can possibly expect to take his money for if he does not expect to have people writing to him in their distress looking to him as a member of the Government to try to get some resolution of their problems. Yet clearly he thinks that we should be in for a long haul of pain. It is just not good enough and yet it is typical of this Government that it has not been prepared to recognise the problems people are facing and to do something about them. There have been no negotiations. There has been no concern for Australian industries. There has been no concern for travellers. The airlines have breached the agreement. It is due to end in 12 months. The Government should terminate the agreement now and let others provide the service that the Government's friends cannot and will not provide and are not providing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a lawyer Senator MacGibbon would make a great dentist. I have some little experience with matters relating to airlines that have ended up in litigation in Northern Territory courts. It would be a very brave person indeed who would safely, in the way Senator Newman just did, predict as a lay down misere the outcome of the inevitable court action that would ensue should the Government be so foolish as to adopt the course that has been placed before it by the Opposition. The Opposition is not serious about the Government's adopting this course at all. This latest piece of sophistry that it has put before the Parliament is just one more political stunt in a long line of political stunts that have been run during this dispute in the last 10 weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans canvassed four huge holes in the Opposition's arguments. I just want to touch on two of them, one in particular which was canvassed by Senator Sanders. I have no doubt at all as to why Senator Sanders touched on this point.
