It was Senator Sanders who sat with me through 13 very painful hours of Estimates committees listening to Opposition members, and principally the two speakers that we have just heard in this debate, bucketing the daylights out of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) for alleged breaches of regulations in expediting the arrival of a handful of new aircraft from overseas on Australian routes. One thing we would have to hand the Opposition in this debate is yet another award for sheer cheek. There is no question at all, as Senator Evans said, that should the Government move so precipitately as to simply terminate at this point the two-airline agreement outside of the correct method for terminating it, which the Government is currently following as laid down in the legislation, it would certainly end up in court. There is not a court in this country that would not have to take into consideration the extraordinary controversy and complications that are related to this dispute and to the obvious and unarguable inability, rather than failure, of the airlines to provide a proper service on Australian routes.

The second point that I want to raise is the one that Senator Sanders so succinctly canvassed, as did Senator Evans-that is, where do we instantly get the aircraft to provide yet another instant solution to this appalling dispute? The two major airlines in Australia are currently, and have been for the last 10 weeks, scouring the world for aircraft of the appropriately high standard demanded by the CAA in this country to fly over their routes. I do not have the slightest doubt that if there were another 20 or 30 aircraft from overseas operators that could instantly be put into the Australian airline system they would be put there tomorrow. But it is really the height of cant and hypocrisy, as Senator Sanders and Senator Evans have both already said, that we now have a solution being proposed by the Opposition, with fleets of expensive aircraft owned by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines sitting on the ground at airport terminals all over Australia, that will simply open the doors instantly for some unknown overseas operator to come into Australia and fly on Australian routes, when the Opposition has just completed 10 weeks of non-stop white anting and bagging on behalf of their allies in the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) of the CAA for alleged breaches and watering down of regulations for getting the handful of overseas aircraft operating on Australian routes that are currently operating. It really deserves a good prize for cheek to run that sort of an argument in the Parliament.

It is a fact that this dispute has ceased to be a dispute in traditional industrial relations terms. That is a great tragedy for this country. It has become a jihad, a holy war, for the Federation of Air Pilots.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the Prime Minister who did that.
—Once again, that argument is a total nonsense.
—Where have you been?

—Where has Senator Chaney been? In support of what I am saying, Senator Chaney issued a press release only last weekend taking the Federation of Air Pilots to task for what it has failed to do in the past 10 weeks. I commend this press release-it did not get much of a run-of Senator Reid's leader. She might do well to read it. Apart from the obligatory criticism of the Government that it contains in a couple of paragraphs, I totally agree with 95 per cent of the press release. It is directed precisely where it needs to be in terms of resolving this dispute-that is, to the Federation of Air Pilots.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon took my breath away somewhat when he opened his contribution to this debate by saying that the AFAP was not in any way responsible for this dispute. I might also add for Senator MacGibbon's benefit that I was interested in his comments. I love people who claim the gift of prescience eight years down the track. Senator MacGibbon also told us during his speech that when he spoke in support of the Airlines Agreement Bill in 1981 he predicted that this dispute would occur as a result of the restrictions placed by the two airlines agreement. I would like to advise the Senate, having just read Senator MacGibbon's speech on the Airlines Agreement Bill of 1981, that he did nothing of the sort. I do not suggest that that is a matter of any great import but I think it is probably important to correct the record. The reason that I read his speech, having been told that he predicted this dispute in 1981 when he made it, is that I have come to appreciate over the last 10 weeks that we can accept on face value nothing that Senator MacGibbon says about airline operations in Australia. Everything he has floated in this Parliament so far in terms of alleged breaches of safety and the terms and conditions of contracts offered by airlines to their employees has been demonstrated to be total nonsense.

Mention was made also of the opportunities that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots has had of resolving this dispute in a proper way by putting its money where its mouth is, negotiating and making the concessions that it constantly says it is prepared to make. The reason that this dispute has continued to the ridiculous extremes that it has is that the Air Pilots Federation is false in its assertions that it is prepared to negotiate. That is precisely what the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) said in the press release to which I referred.

I shall quote from the opening paragraph of Senator Chaney's press release, which was directed to the Federation. It carries the headline, `Pilots' Federation must say where it stands on key issues'. Hear, hear to that. The press release reads:

The best way for the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to contribute to breaking the present absurd impasse is to spell out, in a totally unequivocal way, the circumstances under which it would recommend its members accept re-employment by the domestic airlines.

I might also point out that Senator Chaney, when he issued this press release only last weekend, was pleading in vain, as we all have been pleading in vain with this Federation, for some sense. Of course, the AFAP has not responded to Senator Chaney's totally reasonable demand. Senator Chaney, in this press release, goes on to say what the Federation should clarify. He says that it should clarify:
(1) how a return to work could be effected, on what terms and conditions pending negotiations and involving what number of pilots

(2) whether it accepts there will be big reductions in the number of its members who can be re- employed under more productive arrangements. (Any suggestion that it would enter negotiations only on the basis of a re-employment of the full, pre-dispute complement of pilots is unrealistic.)

(3) whether it accepts the need to do away with restrictive work practices which have held back productivity in the airline industry. (It's no longer good enough for the AFAP to maintain a generalised opposition to the new contracts on offer by claiming they would set conditions back many years.)

(4) whether it will guarantee that it will neither encourage nor tolerate any direct or indirect intimidation of pilots who have already signed up. (The Federation has previously denied it is bringing pressure to dissuade pilots from taking up the new contracts but this needs to be extended to the day-to-day post-dispute operations.)

I do not disagree with a single one of those points that Senator Chaney has made. It is unfortunate that members of his own Party have not paid the slightest attention to the statement that he has issued. One thing that is also painfully obvious is that neither has the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, because it has ignored it in the same way that it has ignored every other reasonable request for some reasonable behaviour on its part over the last 10 weeks.

In terms of unreasonable behaviour and unreasonable positions and in terms of its interpretation of negotiation and industrial relations, one could hardly go past its performance before the Industrial Relations Commission when a number of operators in the airline industry sought the setting aside of the awards that cover its members who do not work for the major airlines in Australia. A perusal of that transcript indicates how totally unreal and totally hypocritical the Federation's position is, because 40 per cent of its members do not work for the major airlines; they work for a whole host of smaller charter general aviation operators and operators that operate regular passenger transport services across Australia. They are all covered by awards, all of which function well-which was argued for hours before the Commission by the Federation-and all of which work to the benefit of the members of that Federation.

The absolutely absurd position that the Federation put to the Commission was that it wanted 40 per cent of its membership to stay inside the system, because that benefited those members, and 60 per cent of its members to go outside the system. I do not think that I have heard of a more absurd, unrealistic or unreasonable stand for a union representing its members to take. I have not heard of one to top that.

The Australian Federation of Air Pilots has in fact succeeded in forming an alliance with the Federal Opposition. That alliance has been more painfully obvious with every day in this Parliament-both in this chamber and in the House of Representatives-and a Federation member has told me that the leadership of the Federation is quite happy to stay out on strike until the Federal election, whenever that may occur, and campaign for the election of the Opposition into government. I hope that that is precisely what it does if the dispute should last that long, and I hope to God that it does not. It will campaign for the election of the Opposition into government because it knows, from the `wink wink nudge nudge' attitude that the Opposition has adopted towards the Federation's outrageous pay claims, that it will get what it wants should the Opposition be elected.

That is the only inference that can be drawn from the continued attack by the Opposition on the Government's support of the airlines in maintaining the non-flying staff of those airlines. The Opposition has been continually asserting that, by providing this support, the Government has simply prolonged the dispute. The only inference that can be drawn from that statement is that it wants to see that support withdrawn so that the airlines will be forced to accede to the unreasonable demands of the pilots and give in. It is no good putting meaningless, qualifying statements in press releases or in debates here that the Opposition does not support the pilots, when everything else it says clearly indicates that it does.

Some of the nonsense run in this Parliament, particularly by Senator MacGibbon during this dispute, to give aid and comfort to the Federation has been outrageous and irresponsible. It has been canvassed in this chamber before: press statements predicting mid-air collisions over Sydney based on incidents which in fact never occurred; allegations of direct political interference by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) in pressuring the Civil Aviation Authority to water down its safety regulations. Senator MacGibbon directly accused Mr Willis of being involved in political interference in the reduction of the standards applied by the CAA. Senator MacGibbon made a number of outrageous statements about the lowering of standards in the CAA, political interference by the Minister, and contracts being offered by airlines to the Federation's members, providing for a 40 per cent increase in their current working conditions-all of which proved to be nonsense.

All of this has been canvassed in Parliament before. Honourable senators might not unreasonably ask why I am canvassing it again. The reason is very simple: today I got hold of a couple of very interesting documents. One of them is a piece of correspondence from the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations sent from London to the Chief Executive of the Civil Aviation Authority and relating to this dispute. The letter, which has been written by an organisation that I would imagine would like people to think it is responsible, rational, reasonable and careful in its canvassing of matters related to airline operations, is based on total rubbish and nonsense. It is very badly drafted. It gives the appearance of having been thrown together in 10 minutes, which I am sure it was, and it is, as a result of a second piece of correspondence that I have received, revealed as a totally put-up job between the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations and the AFAP to once again try to run this appalling scare-mongering campaign of alleged breaches of safety regulations in Australia, a campaign whose principal agents have become not the AFAP but the Federal Opposition. The letter, addressed to Mr Freeland and dated 24 October 1989, states:
Dear Mr Freeland,

For many decades Civil Aviation in Australia has enjoyed an exceptionally high standard and an unsurpassed safety record, due to highly skilled professional pilots and technicians, supported and safeguarded by high CAA operational standards.

The International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations (IFALPA) is proud to have those Australian pilots amongst its members and has often used Australian Civil Aviation, its CAA and its track record on safety as an example when discussing civil aviation matters with other authorities and organisations around the world.

It is, therefore, with shock and disbelief, that I learned of the abrogation of its duties and responsibilities by the Australian CAA, in deviating from its own high standards under commercial and political pressure in the recent airline dispute.

In order to allow airlines to restore some of their commercial operations, the Civil Aviation Authority has relaxed and reinterpreted its own rules to issue certificates of validation, facilitating foreign aircrews to operate indiscriminately on the Australian domestic routes.

I pause to point out to the chamber that that is precisely what the motion we are debating this afternoon, moved by the Opposition, is calling upon us to do. Of course, the Government will not do it. The letter goes on to say:

In Western democracies, like Australia, bodies like the CAA have always performed independently, free from commercial and/or political interference or pressure in order to set fair and high safety standards for the aviation industry.

Either the new lowered and relaxed safety standards concerning licensing, training and operational standards are intended to be the new valid regulations, or they are ``only'' meant to serve as a tool to break a dispute.

In both instances the Federation is extremely concerned at the implications and effects on the level of safety. Should the end result of this unprecedented relaxation be an increase in aviation incidents or, even worse, an accident, the passengers involved and the Australian travelling public will want to know why the previously applied standards were lowered. The Federation hopes the Australian CAA will restore its independence and dignity by re-introducing the standards that have made them the envy of the world and accept that they should not bow to the pressures of political expediency.
The Federation's aims and goals are to assist in developing and maintaining a safe and orderly system of air transportation, and to stem efforts which endanger the level of safety.
As president of IFALPA I would urge you to restore your operational standards and requirements in order to maintain the high level of safety in Australia and restore faith in the CAA.
Yours sincerely,
Captain L. H. D. Bakker
President

The difficulty with that letter, apart from its very obviously flowery and over the top language and bad drafting and the fact it was clearly thrown together in 10 minutes, is that it is based on the nonsense and totally unsubstantiated rubbish that has been run by the combination of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and the Federal Opposition, all of which was destroyed and revealed as rubbish in the 13 hours of Estimates Committee hearings.

The CAA has not lowered its safety standards at all. No political pressure has been placed on the CAA. Mr Freeland stated categorically, on the record, at that Estimates Committee that the only communication he had had on the question of safety from Minister Willis was the stern instruction that, while expediting to the fullest degree possible under the regulations the entry of new aircraft to routes in Australia to assist the travelling public, air safety was not to be prejudiced at all. That is the only instruction that this Government has ever given to the CAA.

What is this claim of the International Federation based on? It is based on a piece of nonsense run in this Parliament by Senator MacGibbon that political interference was involved in the CAA on the basis of a telephone call to a staffer in Minister Willis's office requesting a telephone number so that Ansett technical personnel could urgently contact, late at night, a senior officer of the CAA who was in constant contact with Mr Willis's office. Of course, these technical people knew there was a possibility that the Minister's office would have a late night home telephone number for him. That was it. It is on the basis of this nonsense that this International Federation has written this letter to the Civil Aviation Authority. Why has it written the letter? Is it a genuine attempt by the International Federation to canvass serious, real and substantiated issues on air safety? No, it is a put up job between the International Federation and the Australian Federation to run a bit more baseless scaremongering, to frighten the daylights out of the Australian public and to try to persuade them not to fly in Australia. I saw a recent interview with Mr McCarthy in which he said, `I don't want to be alarmist, but I wouldn't fly in Australia at the moment on Australian Airlines'. Obviously Mr McCarthy's interpretation of being alarmist and that of everyone else who speaks the English language are very different things.

I referred earlier to a second piece of paper that came into my possession today along with this letter. It is a facsimile sent from Mr Terry Middleton, who is the executive officer of the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations in London, to the office of the Airline Pilots Federation in Brisbane. Addressed to Captain Tony Fitzsimmons of the AFAP in its Brisbane office, it states:
Hereunder the letter to Collin Freeland, which we have mailed. Do you have a fax number for him, so that AFAP can make use of this letter? Otherwise you might have to wait a few days . . .

The AFAP has got on to its colleagues in the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations in London and given them 10 minutes of garbage over the telephone about alleged political interference and alleged abrogation of safety standards-none of which is true-and the International Federation has obligingly drafted this piece of scaremongering nonsense, sent it to Freeland and then realised that it takes four or five days for a letter from London to reach its destination and has faxed the AFAP office in Brisbane saying, `Hang on, before you use this letter you had better make sure that you wait a few days until Freeland actually gets it'. That is a disgraceful effort on the part of the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations. I look forward, as I am sure Senator Schacht looks forward, to canvassing point by point once again the allegations contained in the letter sent at the request of the AFAP in Australia from the Federation in London and seeing, once again, the nonsense that is contained in that letter exposed.

The reason I have raised this letter and the associated fax, copies of which I am perfectly happy to provide to Opposition members should they require them-although they probably have their own advance copies ready to run when the Federation launches its copy of the letter in three or four days time after the mail has arrived in Australia-is that we have got to the point where reasonable people have to insist that this stops. Why is it happening? It is happening because the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is losing the support of its members. It is hanging onto that support at the moment-and I know this personally-by a very thin thread indeed, by the skin of its teeth. It is losing the support of the 40 per cent of its membership that it is quite happy to argue should stay inside the industrial relations system under awards while the Federation brings the country to its knees on behalf of the 60 per cent of its membership which it wants to take outside the system. It is losing the support particularly of the younger pilots, who want to get back and fly planes and who think that this dispute has now reached the point of madness and stupidity on the part of its leadership and that it is about time it stopped. Unfortunately, the Federation has decided once again-and it is traditional to do so-to use threats of breaches of safety as a weapon in the dispute to keep everyone on side. It has not just happened in Australia. It has happened in similar disputes in the United States. It was a key issue in the airline pilots disputes in New Zealand. It is usual for pilots to use scaremongering tactics that somehow or other people will be killed or injured as a result of abrogations of air safety standards.

As I said before, it is fair enough for any member of the Federation, any member of the CAA or any member of this Parliament to raise issues such as that if they are based on fact. It is irresponsible to frighten the daylights out of the travelling public based on nonsense and fiction. It has been revealed once again that that is what the Federation is engaged in, in put up jobs and nonsense in conjunction with its colleagues in the Federal Opposition. I am happy to supply Senator MacGibbon, if he does not have them, with copies of this letter and copies of the fax. I have pleaded with Senator MacGibbon on previous occasions that he does not simply accept the nonsense and the rubbish that is handed to him on a regular basis by the Federation and run it in here but that he take some little effort on his own account to check out whether there is any foundation at all in these continual white-anting tactics and scaremongering tactics on the current safety regime that applies in respect of operations of Australian airlines.

The one thing that the Opposition, the Government and the entire country agree on completely is that we all wish that some sanity and common sense will be introduced into this dispute. Senator Chaney obviously appreciates the fact, which Senator MacGibbon is happy to ignore, that the Airline Pilots Federation is playing a key role both in initiating this dispute and continuing it. I simply conclude my contribution to this debate by saying that I would like to add my pleas to those of the Leader of the Opposition in this chamber, Senator Chaney-I look forward to it happening-in having the Australian Federation of Air Pilots answer point by point the requests that Senator Chaney has made in his press release, which the Federation has so far failed to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Near the end of Senator Collins's speech we heard something from him that was of value in the debate. He made the point that the dispute has reached madness and stupidity. It is not helpful, I believe, in trying to get a resolution to this matter for him to behave as he has by constantly attacking the pilots and the Opposition with no recognition whatever of the very valuable role that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) played very early in the dispute and escalating it to the state of-using his own words-the holy war that it now seems to be.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney has called upon the airline pilots, and rightly so, to do certain things. But the dispute cannot be resolved by one party only when the Government for week after week after week has been behaving in a way which had indicated that the parties were not to come together to try to work out a solution. It is not a question of one party only. Anybody can read through the schedule to the Act which sets out the Airlines Agreement of 1981. There can be no doubt or dispute that it is not operating at present, that the scheduled flights are not being provided and that a different solution is necessary as quickly as possible to get airline services operating in this country.

We had Senator Evans's contribution earlier. We can always tell when Senator Evans knows that he is a bit thin on the law and that the argument is not the way that he is obliged to put it. He gets abusive and he raises his voice. That is exactly what we had during his fairly short contribution to the debate earlier this afternoon-accusing us of extending the debate, the most twisted logic I have yet heard. I think that surpassed Senator Collins's contribution in which he said that there could be no resumption of negotiations now. How on earth will we ever be able to resolve anything when that is the Government's position? It is beyond me to contemplate how the dispute can be resolved if the Government takes the attitude that there can be no resumption of negotiations. If the time for that has gone it is because of the actions of this Government.

We have had the situation of questions being put to the relevant Minister in this chamber about the services presently being provided and the suggestion that they are at 60 per cent. Well, if they are, I do not know where they are because it is certainly not in relation to the flights in and out of the national capital. I checked the figures on Tuesday of last week which indicate that there have been 150 seats in and out of Canberra. On a normal Tuesday there would have been 1,500 seats. If the planes are flying they are flying somewhere other than here.

Tonight I particularly want to refer, without taking up too much time, to the impact which this dispute is having on so many people. I refer specifically to my own electorate. Today I have had a telephone open line running to my office to enable people to ring in regarding aspects of the dispute. We all know the figures for the big hotels and the major tourist operators. They are absolutely devastating. But the same thing applies for many other small businesses. It is necessary for the Government to understand what it is doing to so many Australians. I just refer to the small operations of the airport kiosk and bar at Canberra airport. Those businesses have had to put off all staff but one who keeps the services going. They are required to remain open under the franchise that they have. No other staff members are working but the manager. Three university students who, it was put to me, really needed the money have had to be put off. They are not able to continue with the work that they had. The bar, apart from one employee working from time to time, has been closed for virtually eight weeks.

It is not just those people who are dependent on these jobs who are affected by what has occurred. There are in addition to all the other businesses that have been affected, others such as butchers, cake shops, green- grocers and milk deliverers. The business at the Canberra Airport which I referred to normally had $5,000 to $6,000 worth of newspapers and magazines delivered each week. It is now down to $150. A newsagent in Fyshwick is suffering the loss of business as a consequence of his now providing to this shop $150 worth of newspapers and magazines a week whereas his normal turnover to that client was $5,000 to $6,000 a week. These are the real issues of what is happening to people just in Canberra. Look at the rest of the country. The taxi drivers here have had their incomes slashed by 40 per cent; the hire car operators are virtually out of business altogether. At least two operators here who deal with the more expensive end of the market for international tourists are just not operating. If we try to get a plane in to or out of Canberra-well, just try to get a plane in to or out of Canberra!

Advertisements are published in the newspapers of what flights are available. If people ring up they will find that they are not available. As one constituent of mine had said to her, `If you believe that, you will believe anything'. She now does not of course. There are business people who have had to go to Sydney or Melbourne for meetings and other activities. They now have the additional cost of travelling and staying overnight in those cities. A meeting in Melbourne may now take two to three days when we take into account the travelling, not to mention the consequence of increased use of the roads, which will only be exacerbated as the holiday season and Christmas comes upon us.

Talking of holidays and the Christmas season, the number of families who will have their arrangements disrupted is enormous. Honourable senators might think that that does not matter. It is not commerce and is of no consequence if a family whose parents are in Cairns or north Queensland are not able to spend Christmas with their family as they would normally do or if those in Darwin now cannot afford to come south for Christmas because the apex fares that normally operate and that they can manage to pay for will not be operating. Let it be known that from Darwin it is much cheaper to go to Singapore for a holiday than to go anywhere in Australia, and likewise to New Zealand.

These are the facts and the human consequences of what has occurred. I mention one girl who rang my office today who has had to change her wedding plans for November because the flight arrangements that previously were in place will no longer be possible. There are difficulties in visiting and getting to Western Australia. The consequences for some are that they have had to travel by bus to get back. Others, being in ill health, should not have had to travel in that fashion. The one thing that became clear from those who rang my office today was their dismay at the fact that this issue is no longer a front page issue.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking on this matter before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. I think it is appropriate to reiterate what the Senate is discussing. It is discussing a motion put by Senator MacGibbon:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) is of the opinion that, as the pilots' dispute remains unresolved, Ansett and Australian Airlines and the Government have failed to apply the terms of the Two Airline Agreement and the Airlines Agreement Act 1981; and
(b) calls on the Government to terminate that agreement to enable other carriers to fly scheduled services no longer provided on the Australian trunk route system.

There can be no doubt that the carriers are no longer flying the scheduled services on the trunk route system. Other speakers before me have referred to those matters and to the lack of services. I referred briefly to the situation in the Australian Capital Territory where there can be no doubt that normal services are no longer being provided. I carried out a survey on Tuesday of last week to ascertain the truth of the comment of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, that 50 or 60 per cent of normal airline capacity was being provided. On Tuesday that was not the case. Only 150 seats into and out of Canberra were provided on that Tuesday compared with the normal scheduled number of seats-1,500.

The airlines have been publishing in newspapers, virtually on a daily basis, the flights that are alleged to be available into and out of various cities. Many of the flights do not take place. Reliable sources have told me that flights from Darwin to Adelaide, Darwin to Melbourne, and Darwin to Sydney are published. If one is lucky, there may be one flight that goes Darwin-Adelaide-Melbourne-Sydney, or perhaps in the reverse order.

Having spoken to other senators who have done similar checks in their cities, there can be not much doubt that the Government is including in these figures the few flights that are actually being undertaken by the airlines, the flights that are being undertaken by the Royal Australian Air Force and the seats which appear to be available on the flights by international carriers, which includes Qantas Airways Ltd. Qantas is taking only those who are scheduled as international travellers and those whom they regard as travelling on compassionate or other such grounds. Many of the seats on Qantas flights across this country are not occupied or available to passengers who would otherwise wish to fly. By distorting the statistics in that way, the Government has said that some 50 to 60 per cent of seats are available. But those in this country who have wanted to use the airlines know that is not the case.

A woman rang me the other morning, a woman who lives in Canberra whom I know quite well. Her husband had to go to Sydney to a meeting. Several years ago this family's daughter was killed in a motor vehicle accident on the Hume Highway and from then till now they have not, for understandable reasons, used the Hume Highway. Her husband had a meeting in Sydney. He would normally have travelled by plane. She undertook the necessary phone calls to get him booked onto a plane. She looked up the schedule of the flights available that was published in the Canberra Times and proceeded to ring both major domestic airlines and East West, only to find that there was no possibility of getting on a plane to travel from Sydney to Canberra.

She had heard the Prime Minister's remark that some 50 to 60 per cent of seats were available, so she said to the airline representative, which she thought was quite reasonable, `Well, if 50 per cent of the seats are available, if we cannot fly on this day surely we can fly on the next'. Eventually somebody said to her `If you believe what is published you would believe anything'. She rang me, as she was very taken back to find that there were no seats available between Canberra and Sydney, and that it was somewhat of a joke to suggest that there were seats available between Canberra and Sydney. The end result of the whole exercise was that her husband had no choice but to drive from Canberra to Sydney.

I do not know quite where the planes are flying that the Government has referred to when it has talked about 50 to 60 per cent of the seats being available. We have certainly heard Senator Button refer to this in the chamber. Not long ago we all heard the Prime Minister's pledge that he had put his job on the line in relation to the availability of flights. On 14 September 1989, the Sydney Morning Herald ran an article headed `Pilots: PM puts job on the line'. Many people in this country perhaps believed the Prime Minister when he was reported in that article as guaranteeing that `50 per cent of air services would be restored by the end of the month' and saying that if he `did not protect this country against the pilots he would not deserve to be Prime Minister'. I have no choice but to say tonight that, given what has occurred since that time, the Prime Minister does not deserve to be Prime Minister, given that he laid down the gauntlet and issued the statement that he would not deserve to be Prime Minister if by the end of September the planes were not flying. The article went on:
The Prime Minister said that services would return to normal even if the Australian Federation of Air Pilots stood firm.

The Federation of Air Pilots has stood firm. The press release of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, as to the matters that the pilots ought to answer has been read out in this chamber. Up to this time they have not done so. There is no question of the airline pilots being right in this issue. There is no question of the airlines being right in this issue.

What makes this dispute different from any normal dispute between employer and employee is the fact that the Government bought into the dispute at a very early stage, at a stage when any normal person might have expected the Government to act as an honest broker and try to get together the two groups, the airline pilots and the airlines, to work out a solution to the problems facing the country as a result of the dispute. For some reason that I think most Australians regard as totally beyond comprehension, the Government decided to join the airlines and not attempt to bring the parties together and resolve the dispute. Everybody will remember that the Prime Minister very early in the proceedings said that it was war-all out war-against the pilots and that he would win at any cost. But the cost that we are referring to is not a cost to the Prime Minister; it is a cost to the taxpayers and business people of this country who are attempting to earn their living in the tourism industry.

The dispute has gone on now for some 11 weeks. We hear of planes and pilots being brought from overseas. We have seen and heard of the agreement which has been presented to the pilots by the airlines. I have in front of me tonight a copy of the agreement which has been presented to the pilots by Australian Airlines. It is headed `Airline pilot contract of employment'. I shall not read all of the agreement because there is not the time to do so. But I will read some of the points that have been made by a well respected legal firm which was asked to give advice to the pilots on the contract which was presented to them. The letter says:
We acknowledge your instructions to peruse the draft Airline Pilot Contract of Employment given to you by Australian Airlines Limited (``the Contract'').

We note your instructions to consider the draft Contract as to whether it is fair and reasonable from a commercial law point of view. We have considered our advice bearing in mind that our instructions are from a pilot being requested to enter into an agreement for the purposes of enabling him to continue flying as an employee of the airline.
The legal firm goes on to say:
We make the following comments:-
1. We have not given detailed consideration to the terms of the definitions in clause 1, in the absence of your specific instructions as to the same.

2. We note your instructions that you have no objection to clause 2d, which gives the right of the employer to require you to fly in any part of the world. We do however feel that clause 2e should be amended to provide that the employers consent will not be unreasonably withheld, as we understand that it is not unusual for pilots to fly other aircraft while employed as a pilot with a major airline.

3. Clause 3a gives too much discretion to the employer, as they may deem duties quite unconnected with flying, such as ticket collection and baggage handling, to be necessary for the efficient and safe conduct of airline operations.
Clause 3b-similarly, this clause should be amended so as to specifically define pilot's duties as being consistent with the obligations of a qualified pilot.
Few of us who fly regularly would disagree with such an opinion. The letter continues:

Clause 3c-while there appears to be no objection to pilots being available to perform more than 55 flying hours per roster period and being paid an additional hourly rate if they fly in excess of 55 hours, we do suggest the calculation in clause 7g be amended so the denominator is a number of hours equal to the expected standard hourly flying per annum. 660 is a product of 55 hours per month times 12 months. It does not take into account the reduction in hours due to annual leave, sick leave and training time. The clause also does not define what is meant by the word ``available'', which should be the case so the clause can be properly interpreted.
The firm of solicitors also gave this advice to the pilots who were asked to sign the contract:
Clause 4a-you should give consideration to the provisions of CAO Part 48, as it will determine the obligation to perform pursuant to the roster.

Clause 4 generally appears to suggest that the roster shall be determined solely by the Employer, to the result that pilots will not have any rights to have determination as to their flying during the period of service.

Clause 4 e appears to have legal effect that even though the terms of clause 4 d have not been complied with by the Employer, there will be no breech of the Contract by the Employer as the pilot will be entitled to a replacement day off, although there is no statement as to when and how that replacement day can be taken by the pilot.
There are several other comments in relation to clause 4.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of agreement is that?

—It is an agreement presented by Australian Airlines to a pilot. In fact, I believe that it has been presented to a number of pilots. But a particular pilot sought the advice of a leading firm of Australian solicitors as to the implication of the agreement that he was presented with and as to whether or not he might consider signing it. It might be helpful if I refer to the comments made by this firm in respect of a number of other clauses. In regard to clauses 4 f, 4 g and 4 h the solicitors said:

SPEECH.PARA: -it seems when a pilot is rostered for reserve duty, they will receive no payment, also a pilot could be placed on reserve duty almost continuously, on the basis that they would be rostered for a period of time, not exceeding 15 consecutive hours, each day. Additionally, it is noted that the word ``available'' is again used. There should be a definition of the word included in the Contract. There should be some credit for reserve duty, by extending the terms of clause 7 g.

The solicitors refer to the definitions and suggest that the word `available' ought to be defined. It might be worth pointing out the words that are defined under this contract. Those words include `administrative captain', `base', `captain', `check captain', `cleared to the line', `deadhead'-and I rather hesitate to read what that might mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the Prime Minister?

—The honourable senator suggests that perhaps `Prime Minister' is the definition of `deadhead'. I make no comment. Other words that are defined include `duty', `employer', `flight time limitations', `first officer', `line competency', `roster', `sign off time', `sign on time', `time', `trainee pilot' and `training captain'. They are the words which are defined in the contract of employment offered by Australian Airlines to the pilots. It is suggested by the solicitors that the word `available', given the number of times that it is used, should also have been defined. I think there is good reason for suggesting that the solicitors are right.

SPEECH.PARA: The solicitors go on to deal with clause 5 a and clause 5 b. In relation to clause 5 a they say:

-this clause has the effect that the Contract is, during the first six months of service, only a 7 day Contract. After the completion of six months of service, the Contract is a one month term Contract only.

People listening might wonder why it is relevant to go through the contract of employment that has been offered by Australian Airlines to its pilots and to read the legal opinion which deals with clauses included in it. It is relevant to look at this material in the light of the topic which we are debating tonight because, as a consequence of the dispute that exists, many people are suffering grievously. I have dealt with some of these matters.

I referred earlier to the remarks of Senator Collins and Senator Evans. When I spoke before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I said that one can always tell when Senator Evans is attempting to push an argument which is quite contrary to what he believes to be the case. The first sign that one sees is that he is abusive of those who present any alternative argument. The second sign is, of course, that he raises his voice considerably and speaks very loudly. He put forward a very twisted argument that the Opposition was responsible for the dispute being extended. He said nothing convincing to the Senate about why so many people in this community are suffering as a consequence of this dispute.

I have had many meetings with people in Canberra who have been affected by the dispute-people from the major hotels, tourist operators, taxi drivers and hire car operators. Many small businessmen have suffered grievously as a consequence of this dispute which is now in its eleventh week. Today I invited people to ring me on an open line to my electorate office and to tell me whether they have suffered because of this dispute. The results of that have been illuminating.

I referred earlier in this debate to the situation at the Canberra Airport kiosk and bar. That is the most obvious of all because at Canberra Airport things are not happening in the way that they normally do. I have spoken of the staff who have been put off or who have been required to take leave; I have referred to the fact that the manager is virtually the only person left who is working there at all, to the fact that the business is required to remain open under its contract notwithstanding the fact that the airline terminal is not functioning in its normal fashion; to the fact that three university students who need the money to maintain their lifestyle and their studies were employed there on a part time basis and have been put off as a consequence. The bar at the Canberra Airport has virtually been closed for eight weeks and the bistro gift shop likewise has put off a number of employees who normally work there. Some of them are single mothers who need their employment to be able to continue with what they are doing.

I have given examples of many others in this community who have suffered, such as the newsagent no longer supplying the same range of newspapers and magazines as has previously been the case. I can tell the Senate of coach operators who have suffered as a consequence. Some coach operators are doing better because they are travelling up and down the Hume Highway. I have spoken of the conferences that are being lost to Canberra and others that will be lost in the future and of the plight of the taxi drivers and hire car drivers who no longer have the work that they previously had. I have had phone calls today from many people pointing out the way they have been affected. I believe that the Government would be astonished to know the truth of the matter. The time for this debate has expired. I move:
That the question be now put.

—I am asking for the President's guidance on the status of this motion when the time for the debate has expired and we should have been calling on Government Business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the Government will particularly oppose this motion. I just note for the record that the procedures in this chamber were viciously aborted by the use of a gag. It is not a procedure that I particularly object to; I think the gag should be used more judiciously in this chamber. But let it bury once and for all the sanctimonious hypocrites opposite who bleat every time a debate is aborted: let us have no more of it.

—The time for the discussion of the previous debate had expired by less than five seconds at the time I moved that the question be put. Had we gone on for the remaining five seconds, which I could easily have done and will do if honourable senators opposite are not careful, we could have moved for the suspension of Standing Orders for the motion to be put. That may have taken another hour or so of the time of the Senate, which is somewhat valuable at this time of the year. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) is being totally sanctimonious in suggesting that the gag was applied. We were merely seeing whether the motion could be put without further delaying the Senate timetable.
—Order! The honourable senator has made her point. She should have been speaking to Senator MacGibbon's motion, which I will now put.
