TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I seek your indulgence. I suggest that it would suit our convenience if the Government's amendments and the Australian Democrats' amendment were all taken together because they all relate to the same clause. We could have a discussion on the whole clause with questions being put, obviously, on the separate amendments. We have given the Minister leave to move his amendments together and we will seek leave of the Committee for Senator Macklin to introduce his amendment. We can then have the discussion on the Government's amendments and the Australian Democrats' amendment to the same clause at the same time.

—I thank Senator Puplick for his suggestion. These three amendments arose out of the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on clause 32 of the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill. At that time, when I was Minister in charge of these matters, I gave an undertaking to further amend this Bill to bring it into line-that is, to require the Electoral Commissioner to be satisfied as to the existence of adequate safeguards to ensure that information supplied to Government departments under clause 32 will be properly protected, and also to exclude from the operation of clause 32 such Commonwealth authorities with commercial operations as are prescribed by regulations under the Act, bodies such as Qantas Airways Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had a look at the amendment of the Democrats, which would remove proposed new subsection 91 (9), which provides that the Australian Electoral Commission may provide microfiche rolls to Government departments and authorities and other such information that the AEC has-that is, occupation, date of birth and sex. The amendment would not remove the Australian Electoral Commission's ability to provide to departments copies of the roll; indeed, departments could go out and buy them at the reprint. But this would be a once only exercise. We have put proposed subsection 91 (9) in the bigger Bill to confirm the current practice. I also add, although I cannot be absolutely definitive on this-I have been looking at it in another context-that the Democrats' amendment has now probably been made obsolete by the principles of the Privacy Act under which the Electoral Commission has to ensure that appropriate safeguards are in place. I am not sure whether that totally covers the concerns of the Democrats.

The justification for providing this sort of information which has gone on for a long time really relates back to efficiency of government. It should always be stressed, though, that the electoral roll exists not for the service of other government departments, solicitors, missing persons agents or local real estate agents, although they all write and indicate that that is the reason that it exists. It exists on the basis of a certified roll produced every three years. That is the basic substance of it. At this stage the Government will resist the Democrats' amendment and press on with the amendments suggested, for the reason that we believe that the safeguards provided by the Privacy Act are adequate to protect the information contained in the roll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 12, clause 32, proposed subsection 91 (9), lines 39 to 44, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:

`` `(9) Except as otherwise provided by this Act, the Electoral Commission shall not provide any person with any information which discloses particulars of the occupations, sex or dates of birth of electors.'.''.

Clause 32 is a source of some contention. The Australian Electoral Commission has had a fair amount of difficulty in working out whether it has the power to provide this information. It provided it quite readily until recently, when it stopped on some type of legal advice, as I understand it. As the Minister has already said, this essentially is to put beyond doubt what the Electoral Commission is or is not able to do. The amendment that I have moved is an attempt to specify quite clearly where the information that the Electoral Commission has is able to be delivered. I refer back to the eighth report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills last year which stated:

This provision appears to be wider than that recommended by the Joint Select Committee. It . . . gives an apparently unfettered power to the Electoral Commissioner to supply that information to any Department or authority of the Commonwealth. No obligation is placed on the department or authority . . . to whom the information is supplied to deal with that information in confidence.
The Senate Committee also noted:

The proposed subsection 91 (9) does not require the bodies seeking this information to establish some reasonable justification for its supply. It would accordingly engage the Electoral Commissioner in compiling and supplying information for no apparently useful purpose.

To that report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee the Minister for Home Affairs at that time responded in the eleventh report of 1988. He undertook to move an amendment to the Bill `so as to require the Electoral Commissioner to be satisfied as to the existence of safeguards ensuring confidentiality before such information is supplied'. Moreover, the Minister undertook `to introduce a Government amendment to exclude from the operation of the amendment such Commonwealth authorities with commercial operations as are prescribed by regulations under the Act'. One of the amendments that the Minister has moved does precisely that.

Quite frankly, we believe the Government is now engaging in simply a bandaid exercise which does not address our fundamental objection to this, which is that we want to know for what purpose the information is collected by the Electoral Commissioner. We believe that the Electoral Commissioner should rightly have certain information to assist in determining who can vote and who is on the electoral roll. Obviously, the names and addresses of all voters is essential for the Commission, and that type of information is publicly available. However, people do not provide information to the Electoral Commission for purposes other than those associated with the legitimate role of the Commission in the community. So, in putting together our amendment, we are mindful of what has been debated here on a number of occasions. I refer the Minister to the second reading speech made on behalf of Senator Bolkus on the Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 in which he said:

It is generally accepted that individuals have the right to have certain data protection principles applying to large collections of sensitive personal data. The OECD Guidelines on Personal Privacy, which Australia has adhered to, set out these basic principles. These principles are:
there should be limits to the collection of personal data and any such data should be obtained by lawful and fair means with the knowledge or consent of the data subject.
I think that is already well taken care of within the Act. The next principle is:
personal data should be relevant to the purposes for which it is to be used and should be accurate

While we have had some disputes in the past about the range of material collected, because of the dual role situation we have accepted that additional material should be able to be collected but that that material should not appear on the rolls. At one stage that was the intention but the Government withdrew it after a fair amount of community concern on that proposal. The next point is:
the purposes for which personal data is collected should be specified at the time of collection and subsequent use limited to the fulfilment of these purposes.

I contend that the information collected by the Electoral Commissioner is for the purpose of elections only and not for other departments to use simply as a repository for all the information that they may wish to use on some occasion. It is not a repository information to allow private investigators to track down people whom they want to find. It is not a repository for any of those things and I do not think it should be used as such.
The last point is one which, if the Government's amendment is carried, the Government will be ignoring in this Bill. It states:
personal data should not be disclosed for other purposes except with the consent of the data subject or where required by law

When one signs a form to enrol on the electoral roll, there is nothing to suggest that the information will be funnelled off to every department which is too lazy to collect it itself or which feels that it may need it. Also, in regard to this Act, no reason is given why a particular department would wish to get hold of this material or what it might wish to do with it. In looking at the amendments we have tried to work within the constraints of the Act. Our original intent was to circumscribe all information, but obviously that is not possible because, as Senator Ray has quite rightly pointed out, a department can whip around the corner and buy a set of rolls if it wishes to do so, in the same way as can anyone else in the community, and therefore have access to the names and addresses. Of course, in those circumstances it would not have access to the names and addresses on the silent rolls. I wonder whether Senator Ray can inform us of the Government's intention with regard to the silent rolls. I know that not many people have made use of them, but there are names on them.

Our amendment is cast purely in terms of the data currently collected, that is, occupation, sex and date of birth of electors, which are key identifying characteristics. People in the chamber who have been following the credit reference and privacy debate will know full well that these are items that can trigger searches and hence are very useful items. We are saying that this will not be provided elsewhere. I take the Minister's point with regard to whether or not this has been superseded by the Privacy Act-that is, the one from last year. I am not sure that that is the case. I submit that because the Government has gone ahead with this particular clause in this Bill it has some doubts as to whether that is covered by the Privacy Act. In any event I do not think we need to take up the legal exercises. I think we can address ourselves quite particularly to the Electoral Commission.

I remind Senator Ray of one of the principles he set himself very early on as Chairman of the Electoral Reform Committee. That was to put in one Act all the references to elections so that people would not be required to go elsewhere. They would have a complete compendium in one Act. I support that principle. I think it is an excellent principle with regard to this area. Whether this is covered in the Privacy Act or not it bears repetition. I do not believe it is covered and hence I have moved the amendment that has been circulated. If it is not carried I would most definitely support Government amendment No. 5 which enables the exclusion that was offered last year with regard to commercial operations. I believe that we should not go down that track. We should limit ourselves directly.

I do not know what the view of the Electoral Commissioner is with regard to this particular matter but I know from past discussions on the Electoral Reform Committee that the Electoral Commission would be quite happy not to respond to the vast number of requests it gets to do detailed searches of its information. It is a time consuming and expensive exercise. Giving a protection such as is in the amendment that I have moved will mean that the Electoral Commission can spend the little money that it gets doing the job it is required to do-that is, to keep the rolls up to date and to keep the system operating as well as it has been able to do in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has before it three amendments which have been moved by the Government. I am not sure whether we formally have before us the amendment moved by Senator Macklin.
—It is before the Chair.

—I indicate in relation to those amendments that the Opposition supports amendment No. 4 which is a purely procedural and mechanical amendment. In relation to amendment No. 5, we regret that the Government has proceeded on the basis of saying that an authority of the Commonwealth which shall have access in certain circumstances to the details held by the Electoral Commission which do not appear on the printed roll, shall be an authority of the Commonwealth other than those which have been excluded from the operation of this subsection. We believe that the correct procedure should have been that they would have been available to those authorities of the Commonwealth which had been included in the regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, we have a situation where all of the Commonwealth authorities are included unless specifically excluded. The process of exclusion is done by regulation. The regulations are disallowable instruments. As such, the Senate is faced with this problem: if we disallow the regulation it means that that authority has access. The Government should have provided that only those bodies included by regulation should have access. The Senate would then be allowed to determine whether it agreed with the Government that that particular body should have access. That is actually quite an important point because everybody has access unless excluded. The power of the Parliament is such that if it knocks out the regulation which excludes the body that body remains included. What should have happened is that only those bodies included by regulation should have been allowed to have access. We could then have determined by knocking out or by sustaining the regulation whether that was a proper body to have access.

I apologise if the argument sounds convoluted. It seems to me that it is very important that Commonwealth bodies should have been dealt with on the basis of those which are included and therefore have been subject to disallowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure, but doesn't that beg the question of whether they should be included at all? That is what we are really arguing about.

—I am attempting to focus on simply the practicalities, the mechanical steps, which now apply. We would have preferred this clause to say that the Commonwealth authorities shall be those authorities declared by the regulation to be included for the purposes of this section. What has happened is that we have said everybody is in unless excluded. Because they are excluded by regulation, if we knock out the regulation they go back into the available data. I think that is the wrong way to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 24 hours or so in which I have had a copy of these amendments I have not had the opportunity, through the processes of my Party, to get the necessary amendment drafted to put it the other way around. I would be interested in the view of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). If the Minister is persuaded on the basis of the argument that I have put we could stand this clause aside. We are not going to finish this Bill tonight. I understand that the Minister does not intend, for good and proper reasons, to proceed with it tomorrow. As a result, I would be interested to know whether the Minister is prepared to lay aside this amendment and look at whether the regulation should be an inclusive, rather than an exclusive, regulation. If the Minister is not so minded, we will have to come to some judgment on this matter on the way through.

The third Government amendment that we have in front of us, amendment No. 6, is one which I regret to inform the Minister we intend to oppose. We intend to oppose it for this reason: it provides that where a tape or disc has been provided to a political party under section 91 (5) persons shall not use that information for a purpose other than what is described as a permitted purpose in relation to that party. Under subsection (2) that permitted purpose in relation to a political party includes any purpose in connection with an election or referendum; monitoring the accuracy or information contained in a roll; and the performance by a senator or member of the House of Representatives in the discharge of his functions. It seems to me that that says to political parties that if they obtain information from this roll they are not allowed in a non-election period to use that information to pick out particular groups of persons and write to them, for example, asking for donations. They cannot identify particular persons in terms of material that they want to send them which is not directly related to purposes in connection with an election or referendum. In other words, they cannot send them a questionnaire to solicit their views or write to them to ask for a financial donation. It seems to me that, on a reading of the clause as it stands, that would not be a permitted purpose. It is not in connection with an election, it is not in connection with monitoring the accuracy of the roll and it may not be in accordance with the performance by a senator or member of his duty where, for example, the political parties have a code which prevents senators or members from writing to people asking for donations. It seems to me that, under those circumstances, it is an unnecessarily restrictive detail to place upon the political parties. If the Minister says that I am in error in that regard, we can debate the matter a little further in the processes of the Committee.

For the sake of completion, I should indicate to the Committee that the Opposition will support Australian Democrats amendment No. 1, which is to provide a restriction so that the Commission `shall not provide any person with any information which discloses particulars of the occupation, sex or date of birth of electors'. Therefore, I do not intend to canvass the issues raised by Senator Macklin. He has indicated what they are, he has indicated the privacy aspects of the whole thing and, to that extent, I accept the thrust of his argument and indicate that the Opposition parties will support that amendment. We really have two issues in contention. One is whether the question of the prescription of the authorities of the Commonwealth to whom this section applies should be a prescription which is exclusive-those who are not in--

TALK.START.PARA: —If you support Senator Macklin's amendment that doesn't matter.

—Sure, I understand. I am simply saying that, because of the way in which we will vote on these particular matters, it is important to put down for the purposes of the record what those specific issues are. Senator Macklin's amendment causes us to leave out the area which the Minister had previously moved, that is to say, section 9 means quite simply that the authorities of the Commonwealth will have access only to the printed roll which, as Senator Macklin rightly says, if they want to pay for they can get. I raise that matter because I think it is a matter in principle, in terms of the drafting of the legislation, as to how the inclusion or exclusion of bodies should occur. I therefore focus very much upon the question of the impact of proposed new section 91a and what are the permitted purposes in relation to a political party, and I will be most interested to hear what Senator Ray has to say in relation to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the issues raised by Senator Macklin was what is on the enrolment form. The new enrolment form specifies to people enrolling that the information they are providing, including date of birth, may be disclosed to a series of agencies listed on the form, although I note that that would probably leave us with two categories of people in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument is not a matter of privacy. I wish it were. I think that Senator Macklin is wrong when he says that the electoral commissioners are expressing a lot of concern over this matter. On my memory of it, their major concern, the thing that drove them bonkers, was freedom of information requests by private individuals. I have just had a memory lapse and I cannot remember whether we have ever blocked that in the Act. But that is what was driving them mad-inquiry agents, real estate agents and solicitors all making these sorts of requests. I think we went some way towards resolving that problem by making microfiches available in all Commonwealth centres and telling people to look there, so that is probably resolved.

This is not a privacy problem; it is an efficiency problem. We cannot protect the privacy of individuals' names and addresses. We have to print those every two years. We have to make a roll, except for the silent roll, available to everyone and the worst thing we could have is an unchallengeable roll. In terms of its use by other government agencies, it is basically an efficiency matter.

Probably all that the amendment will mean is that those who do not move over a four or five year period will always get caught by the agencies, because they can get a printed roll and catch them, but those constantly on the move, even though most people tend to update their enrolments, will tend not to get caught. Obviously, though, there are privacy matters involved. I do not think it would break the electoral commissioners' hearts if they were prohibited from supplying other government agencies with information. I think we all have some doubts about the exchange of information, but when the pressure comes on, to do with drugs, tax evasion, et cetera, we tend to lower that resistance and try to use every weapon available to catch the people involved. There is no doubt that the Department of Social Security has tracked down a lot of people who were committing fraud. In child maintenance matters, the electoral roll becomes critical for the disclosure of the sort of information needed to track people down.

There is no doubt that, if this prohibition is carried, enrolment will go up ever so slightly, as people will believe that they cannot get tracked down, therefore they may as well go on the roll. So in general the Government will oppose Senator Macklin's view. I am not surprised that the Liberals will support it. For 30 years in government, they exchanged information with the Electoral Commission or the Electoral Office. Suddenly now, in Opposition, they have decided not to and I dare say that, if they get back into government, it will be one of the first things they try to do.

On the latter of the two matters raised by Senator Puplick, I do not have an interpretation of the restriction of rights concerning the use of the roll by members and senators. I know that that is not the intention. The main intention is that someone cannot flog it off to Reader's Digest or someone else. That is the basis-no commercial use and no misuse. That is the intention. If the Opposition considers that the clauses do not cover it well enough, I guess it becomes a matter of interpretation. I am quite satisfied that it will not prohibit a member of parliament from carrying out any particular action at any particular time.

As for the way the other clause is structured, it will not matter much if Senator Macklin's amendment is carried, so at this stage I will not offer to set aside the clause. I have no objection to that process of setting it aside and coming back to it. I could offer to set it aside now, but I think it will die about five minutes hence if Senator Macklin's amendment is carried, so that will not be necessary. Senator Puplick might be right. I have listened to his argument. My initial reaction was to draw it to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) to see whether he wanted to change it when it went to the House of Representatives. But, if it is not going to arrive in that form, he will not have to.

There is not much else I can say on these clauses except to reiterate that they were not in the original amendment. They were prompted by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It is still our belief that the privacy provisions in the Privacy Act provide sufficient safeguards. If Senator Macklin's amendment is carried, it will disarm government too much in its attempts to eliminate a whole variety of fraud on the Commonwealth. As I say, it is not strictly a privacy matter when it comes to the Electoral Commission. It is when it comes to the immigration area of my Department or to the Australian Customs Service-it is strictly a privacy matter then. But here we have names and addresses on rolls.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mine doesn't affect that.

—Not with date of birth, which just means that 50 Sally Smiths get chased up rather than one. That is what it means. There is no way we can stop departments from using rolls as a way of tracking people down. The best thing that could come out of it, although I doubt that it will, for fiscal reasons, is that the rolls would have to be reprinted more often. People in this country seem to be old fashioned and want something printed in their hand rather than go to microfiche. I think that it would be a backward step to carry Senator Macklin's amendment, but if the numbers are not here, so be it. It will not break the heart of the Electoral Commission, but it will impair other government agencies in carrying out their duties. That is a pity because I do not think that the rolls have been abused and misused in the last couple of years in particular, when a little more observance and basic privacy have obtained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment first on the point raised by Senator Puplick with regard to the disallowance argument. I take his point. I think it is a good one. Hopefully the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) will draw it to the attention of the drafters because the way this is done disarms somewhat the Senate's ability to deal with the matter. What Senator Puplick suggested would be far better. I did not comment on the last of the amendments moved by the Minister with regard to rolls being provided on disc and tape to political parties. We will be supporting that. Senator Puplick made the point that we could, if we wished to, make the point clearer. Proposed new subsection 91a states:

SPEECH.PARA: The permitted purposes in relation to a political party are:
(a) any purpose in connection with an election or referendum . . .

It does not say `during an election period'. That means, on my reading, that, if it were an election period, it would be a very tight exercise. I would imagine that the soliciting of money is a purpose `in connection with an election'. Looking at the money that is about to be spent in the next year certainly it is one of the fundamental elements connected with an election.

I did not read it in the way that Senator Puplick did, although I am mindful that the Electoral Commission has already read down its own interpretation of a number of things that appeared in the Act. I would not necessarily be totally sanguine that the point Senator Puplick made would not occur, because it has already occurred with regard to some other elements in the Act which seemed to us to be pretty clear when we suggested them and which seemed to be clear even when we had passed them. But then somebody else got hold of them who did not seem to understand what we were about and interpreted them in a totally different fashion.

I hope that under the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 people might look at this debate and see quite clearly the purpose that Senator Ray and the Government had in mind and what we have in mind in supporting it-and I remember earlier discussions on this in the Committee-which is that we are not interested in any way in allowing this material to simply become a fundraising exercise by being sold off, as the Minister said, to Readers Digest or someone else, but believe it should be used for legitimate political purposes only. It is provided on a tape or disc, whereas normally political parties get it on paper. All this is doing is providing an electronic exercise. That is interesting because it enables political parties to undertake legitimate exercises that would become massively expensive if they had to work from paper. Since all the material has already been put on tape, it seems an unnecessary cost, particularly as a lot of that cost could be recycled through Consolidated Revenue by way of the public funding exercise. I know that Senator Puplick does not like that, but unfortunately he will have to accept the money after the next election and cry as he goes to the bank to pay for the cost of winning or losing government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Losing government.

—Actually, I was referring to Senator Puplick. With regard to the last point about restriction of information going to other departments, one of the basic problems of the privacy exercise is that it restricts information. I do not think there is anything terribly new about that. Indeed, I remember some discussions on the Australia Card when the Committee informally-and this included the Liberals on the Committee and me-said that, if the Australia Card went ahead, in terms of that vast amount of information it would make eminent sense for there to be some connection with the electoral information so we could actually use it for keeping the rolls up to date in a very cheap way. If one was going down that route, one would not want to cut off the operation. The Australia Card did not come about and, instead, the Government itself has moved to take up a number of the privacy concerns out there in the community. In keeping with that, I think this is well within that exercise. Departments will be able to get names and addresses and will be able to operate with them in the same way that anybody else in the community can. What they will not be able to get hold of is the information which is not publicly provided.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Minister to the question that I had on the private rolls. I suppose it becomes academic if my amendment is carried. Was there an intent in terms of the private rolls? Was there any discussion about where the private rolls would fall in regard to the ability of the Electoral Commission to provide information on private rolls to other departments? As I read it, this amendment would in no way exclude the Electoral Commission from handing on all the material in private rolls to various people. I would have thought that was quite contrary to what we did in establishing those private rolls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate for the sake of the record that, having heard Senator Ray on this matter, we will continue to support Senator Macklin's amendment. That amendment provides that `except as otherwise provided by this Act' the Electoral Commission shall not do certain things. Therefore, I presume that, when that is carried, later in the debate before this Bill is concluded in the Senate and goes down to the House of Representatives the Government can simply include a clause which states that bodies shall be included for the purposes of this section by regulation. That will then allow each individual body which the Government seeks to include to be prescribed by regulation. That will overcome the situation with which Senator Ray has difficulty, because clearly the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Federal Police, the Narcotics Bureau, or whatever it happens to be, ought to have access to the information. If we proceed, depending on how the Australian Democrats vote, we will vote for Government amendment No. 5 and insert a new subsection in the Act and then vote for the Democrats' amendment No. 1, which excludes amendment No. 5 and substitutes a new amendment. Or the easiest thing would be to simply vote against Government amendment No. 5.
—Now that I know how you are going, Senator, I am happy to do it that way.

—Precisely. So we will not put something in and then take it out again. Because this debate will continue on another day, the Government will be given the time to come back with an amendment, which we will support, that says that, in relation to what will then be section 91 (9), bodies may be prescribed by regulation for the purposes of this subsection. That will allow the Government to determine which bodies ought to have access to that information. It will be able to do that by regulation, the regulations will come to the Senate and the Senate will be able to decide, on an issue by issue or authority by authority basis, whether they should have access. As a result, the Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security or the Australian Federal Police can be looked at as each regulation is made. That is the correct way to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I persist in indicating my opposition to Government amendment No. 6, not because I object to the tenor of proposed new subsection 91b but because I object to the tenor of proposed new subsection 91a. Both Senator Ray and Senator Macklin are of the view that a permitted purpose is any purpose in connection with an election or referendum, but I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that in public funding provisions of this legislation there is a clear distinction drawn between maintenance and campaign as far as funding is concerned. In other words, if one writes to somebody seeking a donation for the purposes of an election campaign, that is clearly identified as being a specific exercise which attracts certain provisions of the public funding parts of this legislation-and which has to be dealt with in a specific manner. But if one writes to people for the purposes of soliciting money, or if one receives money, for the purposes of party maintenance, a different regime applies.

The concern which the Opposition parties have about 91a concerns what would happen if one were to write to somebody using the information obtained from the tape or disc. For example, we might decide to write to all persons within particular postcodes because that is an area where we think we are more likely to obtain financial support for the maintenance of our political party. At the moment if a person has the hard copy, the printed roll, it is a difficult exercise to go through and mark out everybody who is in that particular postcode area. But if that information is on a tape or disc all a person has to do is punch in the postcode number and he will get a printout which indicates all of the persons in that particular postcode district.

If we write to them and say, `We are writing to you on behalf of the Liberal Party or the National Party to seek your support for the provision of funds for the maintenance of the party'-bearing in mind that maintenance funds do not have to be disclosed in precisely the same way as campaign funds-it seems to me that that is potentially a breach of subclause 91a (2) because it is not a purpose in connection with an election or a referendum. It is not a purpose in relation to the accuracy of the information and it is not a purpose in relation to the performance by a senator or a member of the duties of a senator or a member.

To that extent, despite the fact that we now have Senator Robert Ray's indication that he does not believe that to be the case and Senator Macklin's indication that he does not believe that to be the case-and when the vote is taken, therefore, clearly an indication that a majority of the Senate does not believe that to be the case-if an electoral commissioner or if a person who has to pronounce some judicial opinion on the matter simply chooses to ignore what has been said in the course of the to and fro of this debate he is entirely entitled to do so. Under those circumstances we believe that this is a significant restriction on the capacity of the political party in this regard. I do not resile from the point that I make in relation to the political requirements and the political advantage of my Party and of the National Party that that is a restriction which we think unfair and improper.
I draw attention to the fact that the penalty is a derisory penalty. One thousand dollars is a pretty derisory penalty but it does, nevertheless, involve--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think of $50?

—I think the point at issue is quite simply that whether the fine is $50, $1,000 or $50,000 it involves a potential conviction; it involves a potential recording against a particular person. I presume that it may be the signatory of the appeal letter. It will be interesting to see whether, if the signatory of the appeal letter is Mr Hawke, Mr Peacock or Senator Haines, the electoral commissioner decides to proceed; whereas if it is Joe Blow, campaign manager from Barton or campaign manager for Aston or campaign manager for Capricornia, the electoral commissioner may be perhaps a little more minded to proceed. People ought not to have a conviction recorded against them for going about what we believe to be a legitimate purpose in relation to the ongoing business of the conduct of politics in this country. Therefore, I say in conclusion that Government amendment No. 4 is fine. We will support that. In relation to Government amendment No. 5, now, clearly with the view of the Democrats, we will oppose that amendment. We will oppose Government amendment No. 6 and we will support Australian Democrats amendment No. 1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly raise a couple of points. Senator Macklin raises the question of those on the silent roll. I do not see any conflict with that being provided to certain agencies. It is basically a silent roll to protect certain members of the public. Those who have availed themselves of that tend to be people in violent domestic situation, people in a law and order position, judges of the Family Court of Australia. So I do not really see that as a major problem. I admire Senator Puplick's dexterity. I could almost hear the penny drop as he spoke when he said he would support Senator Macklin's amendment, and that was that. Now he is suggesting that Senator Macklin's amendment be carried but has provided a way in the Act that he will later support to bring everybody back into the ball game. Senator Macklin had a big win there for about five or 10 minutes. That is probably down the drain now.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that if the Government is forced to bring back a list of the agencies, it gives this chamber a good opportunity to look at that list of agencies. I have more of a feeling that it should be in legislation rather than in regulations so that we could have a good look at it on the spot. But we will do that. In regard to amendment No. 6, Senator Puplick's interpretation is not my interpretation. I note Senator Puplick's reference to $1,000 as a paltry fine. The Opposition senators have been carrying on like pork chops when a New South Wales Party secretary was fined $50 and his character was cleared by the relevant magistrate. He must be almost a saint by now by Senator Puplick's--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not almost a saint; almost a senator.

—Like Senator Puplick, if he ever does become a senator, he will make it without facing the people first. In conclusion could I suggest a more appropriate procedural matter. I ask for the permission of the Committee that the question on amendment No. 4 be put first; Senator Macklin's amendment could be put second. If that is carried then we will withdraw amendment No. 5 and then we could put amendment No. 6. That seems to me to be a more sensible way of approaching the matter.

—I think that seems all right. I am just not quite sure that amendment No. 4 should not be put last so that we can work out whether `is' or `are' will be the correct wording in the amendment. In some respects it is a matter of working backwards to determine whether we are in the singular or the plural in terms of amendments.

-In light of what Senator Puplick has invited the Government to do and in the light of the fact that Senator Robert Ray has avidly grasped at the straw and hence the whole matter will be changed, it seems to me that if we are not to finish this matter tonight we should put the whole thing off. Some of the points that Senator Puplick raised with regard to clause 91a seem to indicate to me that he has doubts about it. There are easier ways of doing what the Government intends and what we support. One way of doing that might be in keeping with what has already been suggested by Senator Puplick. For example, the clause could state that a person shall not use information obtained by means of a tape or disc except for a purpose that is a purpose by regulation. In other words, it might be useful not to deal with this particular section at the moment. The Government may wish to look at it again. I invite the Government to do so. If it does not want to, we will be supporting it. It seems to me that if the Government wants to look at it again we will be happy to do so. I think it would be useful to look at the first amendments again. Instead of voting in amendments that we would then have to take back out it would seem to me to be more sensible to put them aside and for the Government to come back with an amendment that is acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is of the view that proposed new section 96a should be opposed. In other words, we are opposing the amendment proposed by the Government which relates to the question of the enrolment of prisoners. This is one of the significant issues which I raised in my speech in the second reading debate and it has been raised by a number of other senators. Proposed section 96a has to be read in conjunction with elements of Schedule 3. We find ourselves in an odd position in this sense: in the bulk of the legislation the Government is proposing an arrangement for the enrolment of prisoners so that they may be electors and in the schedule to the Bill it is removing those sections of the Act which currently disenfranchise certain people who are in prison. So I think it is fair to characterise this as legislatively putting the cart before the horse.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the Government should first of all have dealt in the Bill with the question of the removal of the prohibition on certain prisoners voting which, after all, is contained in section 93 of the principal Act. I really do believe that it is unfortunate-and I choose my words carefully-that an issue which is as significant as the question of the enrolment of prisoners should in fact be found in schedule 3 to the Bill under the heading `Minor Amendments of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918'. The relevant parts in the schedule relate to paragraph 93 (8)(a), 93 (8)(b), section 109 and subsection 110 (1) of the principal Act. We believe that they should have been incorporated in the main body of the legislation. If they were, we could then deal with the enrolment of prisoners under the proposed regime established by new section 96a.

I do not believe that the enfranchisement of prisoners previously disenfranchised is a minor matter and it should not have been in the schedule to the Bill. In fact, I think that is a pretty unfortunate and somewhat less than satisfactory way of dealing with such a major issue. When we get to schedule 3, we propose to move a series of amendments to delete the four parts that I have just mentioned. However, we first of all have to deal with clause 35 of the Bill which seeks to put in place proposed new section 96a.

Proposed new section 96a provides a regime which will make sense only, it seems to me, if schedule 3 is carried. The proposed new section relates to a number of prisoners who would, nevertheless, be entitled to vote even under the existing provisions of the Act because their sentences are not of sufficient length to disenfranchise them. Nevertheless, we believe that we should start by in fact opposing this proposed new section. It is certainly true that some prisoners have the right to vote. They retain that right because their sentences are not of sufficient length of time to disenfranchise them. The proposed new section relates to those prisoners in addition to prisoners who might be enfranchised. If schedule 3 in its printed form is passed, certain things will flow. Proposed new section 96a (1) provides:
A person who is serving a sentence of imprisonment is entitled to remain enrolled for the Subdivision (if any) for which the person was enrolled when he or she began serving the sentence.
A series of proposals are then set out. Frankly, we have some real concerns about subsection (2) of the proposed new section. Subsection (2) states:
An eligible person who is serving a sentence of imprisonment but who was not enrolled when he or she began serving the sentence is entitled to be enrolled for:
The subdivision then specifies a number of areas. Paragraph (a) states:
the Subdivision for which the person was entitled to be enrolled at that time;

That is to say, they shall be put on the roll that they were entitled to be on when they go into prison even if they had not put themselves on the roll prior to going in to prison. In other words, they will be put on the electoral roll as a consequence of their going to prison. Does it necessarily mean that one has to make an application when one goes into prison to be put on the roll or will one be automatically enrolled at the time one is convicted? If that is the case, I think it is ridiculous. Paragraph (b) states:
if the person was not so entitled, a Subdivision for which any of the person's next of kin is enrolled . . .
I mean, really! Since when have we had a decision under Commonwealth electoral law that a person not convicted of anything--

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you read the section on itinerants? It is exactly the same, and you voted for it.
—We are not about to start equating the rights of prisoners with the rights of itinerants. Paragraph (c) states:

SPEECH.PARA: if neither of paragraphs (a) and (b) is applicable, the Subdivision in which the person was born; and . . .

Crown Street Women's Hospital is not mentioned in the subsection. Nevertheless, I am sure that there are a fair number of people who, in terms of any of the major city maternity hospitals, would claim that they were entitled to that particular enrolment. Paragraph (d) states:
if none of the preceding paragraphs is applicable, the subdivision with which the person has the closest connection.

Again, that seems to me to be a pretty extraordinary type of situation. In some instances, the person about whom we are speaking will in fact not have his next of kin anywhere in the country. The next of kin might not have been born in this country and may not have been enrolled at the time the person went into prison.

I suppose that, taking it to its logical conclusion, the Opposition would have only a minor degree of concern about proposed subsection (2) (a). However, paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) present certain other problems. The fundamental problem that they raise is this: we believe that a person who was not enrolled at the time he was sentenced to prison should not be placed on the electoral roll as a consequence of being sent to prison. This seems to me to be a quite illogical type of situation.

The substantive debate will be on schedule 3 where the fundamental issue of principle is to be resolved-namely, whether a person under sentence, who has been convicted of an offence which carries a certain penalty, should or should not be entitled to vote. That is the issue of principle and that will be argued when we come eventually to schedule 3. Nevertheless, certain things flow as a consequence of our general view on this matter. We regard proposed new section 96a as a quite unsatisfactory method of dealing with either those prisoners to be enfranchised if schedule 3 is passed or those prisoners who are currently under sentence but, nevertheless, still entitled to vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I find the objections taken by the Opposition to this particular amendment somewhat strange. The principal Act was amended for another group-itinerant electors-as a result of a report from the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform. The impetus behind that exercise was to provide an ability for everybody in this country to vote. When the Committee looked into this it found a whole series of categories of people who for one reason or another had been deprived of the vote because the system was not flexible enough to enable them to be included on the roll. An example of that might be the workers at an Antarctic base. Quite elaborate systems have been devised to enable that to occur. People who were overseas for a period were often disenfranchised, as were people working in diplomatic missions or in the armed forces. Within Australia itinerant workers and prisoners were often disenfranchised because the system was not flexible enough to contain them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick got a bit upset by proposed new section 96a (2) (b), which refers to next of kin. Section 96 (1) (c) of the principal Act, which relates to a person who is entitled to have his name on the roll but has not been on the roll for whatever reason, states that such a person can apply to have his name added to the roll. It reads:
Where a person . . . applies to . . . have his name added to the Roll for a Subdivision in the State that is-
(c) the Subdivision for which the person's next of kin or, if the person has more than 1 next of kin, one of the person's next of kin, is enrolled at the time when the application is made . . .
That was supported last time around. Section 96 (1) (d) states:
the Subdivision for which the person last had an entitlement to be enrolled;
(e) the Subdivision in which the person was born; or
(f) in a case in which there is no Subdivision for enrolment for which the person can apply in pursuance of paragraph (c), (d) or (e)-the Subdivision with which the person has the closest connection.

In other words, the principles that are applied in this amendment are taken from the Act which already exists. The group of people, the itinerant workers, who do not have a particular place of abode are picked up. I find it very difficult to understand why the Opposition takes objection to the method of finding out where we should enrol eligible prisoners, enabling them to select from a range of subdivisions in the same way as itinerant electors.

The other reason provided by the Opposition is that it felt it was not acceptable that a person who was not enrolled should be enrolled as a result of going to prison. Quite frankly, I find that an extraordinary reason for voting against this measure. The exercise of enrolment under this legislation is to make people accept an obligation. There is not an obligation to be enrolled, but there is an obligation to vote once enrolled. I would have thought that the reverse would be the case; that is, that the Opposition should be reasonably happy that we had induced people to put themselves on the roll as part of an exercise, as it were, of coming back into the mainstream. If prisons are to be seen as places where people are rehabilitated, then I cannot see any objection to the exercise whereby somebody who is in prison for whatever time-it may be a very short time; it could be a matter of weeks or even days-is sought to be placed on the roll. There is no provision and no structure to enable prison authorities to do that.

Remembering that all the prison authorities are State authorities, I do not think any of them will necessarily pursue this as one of their top priorities. I doubt whether in looking at what has occurred in the past we should get excited at the number of people who were on the rolls and who actually voted. In fact, the disparity between the various States in terms of prisoners enrolled and voting is so extraordinary that at one stage I tried to find out why in some prisons people were voting and in others they were not voting at all. It seems very much to do with the prison authorities and whether they see it as a matter of importance. There is no particular provision to get the State authorities to do anything about this matter, but we are saying that, if this occurs, we have to have a mechanism for slotting prisoners into a subdivision. The method the Government has chosen is obviously the correct one; that is, to take the Act as it already stands with regard to another class of voters-itinerant electors-and to use that, since it has already been accepted by the Parliament and has been in operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Puplick is under a total misapprehension. There is no automatic enrolment for prisoners under proposed new section 96a (2). I think the key words there are `entitled to be enrolled for'. That is what the clause says. If a prisoner does not fill out an enrolment card he will not be on the roll. No pressure is to be put on prisoners. Senator Puplick's implication that they are automatically put on the roll or forced on the roll is a total red herring and is not covered in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision to allow prisoners certain voting rights went through with some support in this Parliament from all quarters. The dividing line was about five years and they all supported that. What was not given much thought was where the people would be enrolled. A lot of thought was given to that point previously on the question of itinerants. It has now been decided to give that thought to prisoners. It probably would be undesirable to make all prisoners enrol in the electorate in which their prison is located. Let us face it-in a marginal electorate many Liberals would go to gaol just so that they could enrol there, or whatever. It would be open to a manipulation of all sorts, especially in State government seats, I would have thought. I do not think prisoners very often vote for the incumbent State government. I do not think that party lines matter much there; they vote for whoever is out of power rather than who is in power.

I point out that these clauses are hierarchical; that is, the prisoners do not get a choice. Most of the people that these provisions will apply to are 17-, 18- and 19-year-olds who are not yet on the roll. In some cases the reason for someone not being on the roll is that he was in prison before the age of 18, before he could get on the roll. We also have to remember that some of these people have a highly mobile lifestyle. That is why their charge sheet reads, `place of abode or address unknown. No normal address applies.' Therefore, I think that these provisions are utterly suitable. I wonder why the Liberal representatives on the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform did not object to them. As I recall, they supported this particular set of provisions. I would also have to argue that they strongly opposed those mentioned by Senator Puplick which come later in the schedule. This merely puts more detail into the Act. As I say, there was no objection with regard to itinerants. There is no implication in this set of provisions that anyone will be forced to be enrolled when he is not on the roll. It will merely aid the Australian Electoral Commission and everyone concerned to determine which electorate a person will be enrolled in. I also think it is an appropriate order that if a person has an address at the time of his arrest that address can be taken as a place where he can be enrolled; if not, the other three paragraphs can apply in hierarchical order. In most cases paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) will not have to apply, thank goodness, but in some cases they might have to. I think all this clause has done is give Senator Puplick a bit of a dry run at the later clauses in the schedule which we may get to, at the current rate, some time in December.
Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 36, after clause 53, insert the following new clause:
``53a. The Principal Act is amended by inserting the following section after section 206:
How-to-vote posters in polling booths

`206a. (1) In providing and furnishing proper polling booths for the purpose of paragraph 203 (1) (a), the Divisional Returning Officer shall ensure that there is displayed in each separate voting compartment a poster formed from the how-to-vote cards submitted to the Officer by candidates in the election.
`(2) How-to-vote cards submitted to inclusion in posters under subsection (1) shall be:
(a) in the prescribed form;
(b) submitted in a quantity determined by the Divisional Returning Officer;
(c) received by the Divisional Returning Officer not later than 7 days before polling day; and
(d) such that each how-to-vote card submitted by or on behalf of the same candidate or group of candidates is in identical form.'.''.

This matter goes back quite some time. Indeed, in the first report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in September 1983, I submitted a minority report on the banning of how-to-vote cards at polling booths and urged that a couple of other methods be used that would enable that process to be carried out in the way that senators or members wished. Since this issue has been around some significant changes have been made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. For example, the names of political parties have been put on the ballot paper. We have had the introduction of the above and below the line Senate voting, or the ticket voting system as an option. We have sought quite deliberately to reduce the number of informal votes by providing additional information to electors about the nature of the activity that they are engaged in.

This amendment is not a new suggestion in the Australian context. If we look, for example, at section 246 of the Tasmanian Electoral Act 1985, we see that it specifies that the distribution of voting material, such as how-to-vote cards, handbills, et cetera, is banned on polling day. There are many good reasons why the Federal system should now follow the lead given by Tasmania. First of all, let us take as a base 10 million voters going into the polling booths. Undoubtedly, each voter would receive a minimum of three and a maximum of five how-to-vote cards, so we are looking at between 30 and 50 million being provided at that point. With the number of new political parties currently being registered at a rate of knots, if they ever get around to handing out how-to-vote cards there will be a question mark over how voters will be able to get into the polling booths.

Many voters object very strongly to what goes on outside the polling booths. They see it as almost having to run the gauntlet to get in there. In order to maintain the secrecy of their ballot, most people accept all of the how-to-vote cards offered to them. If one takes simply a Labor, Democrat, Liberal or National Party how-to-vote card, it is like disclosing one's voting intention. Of course, it does not necessarily do anything of the sort but it is seen as breaking secrecy. Some people do it quite deliberately and openly; others simply take all of the cards.

In estimating how many how-to-vote cards are needed, most political parties take the number of electors in the electorate and add at least 10 per cent to account for differences in the way they may be used at polling booths. Some polling booths pick up more than others. The main consolidated polling booths are in the capital cities where special how-to-vote cards are printed. Then there are the interstate how-to-vote cards. The major polling booths-for example, in Queensland, the Sunshine Coast, the Gold Coast and Brisbane-have to have their how-to-vote cards provided generally from Victoria and New South Wales. That is a massive exercise, which is a legitimate electoral expense and hence is able to be paid for from public funding. So it is no longer purely a party matter. It is capable of being paid for from Consolidated Revenue and hence the general population has an interest in this.

If we take 40 million as the average number, being halfway between 30 million and 50 million, of how-to-vote cards needed, we will need about 150 tonnes of paper, involving some 75 hectares of forest, for one Federal election. I suppose one could say that it was a necessary item if there were not other methods. In some States the how-to-vote cards are a necessity. For example, in my State of Queensland the State Government has resisted putting party designations on the ballot papers as doing so enabled voters to have a better chance of working out on their own who they want to vote for and how they wish to distribute their preferences. So in that sense one could argue reasons for them.

Many people do see the need for how-to-vote cards. They like to vote the way that a particular political party suggests. Senator Ray can probably correct me on this if I am wrong, but I think that for the 1985 election, when the analysis was done of the ballot papers in a number of seats to establish the informal vote structure, it was clearly obvious that the vast bulk of people used the how-to-vote cards. This is not surprising in, say, New South Wales, where the ballot paper can have 75 or 76 candidates. It would be amazing if a person were able to come up with the same permutation of numbers as on a political party's how-to-vote card without having used such a card. Therefore, it would be obvious that a voter had placed the candidates in the same sequence as on the how-to-vote card. As I have said, most people do use a how-to-vote card. That is probably a good reason for providing them, at least in some fashion.

In 1983 I made a couple of suggestions of alternative ways that this could be done. One was the poster a la the South Australian method and another was to provide them in self-dispensing boxes at the polling booths. So it could be done in a variety of ways. In my amendment I have chosen the method which has now been tested in a couple of State elections in South Australia, and presumably will be tested again when the next South Australian election is called. This involves getting from each of the political parties its designated how-to-vote card and displaying them in the voting compartment in such a way that they cannot be defaced and are there for each person using that voting compartment. This method would provide all the information normally provided through those 40 million pieces of paper. Nobody would be deprived of any of the information currently available, yet it would result in a massive saving on paper, which in this country is a relatively precious resource.

If we look at voting systems and the habits adopted by voters, Tasmanian voters have had that prohibition in their Electoral Act for a long period and there is a very high below the line Senate vote. Also, in their method of voting at the State level they have shown a very deliberate use of their vote. These things are tied together over time. The hope is that a more educated and more interested electorate will determine how to vote prior to going to the polling booth. That is what I am sure all senators in this place hope will occur. One method of doing that is to get people to make their choice prior to polling day instead of waiting for the how-to-vote cards. Some political parties are addressing this by the provision of information prior to the election by way of advertisements in newspapers, letterbox drops or whatever, in which they set out all the candidates running in the election. The hope is that individual voters will see that there is an advantage in working out their own how-to-vote card independently of what the parties determine.

I think every senator in this place has come across people who believe that they have to vote in the way which the how-to-vote card sets out. That is often promoted because people in political parties find that is the best way of dealing with matters. It is not the case; people are entitled to vote by putting down numbers consecutively in any way they wish, even giving one vote within a particular party group and giving their second vote to a second party group. That additional knowledge and understanding on the part of the voters is something that should be supported. Moving away from that open display outside would add to that movement and would say to people that it is a good and valuable thing if they work out their own how-to-vote cards prior to coming to the polling booth and casting their ballot. After all, we are asking them to vote for a government in their own country only once every three years. It is not a major imposition that we are asking them to engage in. To have made up their minds prior to coming to the polling booth is something that we ought to be able to expect of all conscientious voters.

As I said, my amendment is modelled on section 66 of the South Australian Electoral Act in terms of posters. I believe it is a method which has been tried and which works. The bugs that existed in the initial system in South Australia have now been ironed out. The South Australians have the same type of information that everybody else has. It is not a matter of depriving anybody of any information. It is seeking to save a vast amount of paper. It is seeking to save that harassment at the polls. I think it is a streamlined method of dealing with something that over time has become a massive annoyance to electors as they approach their task of selecting the government of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the Government is minded to support this particular amendment put forward by Senator Macklin. I have listened to his arguments over the years on this question. Our first objection relates to practicality. Senator Macklin says that it works in South Australia. I do not know how many people had a look at the how-to-vote cards or posters that were used in the last Senate election in the various States. The poster in Victoria was so large that, if Senator Boswell and I stood shoulder to shoulder, no-one could see us behind it. That gives people an idea of the size of the poster.
—Nothing is that large!

—I do not tell a lie; that is how big the poster was. How are we going to fit that inside a voting cubicle? Clearly Senator Macklin has thought it out and knows that it has to be behind glass, otherwise it will be defaced. Then again we have arguments. Who goes on top? Are we allowed to have party colours? Why can we not have our ethnic how-to-vote advice in nine or 15 languages? The bottom line is that practicality makes it impossible. I believe we could probably do it for the House of Representatives by itself. We could probably fit it in, given current nomination practices. But in the Senate it becomes a nightmare. It is an infringement on some people's voting rights if they cannot get a how-to-vote card. If it is so small that it cannot be read, then it is useless. We cannot make voting cubicles big enough to accommodate the Boswells and Rays of this world together; it is just impossible. Think of the cost of that and the storage and everything else. It is simply impossible.

SPEECH.PARA: The other reasons adduced by Senator Macklin are more interesting. He should go to the Norm Sanders school of how to put a case when his heart is not really in it and self-interest is really overriding. Senator Macklin, for all his ability in this chamber, has never been good at carrying a proposition that involves self-interest for the Australian Democrats. It always weakens his argument. His first argument is that we should think of the paper we will save. By the next election we will all be using recycled paper for how-to-vote cards. If we cannot buy that paper we will have to make our how-to-vote cards look like recycled paper. We will not have much choice in that. We will all make sure that it is collected and recycled again for another election or for another form of paper. It really comes back to the fact that every three years that amount of paper is not that enormous compared to the paper we see scattered around here and throughout the community.

The next argument adduced by Senator Macklin is that it is very hard to get in to vote because all the people are jostling outside with their how-to-vote cards. It is a lot easier these days because it is pretty hard to find a Democrat in a polling place, which has sometimes been a matter for regret. I do not think we would have drawn the Nunawading election if the Democrats had manned all the booths or, to use a less sexist word for Senator Boswell, staffed all the booths. I cannot get out of the old habit either. Staffing polling booths is what this amendment is all about. The Democrats cannot do it. They have a very low base membership of their political party. They are not that different from the others. They just find it harder because they have to concentrate their efforts in the Senate and therefore would like to have someone outside every polling booth with a how-to-vote card. This proposition is coming forward because of their inability to do so. I understand that. Small parties have some advantages, as do big parties. One of the advantages of the bigger parties is that we can have someone outside every polling booth. But when we go to the electorate we carry other responsibilities and other lead in the saddlebags that small parties do not. These things tend to have a habit of dying out. I would also like to assist the chamber with another argument that I was given in the advice. I have been told that many party activists would feel deprived of one of their most enjoyable duties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That must have been written by a public servant.

—I assure Senator Puplick that no-one beside me here wrote that advice. I ask Senator Faulkner and others: Is that not true? I can remember, after Jack McEwen retired, how wonderful it was to get up at 4 o'clock in the morning and drive to Katandra West to open the Katandra West polling booth at 8 o'clock in the morning. Ninety-four people voted in the 12 hours I was on that booth. I was not there for the whole twelve hours, but for 94 votes we decided to staff that particular booth. One of Senator Boswell's colleagues was there at 8 o'clock in the morning. He abused the living heck out of me for the first hour but, because no-one else was coming through, by 9.30 we were discussing the football, by 12.30 he was shouting me a counter lunch at the local-so we let a few people through without how-to-vote cards-and by the end of the night, when we counted the votes, there was a 10 per cent swing against us-on the only occasion we had ever handed out how-to-vote cards! Some of the local National Party people worked out who the Labor socialist candidate mongrel was and would not vote for him. What a wonderful effort that was. Who would want to deprive themselves of those experiences?
—You stopped the other 100 voting.

—We may well have done that. There were no telephone votes on that particular day. Some of Senator Faulkner's colleagues in New South Wales once insisted on scrutinising a polling booth where they believed people were ringing through their votes. He would remember the circumstances well. We had someone inside all day. The phone would ring and the returning officer would say, `I'm sorry, Joe, you will have to come down to vote'. When they opened the ballot box that night our vote dropped from 40 per cent to 20 per cent. As the local returning officer said, `I was always fair: I used to vote 60 per cent National Party and 40 per cent Labor Party'. We made everyone come in and got a 20 per cent swing against ourselves. That does not always operate to our advantage. I do not think we will do away with how-to-vote cards at the moment. It may come one day with a more simplified voting system, but at the moment it is a bit like disarming in the Middle East-no-one is willing to start first. We will not find any unilateralists on that side or this side to do away with how-to-vote cards.

SPEECH.PARA: I was in Tasmania during the last election. I did not know there was an election on that Saturday because I could not find a polling booth. They do not allow people to hand out how-to-vote cards in that particular State. They are not allowed to canvass within 100 metres of a polling station in that State. What are the booth captains going to do on election day? What are those poor people who love racing around with two-way radios and thermoses of coffee and who get themselves into neurotic tail spins going to do on election day?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the keg at night?

—That is another tradition that these killjoy Democrats may want to do away with; I do not know. But the Government will consistently, right through these clauses, oppose this particular course of action.
