SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes of the time of the Senate to talk about an issue which relates to the price of books in Australia and to a series of reports which have been forthcoming in relation to book pricing in Australia. Earlier today, in the House of Representatives, my colleague Mr Neil Brown, the honourable member for Menzies and shadow Attorney-General, introduced a private member's Bill entitled the Copyright Reform Bill 1989, the purpose of which is to put in place the recommendations of the Copyright Law Review Committee in relation to parallel importing and to the related operations of the Australian book trade and industry. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the brief speech made by Mr Brown in presenting the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr N. A. BROWN (Menzies) (11.00) I present the Copyright Reform Bill 1989. This procedure allows me to introduce a private member's Bill and to make a five minute statement in support of it. I have just introduced the Copyright Reform Bill 1989. It is described as a reform Bill because it will very substantially reform the copyright law in Australia. The Bill, in effect, will implement the recommendations of the Copyright Law Review Committee on imported books and other reproduced articles. The problem that this Bill seeks to resolve arises from the fact that over many years, as many honourable members in this House would realise, readers and booksellers have been quite infuriated by one of the undesirable consequences of the copyright law. It is not necessary for me to explain the details of the copyright law on this occasion.

One of the results of the copyright law is that books published overseas are very often not available in Australia until months, sometimes years, after their publication. Sometimes they are never available despite the fact that they have been published overseas. Indeed, when books are eventually brought to Australia by overseas publishers for sale here the prices of these books are far in excess of any reasonable price and far in excess of the price at which they sell in the country of publication. There has been a lot of evidence to suggest that the increase in prices maybe 10 per cent, 20 per cent or in some cases 30 per cent. This undesirable situation comes about as a result of the provisions of the Copyright Act, which provides that the publisher has copyright in the book and can determine when and where the book is sold.

The Copyright Law Review Committee has investigated this issue and has proposed a series of reforms to the law, which will be implemented by this Bill. Briefly, these reforms provide that overseas publications will be able to be imported and sold here if either of two circumstances arise. The first is where the books are not available here within a reasonable time from when they are available overseas. That is the first situation-the reasonable time test. The second is a more narrow one. It is where a distributor in Australia, for example, a bookseller, has a specific order for an item that a consumer wishes to import but not re-sell; in other words, wants to keep it to read it. The Copyright Law Review Committee recommended draft legislation to implement these proposals. This Bill will incorporate those changes to the Copyright Act. If the Bill becomes law, members of the Australian community will have better access not only to books but also to records and other reproduced articles published overseas. Not only will they have access to them but also they will be able to buy them at lower prices and with much earlier delivery times than are presently available.

I hope the Government will support this Bill. At the same time, I hope that the Government will respond to the recommendations of the Prices Surveillance Authority, which recommended virtually complete deregulation of the industry of the distribution of books and other reproduced articles. The recommendations of the Copyright Law Review Committee are milder than those of the Prices Surveillance Authority. There is now an onus on the Government to show any reason, if there is any, why the recommendations of the Prices Surveillance Authority should not also be implemented. That response-I can understand that the Government may need a few weeks to examine the Bill-should not be allowed to delay the Copyright Law Review Committee proposals, which I now propose in this Bill should be put into law.

It is a very healthy example of micro-economic reform. In many areas the Government has been dragging the chain on micro-economic reform, and here is a very good example. The Government should pick up the ball and run with it, accept this Bill, take it over as a government Bill and make sure that it is passed and put into law as soon as possible. Consumers will benefit; purchasers will benefit; industry and commerce and the economy will benefit. Nothing can really be said against this Bill. Therefore, I hope that in the interests of all buyers and readers of books, the Government will support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The purpose of Mr Brown's Bill was to put in place the recommendations of the Sheppard committee, the Copyright Law Review Committee, which reported in September 1988 on a reference entitled `The importation provisions of the Copyright Act 1968'. I do not intend to take the time of the chamber tonight to go through all of those recommendations; rather, I seek the indulgence of the chamber to incorporate in Hansard the Committee's recommendations, which appear in paragraphs 2 and 3 of the Committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS

2. The principal question which has concerned the Committee in this Reference is whether it should recommend the repeal of the importation provisions of the Copyright Act 1968 in their application to non-pirated articles, i.e. parallel imports. The Reference has involved the Committee in a lengthy consideration of submissions from a great many interests. The Committee's inquiries have covered a number of copyright areas, the principal being those of books, sound recordings, films and computer software. Additionally, it has considered the question of copyright in labels attached to articles which are not themselves the subject of copyright protection. The Committee has unanimously reached the conclusion that the sections should continue to apply to parallel imports, but that their application to such imports should be relaxed in a number of respects.
3. Committee's recommendations are:
(1) The Copyright Act be amended so as to modify the provisions of ss. 37 and 102 (infringement by importation for the purposes of trade, for example, sale or hire) in the following respects:
(a) The importation of a non-pirated copyright article by a person engaged in trade or commerce be permitted without the licence or other permission of the owner of the copyright if:
(i) The article is not available in Australia, and will not, within a reasonable time, be available in Australia, from the copyright owner or his or her licensee or agent; OR

(ii) Although the article is available in Australia, the importer has received a specific order in writing for the article signed by the person requiring it in which that person states that the article is not required for the purposes of trade or commerce.
(b) The onus of establishing the matters specified in paras. (a) (i) and (ii) be upon the importer.

(c) For the purposes of para. (a) (i), an article shall be taken to be unavailable in Australia if the importer, after reasonable investigation, is satisfied that the article cannot be obtained in Australia from the copyright owner or his or her licensee or agent within a reasonable time. The reference to a reasonable time is included so as to take into account the time which is reasonably required in the industry in question for an Australian copyright owner to import or manufacture and market copies of the article. The Committee's objective is not to deprive the Australian copyright owner of the right to supply articles to the Australian market but to ensure that the Australian community is able to obtain access to copyright articles within a reasonable time of their becoming available overseas.

(d) There be included a provision along the lines of sub-secs. 109 (3) and (4) of the Act empowering the making of regulations prescribing, in relation to all articles or to particular articles, the period or periods which is or are to be a reasonable time or reasonable times for the purposes of sub-para. (c).

(e) An article shall be taken to be available in Australia if there is lawfully available here an article which is substantially similar to that which the importer proposes to import. The Committee is not able to suggest a more precise expression than `substantially similar to'. It will be for the courts to apply these words to the infinite variety of circumstances that may arise. The Committee recognizes that this may lead to some uncertainty, but the use of more precise language would be likely to create a different problem, namely, that the legislation would be too inflexible. Rather than attempt a more precise definition, the Committee has given some guidance as to the way in which its proposal is to be understood by reference to some concrete examples (see paras. 91 and 137).

(2) The Copyright Act be amended so as to modify the provisions of ss. 38 and 103 (infringement by sale, letting for hire or otherwise by way of trade, offering or exposing for sale or hire articles known to have been imported into Australia in contravention of s. 37 or s. 102) so as to bring them into line with the provisions of ss.37 and 102 as modified in accordance with para. (1) above.

(3) There will be no infringement of the sections if an article is imported and copyright subsists only in a work comprised in a label or mark affixed or attached to the the article or to its packaging provided that the owner of the copyright has consented to the use of his or her work on the label or mark.

(4) Although the preponderance of submissions from those seeking the retention of the sections did not favour an amendment to the provisions concerning knowledge, the Committee is of opinion, because of the amendments which have been made to s. 132 by the Copyright Amendment Act 1986, that the knowledge provisions should be brought into line with the provisions of s. 132.
(5) The Committee considers that a person importing a non-pirated article ought not to be subject to criminal proceedings and sanctions. Civil proceedings only should lie against him.

(6) Section 135 of the Copyright Act 1968 be amended to cover all works and subject matter other than works. In consequence subsecs (4) and (9) will need to be amended to remove the reference to printed copies so that the section will apply to reproductions of all kinds. The sections should be amended to apply to exclusive licensees of copyright material as well as to owners thereof.

A suggested form of amendment of the relevant sections, other than s. 135, is attached as Appendix A. The amendment is not intended as a final legislative draft, but rather to indicate more precisely the ambit of the Committee's recommendations and that their implementation would be practical. No draft of an amendment to s. 135 is included because the alterations to it will be of a mechanical kind only.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In effect, the Copyright Law Review Committee proposed that the current restrictions under the old system relating to the parallel importing of books should be altered in such a way that, where a non-pirated copyright article is required by a person engaged in the purchase of books, that person would be allowed, through an agent, to import into Australia a book which was not available and would not be available within a reasonable period, or a book for which the importer had received a specific order in writing for the article, signed by the person requiring it, in which the person stated that the article was not required for the purposes of trade or commerce; that the onus of establishing these matters lay upon the importer; and that certain other steps were to be taken to accord protection to copyright owners so that pirated editions were excluded from this procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: The long and short of this issue is that Australians simply pay too much for their books. I wish to indicate that to the Senate by giving a few examples. I have here a book entitled The Brief History of Time by Stephen W. Hawkings. A hard cover version of this book retails for $34.95. It is one of the most successful books in terms of popular science to have been printed and published in the course of the last couple of years. It is also outstandingly one of the best popular science books of the post-war period. It has been on the best seller list in this country for the best part of 18 months. As I say, its retail price is $34.95.

It is expected that, some time towards the end of the year, a paperback version of this book will be available. At the moment, no paperback version is available. I have here, however, a paperback version of the book. It is exactly the same book, which is printed by Bantam Books Ltd. I purchased it at the airport in Bangkok, as I was on my way through that city earlier this year, for in the order of $A8. Australians cannot currently purchase that book in paperback form in Australia, nor are they likely to be able to for some months yet. They have to rely on purchasing the hard cover version for $34.95.

The second example is the fairly notorious book by Salman Rushdie entitled The Satanic Verses. It is available and has been available in this country for some time. Its retail price is $35. It is not yet available in Australia in a paperback version, nor is it likely to be until the latter part of next year. Here, however, I have a paperback version of exactly the same book, The Satanic Verses by Salman Rushdie, purchased again when I was on my way through Bangkok. It is printed by Viking Press and is available for approximately $A12. That book, terrible as it is-awful, wretched, second-rate book that it is-is nevertheless not available in that form in Australia.

A third example is a book by Alexander Leggatt, published by Routledge and Kegan Paul Ltd, entitled Shakespeare's Political Drama. It sells in the United Kingdom for #29.50. It is therefore a fairly expensive book. It is not a large book. In fact, it runs only to 270-odd pages. It is a very interesting book. As I said, it costs #29.50 in England and it would cost another couple of pounds to have it airmailed to Australia, so an Australian purchaser might be looking at $60-odd in terms of legitimate currency conversion. It is in fact available in Australian bookshops for $105.

The reason for this situation in which books are expensive and are unavailable in their cheapest form is that we follow a system derived essentially from a colonial mentality, a colonial arrangement, in which the world has been divided up essentially between the British Empire and the rest of the world for the purposes of book publication and distribution. Australia is still treated in this respect as part of the British Empire, part of a closed network of distribution of books and control of book prices.

The Government, to its credit, some time ago gave a reference to the Prices Surveillance Authority to look at the question of book prices in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the summary of the recommendations of the Prices Surveillance Authority.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PSA
SUMMARY

This Interim Report of the Authority's Inquiry into Book Prices focuses on the effects of the importation provisions of the Copyright Act 1968 on book prices and related issues of economic welfare and efficiency. It aims to provide a more extensive economic analysis of those issues than the Copyright Law Review Committee (CLRC) was able to provide.

Chapter 2 sets out the economic rationale for copyright protection, based on the general theory of property rights. In practice the State places limits on all property rights. In economic theory, those limits should be chosen so as to maximise economic welfare. The granting of copyright provides a necessary incentive for the production of intellectual products, but this benefit must be balanced against the costs of limiting access to copyright works.

The question posed by the importation provisions is whether those property rights should extend beyond the first sale to provide control over the further trading and distribution of copyright works. Those provisions currently make it illegal to import and distribute books for purposes of trade without the permission of the copyright owner. The provisions treat pirate copies and so called `parallel imports' in an identical manner.

The provisions do not derive from any international agreements to which Australia is a signatory. The Berne Convention and the Universal Copyright Convention provide for basic international recognition of copyright in reproduction not distribution. The nature and degree of protection beyond this minimum is on the basis of equal national treatment according to domestic laws.

The optimal level of protection (if any) against parallel imports depends on a balancing of costs and benefits. These costs and benefits are likely to vary between countries with a different location in the pattern of international trade.

Chapter 3 sets out the broad structure of the Australian book market. The retail value of book sales in Australia is estimated to be a little over $1,000 million. A `market for books' does not really exist in an economic sense. Substitutability in supply and demand may be quite limited between different types of books; while substitutability with other leisure and learning products, such as TV, videos, newspapers and magazines, may be quite high.

Demand for books is a function of income and occupation. Price elasticity of demand in sub-markets varies from very high to very low. For most individual titles, elasticity of demand is high. However, for some professional and technical books it may be quite low.
The supply of books is via publishers and retailers. Publishing is dominated by large global corporations, sometimes with interests in substitute and complementary products.

The traditional territorial division of copyright in English language books has meant that the supply of books to the Australian market has historically been dominated by British publishing houses and the majority of books are still imported.

Australian (and overseas) authors have found it difficult to negotiate separate publishing rights in Australia. Educational texts (other than tertiary) are now a major exception to this situation, where supply is dominated by Australian originated texts.
During the 1970s, overseas publishers created a `closed market' for the supply of imported titles to Australia. Retailers can only obtain titles legally from the exclusive distributor.

Retailing has traditionally been dominated by the small independent bookstore, and by newsagents for `mass market' titles. This situation is changing with the growth of discount bookstores, and increased sales through Department stores.

Chapter 4 examines issues of book pricing and efficiency. Copyright itself is not inconsistent with competitive product markets. It corrects the `free rider' problem associated with intellectual products. Competition between titles which seek to satisfy the same consumer wants would result in normal profits being earned. However, by extending copyright into the sphere of distribution, the importation provisions are likely to put Australia on an uneven footing with other industries, resulting in a misallocation of resources and cost inefficiencies.

Profit-maximisation from an individual title will determine a price at which marginal revenue equals marginal cost. Book publishing involves a considerable amount of risk. The publisher must estimate what demand is going to be; on some titles they will make above average profits and on other below average, but averaging across titles would provide a normal return in a competitive market.
The profit-maximising levels of output and price will not normally be those which maximise revenue and therefore authors' royalty payments.

Publishers set a uniform recommended retail price (RRP) for books throughout Australia. This `freight absorption' by suppliers is a common phenomenon in economics. It represents the profit-maximising strategy in response to demand conditions, falling marginal costs and the administrative costs associated with variable pricing.

For publishers operating in several territorial markets with different demand conditions, international price discrimination represents a profit-maximising strategy, providing markets can be effectively segmented. Importation provisions in copyright legislation provide such effective segmentation.

Competitive markets and the price mechanisms generally act as an effective mechanism for producing an optimal allocation of resources and cost efficiency in production and distribution. The distribution of books in Australia is not currently subject to such a market test.

In a world of limited economic resources, there can be too much variety, service and quality in book distribution. Stockholdings by publishers in Australia are considerably higher than for most manufacturing industry. It is suggested that a competitive market would be the best determinant of an optimal level and composition of stockholdings.

The costs of distribution make up around half of the RRP of a book. Although some publishers appear to have technically efficient distribution systems, others may be hiding operating inefficiencies behind the protection of the importation provisions. The wealth of evidence on poor delivery times suggests such inefficiency is widespread. While recent years have seen some improvements in terms of mass handling, the current multiplicity of distribution systems would appear to be losing out on potential gains in operating efficiency.

Chapter 5 examines empirical data on book prices in Australia. There are many pitfalls to beware of in examining price data, especially in making price comparisons. The comparisons utilised in this chapter all compare identical samples of books and examine the issues of international price discrimination and the relative prices of US and UK editions of books.

The evidence suggests that publishers do engage in international price discrimination and that Australian consumers generally lose out from this practice. Publishers operating in the UK, Canada and Australia are able to set Canadian retail prices consistently below those in the UK, despite the additional costs of freight; while charging consistently higher prices in Australia. The average price differentials for Canada were $0.35 and 2.6 per cent below the UK; and for Australia $2.99 and 31.30 per cent above the UK. Price discrimination appears to have its greatest effect in the market for professional and technical books; while tertiary text books are generally priced at quite reasonable levels in Australia.

Where separate UK and US editions of titles are published, Australia generally has access only to the UK edition. For a sample of mass market paperback bestsellers, the domestic price of the UK edition was an average of $US1.54 and 30.6 per cent more expensive than the domestic price of the US edition. Quality differences exist between the two editions, but these differences cannot be judged in any absolute sense. Consumers in Australia are not currently able to exercise a choice.

Chapter 6 considers the possible consequences of repeal of the importation provisions or reform along the lines proposed by the CLRC. Repeal of the provisions would create enormous potential for improvements in allocative and cost efficiency, lower prices and improved economic welfare. While the CLRC proposals would go some way to improving delivery times in book distribution, it seems unlikely that there would be any major benefit in terms of lower prices. A major problem of the proposals is their essentially regulatory nature and the administrative costs which that would impose. Repeal of the provisions may pose some dangers for the further development of Australian literature, but recent growth in that area is essentially demand and profit driven. Furthermore, repeal would seem likely to make separate publishing rights for Australia more feasible, since the value of those rights to UK publishers would be reduced.

Chapter 7 contains the Authority's conclusions and recommendations. The Authority recommends repeal of the importation provisions with two exceptions: pirate editions; and Australian resident authors with separate Australian publishing contracts. The latter is to operate for ten years, to provide support for an `infant industry'. The Authority recognises that this may cause some problems in relation to the Berne Convention; although the importation provisions do not derive from that Convention, it may be construed as requiring national treatment if such provisions exist. It is also recognised that overnight repeal of the provisions could cause significant disruption for industry participants, and it is recommended that a one year period of notice be given to allow the industry to prepare for a competitive market.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Prices Surveillance Authority has recommended what might be regarded as a fundamentally deregulatory approach, an open market approach, for Australian books. It has done so by making an attack upon the copyright restrictions and provisions of the Copyright Act as they exist at the moment and as they serve to protect the position essentially of British publishers and to impede the position of Australian purchasers. The recommendations say in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Competitive markets and the price mechanism generally act as an effective mechanism for producing an optimal allocation of resources and cost efficiency in production and distribution.
The distribution of books in Australia is not currently subject to such a market test.

The report goes on to assert that price differentials between books which can be purchased in Canada, the United Kingdom and Australia are as follows: for Canada, 35c and 2.6 per cent below the United Kingdom; and for Australia, $2.99 and 31.3 per cent above the United Kingdom. The Canadians, who are part of the same British Commonwealth market as Australia, nevertheless have book prices which are reduced by their proximity to the more open, and more accessible, United States market.

In Australia we continue to pay an additional premium for a whole series of reasons. I do not deny that the people who support this particular system claim two things: first, the size of the Australian market and, secondly, the necessity to protect the position of Australian authors are such that some sort of restricted arrangement in terms of Australia's economic evaluation and cultural policy should be maintained. Those arguments have been carefully thought through and carefully analysed by the Prices Surveillance Authority and essentially have been rejected, although the recommendations of the PSA provide a let-out for people who have local Australian contracts and for the protection of Australian authors for a period of, I think, 10 years. Therefore, an open slather is not proposed by the PSA but, rather, a modified version which would lead in due course to a freeing-up of the market.

At this stage I pause to pay great tribute to Professor Fels, the Chairman of the PSA, and his colleagues on that body for the extraordinarily perceptive and significant job they have done in producing their report. However, I must say that one of the things that immediately came to mind when I analysed what the PSA report says about book importers and publishers was a very famous quote of Adam Smith in his book The Wealth of Nations:
People of the same trade seldom meet together, even for merriment and diversion, but the conversation ends in a conspiracy against the public, or some other contrivance to raise prices.
To all intents and purposes that is precisely what has been occurring in Australia.

This matter has not gone without public comment over a prolonged period of time. I pay great tribute to the work of the journalist Robert Haupt, who has for a prolonged period of time campaigned on precisely this question. I have looked at Robert Haupt's articles, stretching back over a period of almost 12 months. On 5 November 1988 he wrote an article entitled, `Bound for Botany Bay. Why Britain still decides what you can read'. On the same day he wrote, `New try to break UK hold'. On the same day, `The closed book market'. On 7 November 1988, `A long drawn-out lesson that words are cheap'. Again on 7 November, `Publishing power game-why we must wait for books'. On 8 November 1988, `Bowen's quest is to strike an equitable balance'. On the same day, `Australians pay more for their paperbacks'. On 18 November 1988 he wrote, `Something rotten in the state of the book battle'. On 10 March 1989, `Touche! The publishers strike back'. On 14 March 1989, `The truth about our publishers'. On 22 July 1989, `Wilder's broadside could free book market from British control'.

Mr Haupt was quite assiduous in pursuing a lone campaign to bring to the attention of people in Australia the rort which was going on in our book trade. When the PSA report appeared, Mr Haupt appeared to have a slight wheel wobble about going immediately to the more deregulatory model. On 12 September 1989 he wrote an articled entitled, `Book market reform plan perhaps a little drastic'. After thinking about the matter for another fortnight he was able to write on 25 October 1989, `Turning the page to new era of freedom'. Mr Haupt deserves great credit for bringing into the public domain the debate about book pricing in Australia.

When the PSA report came out it was largely welcomed. The Sydney Morning Herald, in its editorial on 12 September, stated, `PSA right on publishing'. On the same day, in the same newspaper, John Sampson wrote, `Books: A victory for the reader'. On the same day Paddy McGuinness wrote in the Australian, `Our book market must grow up'. He wrote in another article, `Time is up for British publishers' cosy deals'. In the Australian Barry Lowe wrote, `PSA slams book trade monopoly'. Julie Power, in the Australian Financial Review on the same day, wrote, `Open book market urged'. On 4 October 1989 Tom Dusevic wrote in the Australian Financial Review, `Book market debate ignores the importance of Australian readers', making the point that the PSA report was the first report to put the book reader as the central determinant of the Australian book import policy. On 13 September 1989, in the Sydney Morning Herald, Ross Gittins wrote, `High book prices literally a rip-off'. Max Suich, in the Sydney Morning Herald on 24 October 1989, wrote, `A small advance in the debate on Australia's publishing trade'. The PSA report has been increasingly seen as one which looks after the interests of the Australian book reading public.

Needless to say, there was a certain amount of opposition to the PSA report. Bodies such as the Australian Music Publishers Association and the Australian Record Industry Association noted that the PSA, in its report, said that it would look at the record industry next and were suddenly up in arms about that. Distinguished authors such as Peter Carey thought it would be the destruction of Australian literature and the position of Australian authors. Mr Mark Rubbo of the Australian Book Sellers Association believed that book sellers would be substantially disadvantaged. They basically said, `If we have an open market stuff will be dumped on us, particularly American products'.

Mr Zifcak, the Executive Chairman of Collins booksellers, wrote a letter to the Australian Financial Review on 26 September basically saying, `If we have got to go to the process of reform let us go to the copyright law review committees-a lesser position. But for heaven's sake, let us not be pushed into a deregulatory open market situation because all sorts of things could happen, including the fact that our distributors would not hold as much stock in Australia and, as a result, people would find it more difficult to get the books they want'.
Mr Laurie Muller, the head of the University of Queensland Press, made the claim that this would be a blow to Australian culture. In the Sydney Morning Herald on 3 August 1989, Mr Muller wrote:

This country, as it struggles to its cultural feet after two centuries of insecurity, is in very real danger of being put on its backside again by the new tyranny of a threatened open market. We simply do not have the size, or resilience as a nation, to survive culturally in such an environment.

That is probably the ultimate cultural cringe. Eventually, even the booksellers started to wake up to the realities of the world and, earlier this month, suddenly decided that they would back the Sheppard halfway house recommendations, although I note that the New South Wales branch of the Book Publishers Association indicated its support for an open market.

When the report came down, in my capacity as shadow Minister for the arts, with responsibility for cultural policy matters, I put out a press statement on 12 September headed, `The Australian Books Trade: Report by Prices Surveillance Authority', in which I said that the report was moving in the right direction. I seek leave to incorporate a copy of that press release in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE AUSTRALIAN BOOKS TRADE: REPORT BY PRICES SURVEILLANCE AUTHORITY
In terms of its potential impact on Australian cultural policy, the draft report from the PSA on the Australian book trade is one of the most important developments in recent years.

I welcome the report, endorse its general conclusions and hope that the Government will now take action to move in the direction which it suggests. The Report builds upon the constructive recommendations made some time ago by the Copyright Law Review Committee which themselves have languished without sufficient support from Government.

The work of journalists such as Robert Haupt has over recent months focused attention on what Australian book purchasers have known all along-that books in Australia are too expensive and often too difficult to obtain. It is quite outrageous that those of us who are able to travel overseas can purchase cheap editions of best-sellers such as Hawking's A Brief History of Time (Bantam) or Salman Rushdie's Satanic Verses (Viking) at airports like Bangkok or Singapore for $A10 while domestic consumers have to pay $A20 to $A30 for the same book in restrictive hard-cover editions.

I am not impressed with the argument that opening up of the Australian market will pose a threat to the continued viability of the Australian publishing industry or destroy the demand for Australian works of literature. So long as Australians want to read the works of their local authors the demand will be there and hopefully the interest in Australian literature overseas will continue to grow.

Lessons from our film and television industry need to be studied in this regard as do the lessons to be learned from the growth of international interest in writings from South and Latin America. Support for this industry also exists and can be adjusted within the terms of the Bounty (Books) Act under which some $25.5 million was spent last year.

Taken together the Copyright Law Review Committee, the Prices Surveillance Authority recommendations are genuinely radical. They strike at the heart of a closed, cosy colonial relationship which has benefited a large number of people, but not the people who really matter-the Australian book consumers.

I believe the time has arrived to strike out into this intellectual brave new world-for those who believe that ideas and literature should be challenging and should be prepared to confront the perceived verities and the comfortable status quo let them also apply these tests to the structure of their industry, in the end I am sure we will all benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Professor Fels, the Chairman of the PSA, in a letter published in the Australian Financial Review on 4 October made the point that this was not a matter of the privileges of the Australian publishers; rather it was a matter of Australian consumers. He wrote in that letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The choice for Australian consumers is not between having a title `for $12.95 now or $10.95 in four months' time'. For new titles it is more likely to be between having a title for $12.95 whenever it suits the British publisher to supply it, or having the title for $10.95 now under an open market.

I think that that is entirely correct. I want to say a couple of words about the Australian book market. People tend to think that we are talking about a market in which there is only a small amount of Australian material. The truth of the matter is that Australian-originated books are now at least 50 per cent of the books sold in this country. That figure has increased since 1974 when the figure was only some 15 per cent. Like Australian drama on television it has increased because Australians want to read Australian material. It has increased fundamentally not because of all other extraneous supports which are provided to the industry but because Australians want to read about Australia in works published by Australians. It ought to be made clear that they tend not to read what is regarded as highbrow literature. In non-fiction material in Australia, Australian book sales are dominated by food books, sport books and books about improving our health. If we look at the best sellers in Australia, the best selling books in Australia listed in an article in the Bulletin of 4 October 1988--

TALK.START.PARA: —A biography of Bob Hawke?

—Almost a biography of Bob Hawke; it is a book by John O'Grady entitled They're a Weird Mob. It managed to sell 1.2 million copies in this country. The best foreign books at that stage were the novels The Godfather by Mario Puzo and Jaws by Peter Benchley, each of which had sold half a million copies. The best selling hardcover books in Australia included, for example, The Australian Women's Weekly Cookbook, which sold more than one million copies. In terms of sport, Fishing in Australia by Jack Pollard sold more than 650,000 copies. That is not a cheap book. It is quite clear that in Australia books about lifestyle, sport, recreation, cooking and fitness are major sellers. Those sorts of books will not in any way be affected by these changes.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, Australian publishers have significant opportunities in the international market. In the United States, Australian books teaching people about literacy are major sellers. Senator Colston, who is here this evening, has had a long interest in questions of literacy and education. I may say, for example, that the State of New York has spent more than $250,000 training 70 tutors on the basis of using South Australia's early literacy in-service courses. Books written in Australia about the promotion of literacy and about teaching people to be literate are major international sellers and an area in which Australian books are extremely well regarded and have an extremely bright commercial future. According to the figures prepared for the Cultural Ministers Council's statistical advisory group in March 1989, wholesale book sales in Australia constituted some $500m worth of wholesale book sales and some $880m worth of retail book sales.

There are some unique niches. For example, I have had representations on behalf of Koorong Books Pty Ltd, which is one of this country's major importers of Christian books, saying that it hopes that the barriers will be reduced because there is a substantial disadvantage to it in importing Christian books, nearly all of which are published overseas. The National Library of Australia in its submission to the Prices Surveillance Authority said that it believes that the Copyright Law Review Committee report should be put in place because this would go some way towards ensuring the timely availability of overseas publications to the Australian community.

It is not as if the book industry and publishers have been without assistance in this country. They have had that in some respects since the introduction of the Berne convention in 1886, since 1952 with Australia's accession to the Universal Copyright Convention and since the 1912 Copyright Act which was modelled on the 1911 UK Copyright Act. In 1968 following the report of the Spicer committee we eliminated parallel importing which had operated up until that date in order to give some protection to Australian booksellers. In 1977 as a result of the Time-Life case taken against Angus and Robertson, they were prevented from importing books under the parallel importing system which the Spicer committee had outlawed to protect the local industry. In 1969 the Bounty (Books) Act was introduced. It provided a bounty assistance to local publishers which, although it has been declining over recent years, is still nevertheless a significant bounty. That bounty aids local manufacturers, particularly at a time when the value of the Australian dollar is falling. The Act also has additional clauses that help the book industry in Australia by the restrictions which are imposed under customs legislation about the importation of books which are obscene, indecent or blasphemous. Those books nevertheless can still be printed in Australia but cannot be imported to Australia because of the provisions of the Customs Act.

In 1971 after the report of the Trade Practices Tribunal retail price maintenance was abolished. In 1974 there was a major anti-trust case in the United States, where the United States Department of Justice filed suit against 21 American publishing companies because of the carve-up of the world between the United States and the British Commonwealth. As a result of that in May 1976 there was an out of court settlement which scrapped the traditional markets agreement, as it was called, and opened up the United States to a great deal more competition. As I said, the Bounty (Books) Act is not insignificant. For example, in this last year $25m of public money went to support the Bounty (Books) Act. The bounty paid on printing of books in Australia has been substantial-$17.4m in 1984-85; $18.8m in 1985-86; $18.4m in 1986-87; $20.7m in 1987-88 and, as I said, $25.5m in the last year-representing throughout those years a percentage of our total bounty and subsidy payment rising from 6.59 per cent in 1984-85 to well over 8 per cent in this last year.

The economics of the book industry are something we could take another couple of days to discuss. I want to say to the Minister-I am grateful to Senator Bolkus for coming into the chamber and listening to my contribution this evening-that we believe there are two steps to be taken in this particular matter. The first is to proceed straight away with the enactment of the Sheppard recommendations to bring about a situation of parallel importing. The second is to encourage the Prices Surveillance Authority to move from its interim report through the process of coming to its final report. We will not pre-empt what the PSA has to say in its final report. But I make it clear on behalf of the Opposition that we think that the PSA is moving in the correct direction. We believe that it is proper to wait until the PSA brings down its final report and then to consider a position based on that: nevertheless the PSA is moving in the correct direction.

The removal of the barriers to the importation of books to Australia so that the Australian consumer gets the book at the cheapest possible price in the edition that he or she chooses to buy and in the minimum period of time is the correct way to move.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the only reason you are doing this now-to advance one step at a time?

—I take note of the Minister's interjection. It is in order to advance one step at a time so that if the Government takes some time to consider its response to the PSA report we will at least, have moved to the Sheppard position. Our hope is that, in fact, we would move beyond that to the PSA position and that the recommendations about breaking down the barriers to the importation of books in Australia would be acted upon as swiftly as possible. The PSA has done an outstanding job for Australia. I commend its report and I hope that the Government will have the fortitude to embrace its recommendations and move in that direction as expeditiously as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I, along with, I assume, all my colleagues, received a roneoed bulk mail-out from one Barbara McGregor, the publisher of a magazine called Australian Well-being. I freely admit that I do not give as much attention to a roneoed bulk mail-out as I do to personalised letters which someone has bothered to write to me and sign. Ms McGregor has a very good point to make. She drew to the attention of everyone to whom she sent her little package a change in Australia Post's regulations with respect to subscription discounts for publications produced in Australia. Apparently, Australia Post has now decided that, where the retail price of a publication exceeds $5 these discounts will no longer be available. Ms McGregor says that this is a stupid move and the case that she puts, I think, is quite a good one.

SPEECH.PARA: She says that as a consequence of this, a monthly publication such as the Australian Women's Weekly-which is not at all intended to diminish the standing in the community of the Australian Women's Weekly-will continue to be posted to subscribers for around 45c per edition, whereas a bi-monthly publication such as hers, Australian Well-being, of a similar size and weight, will now cost the publisher somewhere between $1.65 and $2 each to post, depending on where the magazine is being sent, that is, a fourfold or fivefold increase.

I am told that the argument Australia Post put forward is that it is losing $20m a year on subscription postal handling. Australia Post cannot exactly identify where this money is lost. It is not really full bottle on its own argument. But, as Ms McGregor says, in this area an enormous amount of pre-sorting is already done. She makes the point that publications that sell for less than $5 are printed on cheaper paper, have a high advertising content and are generally disposable in the short to middle term, whereas material costing over $5 is generally on higher quality paper, has a higher editorial to advertising ratio and operates on far less a publishing margin than the mass media do. She asks the question: Can Australia Post really contend that Kerry Packer, for example, is less able to afford a higher rate of postage for subscription handling of the Australian Women's Weekly than she is, a small and unknown publisher?

Ms McGregor was kind enough to send everybody a copy of her magazine. It is quite different from the Australian Women's Weekly. It contains article on herbs and nutritional updates. If I want to read the advertisements I can, for example, select from a number of advertisements on flotation tanks, if I feel that I need some sort of relaxation. If I think I need some nutritional or colon therapy there are plenty of advertisements telling me where I can go to get that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some nice recipes.

—There are. I can read about the role of vitamins in coping with stress and metabolic imbalance. I can read about chronic fatigue syndrome and the hidden cause of common female disorders. As well as the recipes that Senator Reid was good enough to draw attention to, I can read about clues to live longer and have more fun by stimulating my endorphin flow.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no self-interest in raising this matter. I am not a reader of Australian Well-being and, having had a quick look at it, am not sure that I will become one. But none of that detracts from the points that Ms McGregor makes. Why should Australia Post offer this discount to people who sell material for less than $5 and not to people who want to sell it for more than $5? It seems a totally irrational and typically bureaucratic decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —It also destroys most of the small cultural magazines in this country.

—As Senator Puplick says, and the point is made by plenty of people upset by this, it will destroy a lot of the small cultural magazines that necessarily, because of their small size, have an expensive price on their magazines. Worse still, sometimes we can wear irrational and bureaucratic decisions if we have had a hand in fighting the battle, but in this particular case the proposal was apparently announced totally without consultation and at very short notice, without any attempt to phase it in over an extended period. This, of course, means that publications that have worked very hard at getting long-term subscriptions at an accepted subscription price just have to weather the loss of income occasioned by higher expenses; namely, higher postal charges.

SPEECH.PARA: The further point is made that Australia Post says that it cannot continue to subsidise these sorts of magazines. That may be the case. Perhaps Australia Post does want to look at the rules and regulations that govern registered postal discounts. But it is my suggestion that if it wants to look at that it should do so with some sense and not just draw some $5 cut-off point and leave it at that and have the quality magazines, those that are trying to do a good job, pay more. This cut-off point would in fact give a discount to the cheaper publications. It just does not seem sensible.

Apart from it not seeming sensible because it has no rhyme or reason to it in the first place, it is not sensible for another reason. The publications that are printed in Australia-and this magazine is a quality printing job; we could not call it a second-rate job-will have to look at how they are going to cut their costs if they want to keep going. One way they can cut their costs is to send their printing offshore. They would make significant costs reductions, perhaps enough to make up for the increased Australia Post charges. But where will that leave us? Australian printers will be out of jobs. Why? Because Australia Post thinks that someone selling something for over $5 should be able to pay a higher postal charge than someone who is selling for less than $5.

The idiocy of this is that some of the magazines that will continue to get this discount are high volume magazines. It is not as if there is any real benefit to Australia Post, as if there is any saving in higher volumes. Subscription magazines still have to be put in each letterbox. If a magazine is subscribed to by 16 million people, is that 16 million times a postman has to put that magazine in a letterbox. There is no way of reducing the cost of doing that. It is not as if there is a saving in that respect. So I think Ms McGregor has probably made some very good points.

I understand that one of the Australian Democrats, Senator Sanders, has raised this matter and put some questions on notice. I am informed by my colleague Senator Reid that an answer has been produced, but I have not had the opportunity to see it. Without wishing to appear an intellectual pig, I am reasonably satisfied that the answer will not answer these questions. It cannot. The case is so good for not drawing a line on the basis simply of the price of a magazine that I am at a loss to imagine what the answer will be. I look forward to leaving the chamber and looking at that answer. I give the Minister at the table, Senator Bolkus, an undertaking-and not lightly-that if the answer is a good one I will come back on Monday and withdraw everything I have said. But I am quite sure it will not be. I invite the Minister to address the attention of his colleague Mr Willis to this matter and to the answer that has been given. If it is, as I suspect, a glib cover-up of a hopeless and inefficient bureaucratic decision that he will give a return undertaking to have something done about it so that the producers of quality magazines such as Australian Well-being first of all do not suffer higher costs as a consequence of a stupid decision but also, secondly, do not take their printing offshore and so cause Australian jobs to be lost as a consequence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of points in responding, first, to the remarks of Senator Vanstone. I suggest that maybe in the first instance she should talk to her colleague Senator Alston, who has a very deep interest in statutory organisations and government business enterprises having to perform competitively and having to review their community service obligations. He also has a very keen interest in ensuring that subsidies are not given in an indirect way. Maybe what Australia Post is trying to do-I take the point that $5 seems to be an arbitrary figure; and I am not a long-time defender of Australia Post-is rationalise its community service operations. The rationale behind its decision may be to assist the least expensive magazines. I am sure, as she said, that Senator Sanders has had a reply. I am also sure that she will get a free annual subscription to Australian Well-being. I suggest that, in terms of Astral Health, she should not dismiss so quickly some of the remedies and treatments that are mentioned in that magazine.
—She wasn't.
—She went very cursorily through things such as flotation therapy and so on.
—You want to read the whole magazine.

—In fact, I have read the magazine. It might surprise the honourable senator to know that it is one of the magazines that I have read in recent months. I actually find some value in it. But I will take up her point and pass it on to the relevant Minister.
—She was not rubbishing it.
—I was not rubbishing the magazine.

—The honourable senator was not all that keen to indulge in some of the therapies. I would suggest to all honourable senators that a bit of stress therapy might do us some good, particularly at 11.12 at night. But I will pass that contribution on to the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very pleased to hear the comments made by Senator Puplick. I think it has taken 99 months for us to come to some agreement across the chamber. I am pleased to see that Senator Puplick has taken a certain position on the whole question of the book trade in Australia. I asked the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) to inquire into the price of books in this country. This was stimulated by my own concern about the way in which the book trade is run, the articles that Senator Puplick mentioned by Robert Haupt and the Sheppard report-the Copyright Law Review Committee report-which also made mention of the need for an economically based inquiry into the area.

I agree with Senator Puplick that the PSA has done a marvellous, if not sterling, job in this instance. I think Senator Puplick mentioned Professor Allan Fels. We should also recognise the work done by David Cousins, Len Hatch and also Stan Honey who have produced the report. Basically they found that what we read in Australia, when we read it and how much we pay for it is dictated by British publishers who have no real recognition of the demands of the marketplace in this country and, in fact, the demands of the consuming public in this country.

Senator Puplick cited some books that he has had problems with. During the course of this inquiry a couple of books came to my notice that I thought were handled by the publishers in a most outrageous way. One example of this is a book written about Michael Dukakis and the Unites States presidential campaign. That book was quite relevant and timely where it was published in the United States. But from what I have been told, it seems that this book has been published in Australia in the last month or so. It is quite irrelevant to the Australian scene. As people in the United States are asking, `Where is Dukakis now?'. One wonders what people in Australia are saying about Michael Dukakis and his relevance to world politics.

I have been trying for some time to get a book called Love in the Time of Cholera by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. The book was published internationally probably 18 months or two years ago and was written by a Nobel Prize winning author. It was in the book stores of Australia in hard cover at the end of last year, but was released in paperback only in the last three weeks. I think that for the book publishing industry to be under scrutiny publicly and at the same time to deny the Australian public access to a book such as this by an internationally acclaimed author is totally outrageous. Such an attitude totally disregards the considerations and sensitivities not only of government, but also of book readers. I do not think there is any doubt that the Sheppard review and the PSA review have demonstrated the need for change, the need for law reform in this area. It has been demonstrated very strongly. There is no doubt that the book-reading public are the ones who will benefit from that particular change.

I do not accept, as Senator Puplick does not, the arguments of very few Australian authors who have gained some prominence in recent days. I am quite sceptical also of the interwoven nature of the Australian book publishers coming out in support of some protection for the British copyright holders. It is curious to see what sort of interwoven relationships there are between those publishers and those in the United Kingdom, but also when we remove the corporate shield the sort of interwoven relationship there is between the British publishers and those in the United States who will have access to Australian markets, given some law reform in this area. I am pleased to see that Senator Puplick mentioned that he is committed to the PSA attitude in this area. I am and, as I said earlier, I have no doubt that the Government recognises there is a need for change and that the aspirations of quite a number of people for reform in this area will be met in the very near future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.18 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 21 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: With regard to an answer to an Estimates Committee Question on Notice (14/4/89), in which I was advised that the Defence Department had requested that the requirement to fully substantiate Uniform Maintenance Allowance expenditure be made effective on 1 July 1989; and in which I was also advised that as of 28 April 1989, no response had been received from the Australian Taxation Office, but that the issue would be followed up during the preparation of the ADF Income Tax Guide in May 1989: (a) has a decision on the matter been taken yet; if so, what is it; if not why not, and when can a decision be expected; and (b) was the matter resolved in time for inclusion in the ADF Income Tax Guide.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Taxation Office responded to Defence on 27 June 1989 advising that it was unable to relax the substantiation rules as requested, nor could it grant a general remission from tax penalties. However, ATO branches were to be advised to take the change in circumstances into account in cases where ADF members were requested to substantiate UMA expenditure. Further, penalties would not be imposed where members had not included UMA in tax returns and not claimed a deduction; or where any deduction claimed did not exceed the amount of UMA included in the return. Full substantiation rules were to apply from 1 July 1989.
The response was received too late for inclusion in the 1989 ADF Income Tax Guide which was released on 19 June 1989 to enable the Guide to be published in July editions of the Services' newspapers.
The information contained in the Australian Taxation Office response was circulated to the Services on 3 July 1989.
